story:
The Aurora AppCo Alumni Series is an annual event hosted by Aurora Theatre in their Studio space. The goal of the Series is to give a platform to past and present apprentices creating their own work featuring young artists. The Series provides experience, and a voice, to the future of theatre in Atlanta. 

This is the second year of the Series. The two shows this year are Fish Eye by Lucas Kavner and A New Brain by William Finn and James Lapine. 
Fish Eye takes a slightly skewed look at four intertwining lives as we wade through their memories and examine what causes certain moments to crystallize in our minds, and how we look back when those moments have passed.
A New Brain is a musical that follows the story of Gordon Schwinn, a struggling, frustrated songwriter who suffers from a rare brain disorder that causes him to hallucinate, amongst other things, a tyrannical singing, dancing frog.

As young artists, we need funding to be able to do justice to these fantastic, fun, and quirky pieces of theatre. Funding which can help cover the costs of costumes, sets, props, royalties, marketing, and hopefully the ability to pay our talented team of actors and designers.

Our goal is $10,000. With the help of our friends and the friends of Atlanta theatre, this is super-doable. AND as a special way of saying "THANK YOU, YOU'RE AMAZING AND WE LOVE YOU!", we have some truly unique and fun perks for donors at all levels!

If you can't give a lot, give a little! If you can't give a little, please help spread the word about the exciting work we're doing!

story:
Kairos

Kairos is a 50-minute dance event which traces the embodied timelines of six dancers. Too often, dancers’ stories are ignored in favor of their physical abilities. The aim of Kairos is to invert this tendency and through collage, poetry, electronic music and movement, tell their stories— from the quotidian to the traumatic. 

In today’s society, women are physically inhibited by the clothes they wear, the movements they are taught, the pressures that are placed upon their beings by the ever present need for female perfection. Too often we ignore the backstory, how and why each woman came to look, to speak and to move as she does today. Kairos uses media images from magazines that trace the beauty trends throughout the years of each dancer’s life, in order to trigger the reactions of our company members. These reactions materialize for the audience in collage, poetic, musical and choreographic form. 

The aim of Kairos is to be an evening of visual art, poetry, electronic music and dance. An evening where the unique story of each dancer is told. Above all, it is an evening where the personal can become universal as the audience engages with each dancer. 

Who We Are: 

Ephemera Dance Company is composed  of woman movers. Our artistic aim is to marry the genres of collage, electronic music, poetry and movement. The company takes its name from collected materials that have a short-lived expression— similarly Ephemera’s work is improvisation-based, time durational and participatory, thus taking aim at theatrical conventions. Ephemera values the unique emotional expression of each mover, be they musician, dancer or audience member. As an all female company, EDC aims to challenge preconceived notions of femininity and fembody expression. 

Katrina Elizabeth (Artistic Director) trained as a contemporary dancer at the San Francisco Conservatory and the Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance. She received a degree in literature from Reed College in Portland, Oregon. Her area of investigation was the grotesque genre and its influence upon poetic and performance conventions. Katrina Elizabeth now lives and works in Germany where she is artistic director of Ephemera Dance Company—a dance company of women movers that works within collage, poetry, and movement. Her work investigates cultural biases towards women, especially as they pertain to bodily awareness and expression.

Film: Kamilla Gylfadóttir

Music: Katja Kettler

Dancers:

Amit Abend 

Laura Guy

Alice Botelho

Julia Rauch 

Julia Monschau 

Veronica Lillo 

We Need Your Help!

Any contribution you might be able to make will be infinitely helpful.  Most importantly, your contribution will help our artists get paid for their work.  Additionally, your support will cover studio space, collage materials, costumes, and performance fees.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to our shows! We will be hosting informal showings throughout the summer. Stay tuned and follow our facebook page to stay up to date. Please also consider sharing our campaign with your networks and friends!

story:
The Landless Theatre Company will produce the classic musical 1776 at the Weinberg Center on the weekend of June 30-July 2. The musical dramatizes the days leading up to the signing of our Declaration of Independence, bringing to life founding figures John and Abigail Adams, Thomas Jefferson, Ben Franklin, and many others.

"In our current climate of polarized political opinions, it's important to remember that the founders of the United States frequently disagreed with each other - often vehemently," said Producing Artistic Director Andrew Baughman. "Each one was a patriot, and what better way to celebrate the 4th of July in Frederick."

Baughman will co-direct the production with wife Melissa Baughman (2015 Helen Hayes Award Outstanding Director nominee), and appear in the role of John Adams. The production concept features a core of professional actors with local elected officials and community leaders in the supporting roles.

"As a teenager in the mid 90's I attended a production of 1776 at DC's Constitution Hall that utilized US Representatives and Senators in a number of cameo roles," said Baughman. "It made for a very exciting event, and we hope to capture some of that spirit in this production."

The current list of special guest performers includes Rick Weldon (former MD Delegate,  Vice President of Frederick Chamber of Commerce), Michael O’Connor (Frederick Alderman), Josh Pedersen (Former United Way of Frederick CEO, MD 2-1-1 referral system), Jason Hoffman (Theater Arts Teacher, TJ High School), and Frederick's Mayor Randy McClement. 

Filling out the cast are regional actors Matt Baughman, Bob Causer, Chris Causer, Clay Comer, Robert Herbertson, David Horch, Eric Jones, Laura J. Martin, Lee Merriman, Jaclyn Muir, Ray Shaw, Tim Seltzer, Wilson Seltzer, Bill Stitely, and Alex Throne.

The Landless Theatre Company is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to cultivating new and diverse audiences for live theatre. Founded in 2003, the company is most recently known for its METALTHEATRE movement to create rock orchestrations of classic musicals. Landless was given special permission by Stephen Sondheim to orchestrate and produce SWEENEY TODD [PROG METAL VERSION], which was nominated for three 2015 Helen Hayes Awards, including Outstanding Musical and Outstanding Direction of a Musical.

Proceeds from 1776 will benefit Landless' 2018 premiere of THE MYSTERY OF EDWIN DROOD [SYMPHONIC METAL PRODUCTION], presented with special permission from Tony-winner, mystery novelist, and pop music veteran Rupert Holmes.

story:
The Story

Peter and Raff's piece got its start with Walla Walla Dance Festival in the summer of 2015, and was enthusiastically received last fall at Against The Grain/Men in Dance's choreographic showcase at Velocity in Seattle.  After renovating the piece for a successful performance at Seattle International Dance Festival in June, Peter and Raff welcomed the opportunity to take the piece to an international platform.  What began as a humble conversation about continuing to make dance work for the local scene has produced a piece that has a life all its own.  What will be next?


What We Need & What You Get

Here's the nitty gritty on money:

We need two round trip tickets from Walla Walla to Warsaw.  These will cost roughly 1,650 dollars each.  We can't go for rock-bottom plane tickets because we are taking only a week away from our regular professional obligations, and we need to arrive in Poland rested and ready to perform.

We need lodging.  The conference has offered to help us with rooms at the University of Warsaw.  Rooms will cost in the neighborhood of 50 dollars per person per night.  We plan to spend five nights in Warsaw, totaling 1,100 dollars. Per diem at the same rate will also total 1,100.


And here's our blurb:

"We wanted to be machines again," an intimate contemporary dance piece, opens with autobiographical dance monologues in which two career artists reflect on their nostalgic desire to return to the hard demands of company life.  The introspective voiceover soundtrack of the first section gives way to an energized, intricately partnered duet set to the piano/rhythm fusion of jazz adept Bugge Wesseltoft and techno superstar Henrik Schwarz.


The Impact

Peter and Raff live in Walla Walla, and are representing the United States at a major international event in Warsaw.  This is an opportunity to support two local boys with a lock on the international scene!

story:
About

My name is Spencer Frankeberger, and I have a BM in Music Therapy and an MFA in Film Production and found a love of both of these expressive arts and found a way to combine both film and music but also adding a third love: theatre.  This project is very important to me because it's a unique idea, and I feel I can express this story without judgment and allow others to view the world in a different way.  Your contributions will help make my dream a reality!

Budgeting & Incentives

We have a long road to go to bring this show to its full potential, and here's what our budget will go toward:
-Hollywood Fringe registration
-Hollywood Fringe rental fees
-production insurance
-compensation for cast and crew
-costumes, makeup, wigs (we have drag queens after all!)
-marketing
-rental space for rehearsals
-expendables (printing scripts, ticketing elements, etc.)
Anything and everything helps as it helps get one step closer to the goal!
Unique Perks:
-individualized jingle
-complimentary tickets to a show of your choice
-signed memorabilia
and more!

Themes & Topics

Some talking points from this project include: LGBT acceptance, powering through struggles and hardships, the meaning of love, finding the creativity, and much more!

Ways to Help

If you cannot donate at this time, I certainly understand, but please like our FB page, follow us on Twitter and IG, come see our performance at the Eclectic Theatre, and share this page with your friends!

story:
who are we? 

We fell in love dancing at a party at Ecole Jacques Lecoq theatre school. We were both there with the intention of absorbing a technique that could help us to translate the world with our bodies. From there we developed an interest in gestures, space, composition and a love of images. 

We work across disciplines, including but not exclusive to theatre, installation and short films. We are interested in unconscious human desires, public and private spaces, wakefulness and sleep, nature and its opposite.

Cut Tongues is a creative marriage, born from the need to cut up our universe in order to re-constitute it and present it in unforeseen ways. We use a visual language because this is the language of our dreams.

We have devised toured and performed multiple shows with previous companies- Clout Theatre and RemoteControl, taking work to China, Russia, Norway, Germany, France, Turkey and round the UK, winning awards and acclaim.


what are we doing? 

This is an event on the cusp of installation and theatre, concerned with voyeurism, the everyday and judgement in communities. 

The idea began it's life when we read the story 'Some Of Us Had Been Threatening Our Friend Colby' by Donald Barthelme (having bought it purely because we liked the title). It's about a group of friends who get together to hang their pal Colby, because he has 'gone too far'. It is dead-pan funny, disturbing and poetic. Kafka for a postmodern world. 

Ever since then we have been searching for a way to work on this story. A straight theatre adaptation didn't seem right. Little by little the idea of a hyper-real museum of human domestic installations emerged. We believe that through looking at the mundane minutiae of existence we are best placed to understand pressing existential questions. The domestic scenes and their inhabitants are viewed by a public through a perspex screen as in a cabinet at the Natural History museum. Time is slowed almost to a stop, the skin is given a waxy quality: the dissonance between the presence and absence of life is amplified as the body becomes part-object.

We have already tried out the idea at a group exhibition where we created a hyper-real kitchenette with a white bearded man watching television inside. The response was excellent 'like watching a real time film: fascinating and awkward' we could see that  we were on to something exciting and there was hunger for more.

We have been given the wonderful opportunity to access an exquisitely dilapidated Georgian townhouse in Tottenham. This will become the site of this bold project.

As we live in Tottenham we are naturally inspired by our surroundings, and therefore will on research and experiences in the area. 


how will we achieve this?

-With help from Haringey Council we will collaborate with local non professional performers through workshops at New River Studios 

-The event will take place on the 25th, 26th and 27th of November.

-It's supported by Middlesex University and Tottenham Hotspurs FC (who own the building)

-It's part of Camden People's Theatre's Autumn programme


why are you asking me for money and where will it go?

-Good question, we are applying to Arts Council England (with what we feel is a very strong application) but crucially need crowdfunding support to diversify our income

-This money will go towards funding the design for the project, we work with an incredible curly haired designer called Naomi Kuyck Cohen. She is an integral part of the project and we meet with her very early in our process. This money will help her create her amazing designs.


what this project means for us

This project has been growing for a year and finally we have found some amazing partners and collaborators and a suggestive and inspiring location.

We are extremely excited by the possibility that this, which is been our dream for quite a while, can come true.

story:
Ή Σ Ο Υ Ν Α   Κ Α Π Ο Τ Ε   Ε Δ Ω 

[Poetry on Theater]

Για το κείμενο στα Ελληνικά, προχωρήστε παρακάτω στη σελίδα.

 

The "Once you were here" is a project that is based on the first Evi's Koroni poetry collection. The first thoughts, the first emotions, the first erotic experiences of a girl. Α monologue which consists of short poems - thoughts, which they were written at the age of 16,17, 18, 19. Simple words, simple thoughts structured so as to create a tender story.

Poetry on stage.. An actress and a dancer travel us in a sweet love story. A projecy based on the poetry collection (book) of Evi Koroni.

 

"We are a team from Greece. We are young artists with love and passion about our art but in this hard area that we live it's so difficult to show us projects. The economic crisis that bleeding our country, make us work harder."

So, we decided to creat that campaign to ask for help about that project.
 

 

ΕVI KORONI - actress, writer 

Evi Koroni was born on December 9,1989. She studied theater acting at the “Vasilis Diamantopoulos Drama School” in Thessaloniki. Since 2008, she is working as an actress on theater and as assistant director in many theatrical projects. Since 2012, she has starting to work on cinema first as screenwriter and then as director and actress.

 

C R E D I T S 

Starring  the actress Evi Koroni & the dancer Tzanos 

Directed by Christina Rapti
Written by Evi Koroni
Stage designer & Clothes by Dimitris Angelis
Edited of Illumination by Vaggelis Tzifakis

Duration: 60 min

December 17 & 18 - January 6 & 7
Alkmini Theater
Athens,Greece

 

W H A T   W E   N E E D

The complexity of the script demands a certain amount of money, which is not possible for us to spend without help. For this reason, we are kindly asking you to become members of our team and support our project.

 

H O W   T O   S P L I T   O U R   B U D G E T

Your donations will help fund the cost we spent on renting rehearsal spaces and our theater for our production.

  • Rehearsal space rental cost
  • Theater rental for performance
  • Equipments

 

H O W   Y O U   C A N   H E L P

We have started this campaign, in order to collect the necessary amount of money to produce our show. That's our principle target. 

If you cannot contribute financially though, you can still help us by sharing our campaign on social media!

         

Ε Λ Λ H Ν Ι Κ Α

Ή Σ Ο Υ Ν Α   Κ Α Π Ο Τ Ε   Ε Δ Ω 

[η θεατρική μεταφορά]

 

 

Λ Ι Γ Α   Λ Ο Γ Ι Α   Γ Ι Α   Τ Ο   Ε Ρ Γ Ο

Το «‘Ησουνα κάποτε εδώ» είναι ένας μονόλογος, ο οποίος βασίζεται στην πρώτη ποιητική συλλογή της ηθοποιού Εύης Κορώνη.

Οι πρώτες σκέψεις, τα πρώτα συναισθήματα, τα πρώτα ερωτικά βιώματα ενός κοριτσιού. Στη θεατρική σκηνή θα δούμε δύο νέους ηθοποιούς όπου μέσα από ποιήματα, μουσική και κινησιολογικά κομμάτια θα δημιουργήσουν τρυφερή ιστορία. Ζητάμε τη στήριξη σας για να μπορέσουμε να "ανεβάσουμε" αυτή την ιστορία στη θεατρική σκηνή.  

 

ΕΥΗ ΚΟΡΩΝΗ - ηθοποιός, σεναριογράφος

Η Εύη Κορώνη φοίτησε στην Ανώτερη δραματική σχολή "Βασίλης Διαμαντόπουλος" της Θεσ/νίκης. Από το 2009, έχει σταθερή παρουσία στο θέατρο ως ηθοποιός και ως βοηθός σκηνοθέτης. Το 2014, υλοποίησε τη πρώτη της ταινία μικρού μήκους, ενώ το 2016 τη δεύτερη (σενάριο - σκηνοθεσία), η οποία έχει αποσπάσει και δύο διακρίσεις. Επίσης το 2016, κυκλοφόρησε και το πρώτο της βιβλίο από τις εκδόσεις mystory.gr

 

Σ Υ Ν Τ Ε Λ Ε Σ Τ Ε Σ

Ένας μονόλογος βασισμένος στην ποιητική συλλογή της ηθοποιού Εύης Κορώνη.

 

Σκηνοθεσία : Χριστίνα Ράπτη

Συγγραφή: Εύη Κορώνη

Παίζουν: Εύη Κορώνη, Τζάνος Μάζης

Σκηνικά/Κουστούμια: Δημήτρης Αγγέλης

Χορογραφίες: Τζάνος Μάζης

 

Διάρκεια: 60 λεπτά

17 & 18 Δεκεμβρίου - 6 & 7 Ιανουαρίου
στο Θέατρο Αλκμήνη
Αθηνα, Ελλάδα

 

Σ Τ Ο Χ Ο Σ

Ο στόχος της καμπάνιας μας είναι να καταφέρουμε να μαζέψουμε τα πρώτα έξοδα για την παραγωγή του έργου μας. Η πολυπλοκότητα του σεναρίου, σε συνδυασμό με στην live μουσική απαιτεί τη δαπάνη ενός συγκεκριμένου ποσού, το οποίο δυστυχώς δεν είμαστε σε θέση να καλύψουμε χωρίς βοήθεια. Για αυτό το λόγο, σας ζητάμε να γίνετε μέλη της ομάδας μας και να στηρίξετε το εγχείρημά μας.

 

Π Ω Σ   Θ Α   Μ Ο Ι Ρ Α Σ Τ Ο Υ Ν   Τ Α   Χ Ρ Η Μ Α Τ Α

  • Ενοικίαση χώρου 
  • Εξοπλισμός
  • Πληρωμή πρώτων εξόδων (αφίσες, εισιτήρια κλπ) 

 

Π Ω Σ   Μ Π Ο Ρ Ε Ι Τ Ε   Ν Α   Β Ο Η Θ Η Σ Ε Τ Ε

·  Φτιάξαμε αυτή την καμπάνια, ώστε να συλλέξουμε το ποσό που χρειάζεται για την υλοποίηση της παράστασης μας.

·  Αν, ωστόσο, δεν υπάρχει η δυνατότητα για οικονομική συνεισφορά, μπορείτε να βοηθήσετε κοινοποιώντας την καμπάνια μας...

ΣΗΜΕΙΩΣΗ: Υπάρχει η δυνατότητα και τραπεζικής κατάθεσης για συνεισφορά στην καμπάνια. Στείλτε ένα email στο evikoroni@gmail.com για περισσότερες λεπτομέρειες.
story_txt:
Ή Σ Ο Υ Ν Α   Κ Α Π Ο Τ Ε   Ε Δ Ω [Poetry on Theater]Για το κείμενο στα Ελληνικά, προχωρήστε παρακάτω στη σελίδα. The "Once you were here" is a project that is based on the first Evi's Koroni poetry collection. The first thoughts, the first emotions, the first erotic experiences of a girl. Α monologue which consists of short poems - thoughts, which they were written at the age of 16,17, 18, 19. Simple words, simple thoughts structured so as to create a tender story.Poetry on stage.. An actress and a dancer travel us in a sweet love story. A projecy based on the poetry collection (book) of Evi Koroni. "We are a team from Greece. We are young artists with love and passion about our art but in this hard area that we live it's so difficult to show us projects. The economic crisis that bleeding our country, make us work harder."So, we decided to creat that campaign to ask for help about that project.  ΕVI KORONI - actress, writer Evi Koroni was born on December 9,1989. She studied theater acting at the “Vasilis Diamantopoulos Drama School” in Thessaloniki. Since 2008, she is working as an actress on theater and as assistant director in many theatrical projects. Since 2012, she has starting to work on cinema first as screenwriter and then as director and actress. C R E D I T S Starring  the actress Evi Koroni & the dancer Tzanos Directed by Christina RaptiWritten by Evi KoroniStage designer & Clothes by Dimitris AngelisEdited of Illumination by Vaggelis TzifakisDuration: 60 minDecember 17 & 18 - January 6 & 7Alkmini TheaterAthens,Greece W H A T   W E   N E E DThe complexity of the script demands a certain amount of money, which is not possible for us to spend without help. For this reason, we are kindly asking you to become members of our team and support our project. H O W   T O   S P L I T   O U R   B U D G E TYour donations will help fund the cost we spent on renting rehearsal spaces and our theater for our production.
Rehearsal space rental cost
Theater rental for performance
Equipments
 H O W   Y O U   C A N   H E L PWe have started this campaign, in order to collect the necessary amount of money to produce our show. That's our principle target. If you cannot contribute financially though, you can still help us by sharing our campaign on social media!         Ε Λ Λ H Ν Ι Κ ΑΉ Σ Ο Υ Ν Α   Κ Α Π Ο Τ Ε   Ε Δ Ω [η θεατρική μεταφορά]  Λ Ι Γ Α   Λ Ο Γ Ι Α   Γ Ι Α   Τ Ο   Ε Ρ Γ Ο Το «‘Ησουνα κάποτε εδώ» είναι ένας μονόλογος, ο οποίος βασίζεται στην πρώτη ποιητική συλλογή της ηθοποιού Εύης Κορώνη.Οι πρώτες σκέψεις, τα πρώτα συναισθήματα, τα πρώτα ερωτικά βιώματα ενός κοριτσιού. Στη θεατρική σκηνή θα δούμε δύο νέους ηθοποιούς όπου μέσα από ποιήματα, μουσική και κινησιολογικά κομμάτια θα δημιουργήσουν τρυφερή ιστορία. Ζητάμε τη στήριξη σας για να μπορέσουμε να "ανεβάσουμε" αυτή την ιστορία στη θεατρική σκηνή.   ΕΥΗ ΚΟΡΩΝΗ - ηθοποιός, σεναριογράφοςΗ Εύη Κορώνη φοίτησε στην Ανώτερη δραματική σχολή "Βασίλης Διαμαντόπουλος" της Θεσ/νίκης. Από το 2009, έχει σταθερή παρουσία στο θέατρο ως ηθοποιός και ως βοηθός σκηνοθέτης. Το 2014, υλοποίησε τη πρώτη της ταινία μικρού μήκους, ενώ το 2016 τη δεύτερη (σενάριο - σκηνοθεσία), η οποία έχει αποσπάσει και δύο διακρίσεις. Επίσης το 2016, κυκλοφόρησε και το πρώτο της βιβλίο από τις εκδόσεις mystory.gr Σ Υ Ν Τ Ε Λ Ε Σ Τ Ε ΣΈνας μονόλογος βασισμένος στην ποιητική συλλογή της ηθοποιού Εύης Κορώνη. Σκηνοθεσία : Χριστίνα ΡάπτηΣυγγραφή: Εύη ΚορώνηΠαίζουν: Εύη Κορώνη, Τζάνος ΜάζηςΣκηνικά/Κουστούμια: Δημήτρης ΑγγέληςΧορογραφίες: Τζάνος Μάζης Διάρκεια: 60 λεπτά17 & 18 Δεκεμβρίου - 6 & 7 Ιανουαρίουστο Θέατρο ΑλκμήνηΑθηνα, Ελλάδα Σ Τ Ο Χ Ο ΣΟ στόχος της καμπάνιας μας είναι να καταφέρουμε να μαζέψουμε τα πρώτα έξοδα για την παραγωγή του έργου μας. Η πολυπλοκότητα του σεναρίου, σε συνδυασμό με στην live μουσική απαιτεί τη δαπάνη ενός συγκεκριμένου ποσού, το οποίο δυστυχώς δεν είμαστε σε θέση να καλύψουμε χωρίς βοήθεια. Για αυτό το λόγο, σας ζητάμε να γίνετε μέλη της ομάδας μας και να στηρίξετε το εγχείρημά μας. Π Ω Σ   Θ Α   Μ Ο Ι Ρ Α Σ Τ Ο Υ Ν   Τ Α   Χ Ρ Η Μ Α Τ Α
Ενοικίαση χώρου 
Εξοπλισμός
Πληρωμή πρώτων εξόδων (αφίσες, εισιτήρια κλπ) 
 Π Ω Σ   Μ Π Ο Ρ Ε Ι Τ Ε   Ν Α   Β Ο Η Θ Η Σ Ε Τ Ε·  Φτιάξαμε αυτή την καμπάνια, ώστε να συλλέξουμε το ποσό που χρειάζεται για την υλοποίηση της παράστασης μας.·  Αν, ωστόσο, δεν υπάρχει η δυνατότητα για οικονομική συνεισφορά, μπορείτε να βοηθήσετε κοινοποιώντας την καμπάνια μας...ΣΗΜΕΙΩΣΗ: Υπάρχει η δυνατότητα και τραπεζικής κατάθεσης για συνεισφορά στην καμπάνια. Στείλτε ένα email στο evikoroni@gmail.com για περισσότερες λεπτομέρειες.

story:
What is TILTYARD?

Tiltyard is a new Brooklyn-based theater company co-founded by Sara Holdren, Rachel Carpman, and Josephine Stewart. We are devoted to passionate physical storytelling, vibrant new interpretations of old tales, and ensemble-driven new work. We are artists and friends striving to tell thrilling, necessary stories in a spirit of serious play. Learn more here!

What is MIDSUMMER?

Midnight. The forest. Can a chance encounter between a wily fairy and a ragtag troupe of would-be actors bring the world back from the brink of destruction?

MIDSUMMER is a radical reworking of William Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, created by Rachel Carpman and Sara Holdren. At once familiar and alien, joyful and vicious, MIDSUMMER explores the havoc we foolish mortals wreak on the world around us and revels in the redemptive power of imagination. This topsy-turvy new spin on the bard's most magical comedy incorporates text from every play in Shakespeare's canon to create a playful, aware, contemporary tale for skeptics, romantics, and those of us who still, somehow, believe in magic.

MIDSUMMER will perform October 13-16, 2016 at the American Theatre of Actors (314 W. 54th St, NY/NY) as part of the 2016 Araca Project. Get your tickets today!

What do we NEED?

For our inaugural production of MIDSUMMER, we have a fundraising goal of $12,000. Through the generosity of the Araca Project and many wonderful supporters, we have already raised half of that target amount. And now we need you to help get us across the finish line!

﻿For us, the real magic of theater is the support that lifts ideas out of our minds and sketchbooks and renders them vivid and tangible.Your generosity puts actors in the rehearsal room, designers in their workshops, and our show on the stage. Any amount you give will help us build the wondrous world we want to show you. And to see where your dollars are going when you donate to Tiltyard, take a look at this handy pie-chart:

Above all else, we are committed to compensating the amazing artists who work with us. We are also dedicated to building a truly remarkable scenic and sonic experience for our audiences. With $12,000, we will be able to achieve these goals, bring MIDSUMMER to magical life, and begin investing in the future of Tiltyard.   

Why THIS campaign?

We know. There are a thousand exciting crowd-funding campaigns out there for you to choose from. We're so glad you're here learning about ours! When you contribute to Tiltyard, you're doing more than funding a one-time project — you are helping our company establish itself. Tiltyard is a place for experimentation, collaboration, and the joyful crashing together of ideas... and we're just getting started. We've got big things planned for Tiltyard, and we want YOU to be a part of them — whether as a supporter, an audience member, an artist, or a friend. We can't wait to share our dreams with you. 

Are there OTHER ways I can contribute?

Absolutely! We're always on the hunt for...

  • Space (for Rehearsals, Workshops, Performances)
  • Materials (wood, paper, recycled scenic elements...)
  • Resources for things like Printing, Concessions, Administrative Support
  • Production Volunteers (ushers, board operators, his-girl/guy-Fridays...)

If you have connections with any of the above and would like to talk to us about a trade or in-kind donation, we'd love to hear from you! We love finding creative ways to expand the community that helps us Make the Work.

Anything ELSE?

That's it! THANK YOU for helping us to create MIDSUMMER and to launch TILTYARD.

story: Fannytasticals comprises of six Brighton based ladies, spanning 20 years of life experience. Brought together by previous theatre experiences, we have devised an entire cabaret style performance with a distinctly feminine twist. Fear not; we are not all raging lesbians, hairy feminists or man-haters. None of us actually hate men, in fact some of us even live with them. With live music, short sketches and a healthy dollop of satire, the six of us bring you a silly, saucy, lewd, rude and crude fanciful feast of femininity and gendered topics, talking about the things that you just don't hear people speak about, especially women. Fannytasticals provides an essential gendered voice with the perfect amount of humour to really get under the skin and make an impression. We would love for more people to hear and experience our comedic yet profound performance, commenting on life, love and the universe, and are therefore seeking any pledges and donations you are willing to contribute to take us to the Brighton Fringe and, ultimately, to Edinburgh. Find news of our upcoming shows with Fannytasticals on Facebook and Twitter at @Fanny_tasticals and come and see what we're all about! Thank you.

story:
Where your contribution will be used:

Your contributions will go to help us bring Southern Railroad's first full scale production to San Francisco with the world premiere of TAKEN. This is our largest production to date and we hope you'll be a part of laying the tracks for this new journey.  We're proud to announce our collaboration with Entropy Productions and 3Girls Theatre on TAKEN.  

“We found this family drama to be a compelling exploration of loss and the way we react when the things we love are taken from us." 

-Lexi Diamond, Berkeley Repertory Theatre Literary Manager 

Thanks to our collaboration with our producing partner 3Girls Theatre, your contributions are now tax-deductible!!!

We've had the pleasure of working with some of the best theater companies, theatre makers and artists the Bay Area has to offer. In 2013, we were invited to New York City for Altruistic Theatre Company's Bare Knuckle Theatre Fest.  We've been working to build creative alliances with other companies including the immersion experience theatre producers, Incentives to Intrige. We collaborate with writers, directors and producers from Entropy Productions, Wily West Productions, Pacifica Table Readers, Pear Avenue Theater, PianoFight Productions and 3Girls Theatre.  In 2014, we were invited to participate in the Eugene O'Neill Foundation's Eugene O' Neill Festival where we presented A RAZING IN MISSOURI, written and directed by Susan Jackson.  In 2015 we were invited back to NYC for Midtown's Mid-Winter Theatre Festival. We made our critically acclaimed Washington, DC debut in July 2016 with DEATH BE NOT LOUD! earning rave reviews from The Washington Post:  

“Under the direction of Wesley Cayabyab, the two recognizable and credible characters are comfortable in their own skin.”

-Roger Catlin, The Washington Post

& DC Metro Theatre Arts:

“Susan Jackson’s new play DEATH BE NOT LOUD – Produced by the Southern Railroad Theatre Company and billed as a “contemporary Southern comedy” – is a sweet reflection on love and loss, featuring two gifted actors...”

-Ravelle Brickman, DC Metro Theatre Arts

 

Now we're back home in San Francisco and we've partnered with San Francisco Entropy Productions and 3Girls Theatre Company to bring the world premiere production of Susan Jackson's new drama TAKEN.  

 

 

Under the direction of Wesley Cayabyab.  TAKEN will feature Southern Railroad Co-Producers, Diana Brown and Susan Jackson, Bay Area actor, Brian Levi, San Francisco Actor and Founder/Producer of Theater Madcap, Eric Reid, Amitis Rossoukh & Nathan Tucker.  We're thrilled to have Brian, Eric, Amitis and Nathan making their Southern Railroad Theatre Company debuts.

TAKEN

By Susan Jackson

Directed by Wesley Cayabyab

Featuring: Diana Brown and Susan Jackson, Brian Levi, Eric Reid, Amitis Rossoukh & Nathan Tucker

In TAKEN, Corrie travels to San Francisco to see if she can identify the body of a young man evicted from his home. Is it her brother? Or just a stranger? Who is responsible for this life that was taken?

TAKEN will run Friday and Saturdays at 8 PM, October 21 – November 18, 2016

 Where your contribution will be used:

OUR BIGGEST SHOW EVER!

We'll use your contributions to prepare the production for our 4 week San Francisco run of TAKEN.

Our Goal of $11,000 will go to pay for rental of the Royce Gallery performance space, Set design and construction, lights and sound production, insurance, production staff and to compensate our director and collaborators.  And go to pay for advertising to market our production and to document the project.

 

In thanks for your support:

You'll receive inside access to the production process through special posts and video updates.Invitations to closed rehearsals.  At certain levels, contributors will enjoy credit in the program and on our website for TAKEN, VIP tickets to TAKEN by Susan Jackson.  A Southern "Comfort Food Feast" with the cast of DEATH BE NOT LOUD and TAKEN. All of you will receive our sincere gratitude!

As an independent producing company, we are used finding ways to self fund. Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to make this production possible. Your support and contributions also ensure the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.

 

The Impact

Your contributions will go to help us bring Southern Railroad's first full scale production. This is the largest production we have undertaken and we hope you'll be a part of laying the tracks for this new journey.

This opportunity to bring this San Francisco based play to life in our home city will expand our producing knowledge and experience.  We are thrilled to forge these new creative partnerships as we continue to increase our artistic community in the San Francisco Bay Area and across the nation.

As always a portion of our proceeds will go in support of a charity.  In the past, we've supported Tornado Relief in Joplin, MO., Puppy Rescue Mission, SF Suicide Prevention and Rocket Dog Rescue.  

Southern Railroad Theatre Company has been presenting award winning, critically acclaimed theatre in the Bay Area and beyond since 2008. 

 

Risks & Challenges

 

Southern Railroad's first full scale production. This is the largest production with the largest budget we have undertaken.  We're excited to face the challenge of bringing this show to life with our producing partners.  Co-producers, Brown and Jackson have presented at New York City, Washington, DC and San Francisco theatre festivals as well as producing smaller scale runs of productions locally. They will rely on what they've learned from those experiences and the considerable experience of Entropy Productions and 3Girls Theatre Company.

Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to bring this world premiere production to San Francisco with this talented ensemble of performers and this creative team.  And your support ensures the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially:

Your good wishes, sharing our story on social media are just as valuable and appreciated!

Indiegogo share tools are a great way to do just that!

We sure thank you for your support!

Diana Brown and Susan Jackson, Co-Producers, Southern Railroad Theatre Company

Wesley Cayabyab, Entropy Productions, Co-Producer

3Girls Theatre Company, Co-Producer

This is the largest production with the largest budget we have undertaken.  We're excited to face the challenge of bringing this show to life with our producing partners.  Co-producers, Brown and Jackson have presented at New York City, Washington, DC and San Francisco theatre festivals as well as producing smaller scale runs of productions locally. They will rely on what they've learned from those experiences and the considerable experience of Entropy Productions and 3Girls Theatre Company.Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to bring this world premiere production to San Francisco with this talented ensemble of performers and this creative team.  And your support ensures the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company. Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that not everyone can contribute financially:Your good wishes, sharing our story on social media are just as valuable and appreciated!Indiegogo share tools are a great way to do just that!We sure thank you for your support!Diana Brown and Susan Jackson, Co-Producers, Southern Railroad Theatre CompanyWesley Cayabyab, Entropy Productions, Co-Producer3Girls Theatre Company, Co-Producer

story:
I am a first time playwright. I first heard about sex trafficking 10 years ago and I immediately knew I wanted to write about it. I guess you can say then that Dara is 10 years old, which is sometimes the case for the victims. Our Dara ranges in age from 14 to 17 throughout the play.

We are already funded for things like lights, sound, building rental, etc. These funds needed are strictly to help pay the cast and crew for the many, many hours they put into this project.
 
20% of our ticket sales are going to Love146, an organization committed to fighting child sex trafficking.
 
Thank you for considering and if you can't donate, please share this page.

story:
About This DogStar Theater Co. Production

Hi Wonders!

This past January, it was time; time to launch my dream of creating our own theater company!

Our first production took place last April and was ever so well received, and now we are ready to dive into our second production of the year with the comedy "The Foreigner" written by Larry Shue. This timely themed story brings together a unique bunch of characters in the middle of rural Georgia.  The story, although a comedy, dances around the themes of racism, stereotype, prejudice, and the human heart. This is a story that needs to be told - NOW.

When I choose a play, I look for a story that will bring a community together. I look for characters and themes that will inspire conversation after the show. I want people to unite in the experience of watching a play that I direct. After the show, I want each member of the audience to walk out with a gem in their heart, a sparkle in their eye and a warmer sense of engagement with their fellow man, woman and greater world around them.

 

Where Your Support Goes

Your donation will go DIRECTLY towards:

  • our fabulous actors 
  • our phenomenal stage manager
  • rehearsal space costs
  • stage rental, lights, set, costumes and props costs
  • 5% pf all profits will go to the Anti-Defamation League

The Impact

We are in the process of becoming a non-profit. Our aim is to share stories that inspire and unite. Your donation will go directly to bringing this play and the actors who play the characters to life! Your donation will play a part in making every audience member smile, in bringing a laugh to their belly and warmth into their heart. Your donation is, essentially, an investment in happiness, community, and human goodness.

Challenges

Creative artists and organizations are struggling more than ever, and this is exactly the reason to do MORE art and CREATE more together! As a community, we have all the resources, energy, wisdom and experience we need; sometimes we forget to turn towards one another and ask for help. But boy, it always feels good to be asked, and it always feels good to give.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you'd like to be involved with supporting DogStar in other ways, here are a few additional opportunities:

  • provide baked goods for intermission
  • help us to find costumes and props 
  • help us build the set
  • take photos of our rehearsals and production
  • ...help to spread the word about our show and this campaign!

Above and beyond it all: WE APPRECIATE YOU so much. YOU are the community we bring stories to life for. YOU. Yes. YOU. without you - there would be no audience, no one to share our creation with! So, THANK YOU in abundance.

story:
Imagine 6 movement art pieces performed one after another around independently standing DOOR. Including projections, interaction with audience and a short movie.

Isn’t it cool?

My name is Nadya, I am a moving artist and beginning curator. I am obsessed with the idea of a DOOR as a vehicle for art.

In 2016 I performed my first multimedia exploration of this obsession and I’ve realized the infinite potential that it has for moving artists.

I became curious: what will others create?

I made an application call for works with the idea of a DOOR as a main character and honestly, I was blown away by concepts that I’ve received: well-thought, compelling, meaningful,  touching and fascinating. Now we have 6 different artists (+ myself). 

Through their works artists will reach out to viewers about borders that society builds, immigration issues, conservatism and flexibility, conflict with one’s self and simple beauty of common objects.

Audiences will get the chance to experience several art mediums: dance theater, contemporary dance, short film, Bharatanatyam, interactive performance art & video installation - all in one night (2 actually).  

Our great team consists of talented performers, choreographers and videographer:
1. Rozina Shiraz Gilani (dance + video installation)
2. Bjørn Venø (interactive performance)
3. Professional Bodies (dance)
4. Jennifer Tarrazi-Scully (short film)
5. Britt Ford (dance)
6. Rourou Ye (short film)
7. and my humble self  (dance + video installation)

You can find out more about each artist here: https://nadyazeitlin.wixsite.com/doorscandance

What We Need

A lot of things changed since I’ve started this project. Current situation will take most part (if not all) from proceeds and there’s not much left for the artists. 

It’s not cool. Artists are the main engines for this show! It takes time and energy to create a dance work, and of course, money: to pay dancers and studio rent at least. Artists need decent honorariums!  

But to make a show happen we need to “kill bills” as well.

- Rental of the gallery for 2 performance nights and 2 rehearsals; 
- The DOOR in a frame, including transportation;
- Stage manager, reliable and experience person for 4 nights (2 rehearsals, 2 performances);
plus the platform fees 

So I’m asking for your help. We need to cover these expenses so we can split proceeds from the show between artists. 

Every dollar means your support, and your support means a Universe for us! 

& What You Get

The day of the show I will post names of all of our contributors to the Facebook event page. And once a day I will add names of current day's backers on our website. 

I have a unique collection of dance movies and videos that will give you inspiration, aesthetic pleasure, “Oh wows!” and  probably even goosebumps. And I will be happy to share them with you! I believe you haven't heard about these artists (if you did, it will be a good reminder for you)
I will send 2 links twice a week starting in the end of September. You will receive amount accordingly to your contribution. 

Most of the backers will receive a Door postcard, signed by all of the artists. It should definitely become your lucky charm. I will send it out in the end of September. 

Another cool perk is an authentic decorative key. Please note, that this picture is just an example of what you will receive. I will choose shape and color for you, listening to my intuition. 

$70 contributors ONLY will get 10 minutes photoshoot with the door before the event. Please note that you will need to bring your own camera and photographer (or model), come at least 1 hr before the show and the set up might be dark. In the case you cannot do it before the event, we may arrange something that will work for you. $100 contributors can borrow the door for 1 day (transportation to your location and back on your side please). 

Also, perks include a Creative Movement class and borrowing of our DOOR (that you're helping to build with your generous contribution) for the whole week. Storage for this period, transportation to location and back is on your side. This option is available for metro Atlanta residents though. But I have a special perk for non-Atlanta $150 contributors. 

The Impact

Supporting this show you will light some new stars and help me to  c o n n e c t very important dots: artists and audiences. 

1) It’s not easy to perform in big ATL city, but artists need to share their works, it’s our essential need! This intimate c o n n e c t i o n with viewer is our way  to  h e a l people and contribute to all the good stuff on our planet. 

2) Another important thing for me is  to  c o n n e c t audiences. We have an eclectic team of emerging and established artists with their own fans. And they will gather in one space to experience their favs as well as unfamiliar art languages of other artists, which will enrich their art and life experience. 

And you (yes, You!) will become the starter for our battery. And we promise to keep the engine going and bring more and more light and healing energy to people's hearts. Art indeed heals.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute $$? Please help us spread the word to those who can! Just press “share” button! Our deepest gratitude, virtual hugs (or high fives, or simply an eye wink :)) fly to you to bring something good to your day!

Our deepest gratitude, virtual hugs (or high fives, or simply an eye wink :)) fly to you to bring something good to your day!

story:
Who We Are & What We Do

  • Peter Zachari and Joey Mirabile have been producing independent theater in New York City since 2011 starting with their production of Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow at the New York International Fringe Festival. The show was selected as part of the Encore Series and remounted at The Players Theater. The show returned yet again at Theater for the New City in 2014. 
  • We have found the most wonderful artistic home at Theater for the New City. In the past five years we have presented a bevy of original shows: Fat Asses: The Musical, Under the Knife: A Farce, One Love, a freshly reimagined production of Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow and the premiere of Anne Marilyn Lucas' From Silence.

  • Peter Zachari and his writing partner Damon Maida wrote Fat Asses: The Musical. We had a two week run in 2011 and played to sold out audience. The show was a hit. We have the opportunity to bring this show with a refreshed score back in 2018 at Theater for the New City. But we need help to make this happen. 

How You Can Make a Difference

We got into New York Musical Festival...and didn't have the funds to participate.

We got into New York Fringe Festival...and didn't have the funds to participate.

The world wants this show. And we want to make it happen! And we will if you help us. We need to raise $25,000. That funding goes for:

  • Payment for Equity actors, director, musical director, musicians stage managers, set designer, costume designer, lighting designer and sound engineers 
  • Sets, props, costumes, projections, video equipment
  • Publicity and Marketing, printed materials, mailings, ads, email blasts

The Impact

  • The world needs this show. It's time that all shapes and sizes are fairly represented in the world and this show blasts that message. But it's not just about bigger people. It's about ALL shapes and sizes. You will be contributing to an original piece that send a positive message to the world. And it's fun. It's funny. And it's poignant. I think you would be proud to say you were a part of this production team.
  • Because of people like you we HAVE been producing original works. Six original Peter Zachari plays and musicals have been produced in New York City from the generosity of friends, family and participants of crowdfunding efforts.
  • Not only does the audiences of New York City get to see the show but tens of New York artists, actors, designers and staff get to participate in this work of passion and contribute to the landscape of the New York City theater scene.

Let's Do This!

We can't let another opportunity like this slip by. It's important that we present shows that challenge the status quo and represent those voices who aren't being heard. Without your help, we could be at risk of not presenting this show next year. And that would be a shame!

Take a listen:

Here is the song, "Loving You Is A Dying Art" from the FAT ASSES: THE MUSICAL, sung by Kelly Teal Goyette from the original run. When Margaux discovers her husband has cut her off without a cent she discovers she still has mixed feeling for him. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please help us spread the word about our show. Tell everyone about the Fat Asses!
  • Join our Facebook group: www.facebook.com/fatassesthemusical
  • Join us on Twitter: www.twitter.com/fatassesmusical

So what are you waiting for? Join us!

story:
THE IDEA

Hey, we're Lisa and Jeff, we're producing a musical, and we need your help.

This is not just any musical - it’s our favorite in the whole wide world.  It's the kind of show we dreamed of doing even while performing at such acclaimed venues as the Vancouver, Washington Sausage Festival and an 80's themed metal wedding.

The musical is “The Last Five Years”, by Jason Robert Brown.  Now if you're a drama nerd you are probably already obsessed with this award winning show, but if you are of the other 98.6% of the world population you’ve never heard of it. It's beautiful, funny, original, brutally honest and not nearly enough people have seen it.  We're working with a non-profit theater company to change that.

 

HOW TO MAKE IT HAPPEN

The first step is to put on the show in Los Angeles.  This limited run will serve as our “pilot episode” for other theaters and venues around the country. If they like what they see in L.A., we’ll be able to take this thing on the road (the production is “pack and play” with a cast of two that can travel easily to anywhere looking for good theater). 

We’ve already assembled our creative team, reserved the rights to the show and booked The Studio Theater at Sacred Fools in Hollywood for performances from November 11 – November 18, 2017.  Paying for the show rights, theater, rehearsal space, sets, costumes, marketing materials, and tech crew is where you all come in.

From nose to tail, top to bottom, soup to nuts - and whatever other metaphor you can come up with - putting on this production for four nights is going to cost us the price of a used 2009 Chevy Cobalt, aka $7,000.

 

WHAT YOU GET

The fantastic news for you is that helping us pay for the show is TAX DEDUCTIBLE. Our production company, Lucid By Proxy is a Not for Profit organization, so 100% of your donation will go directly to production expenses.

(Lucid by proxy Theater Group (tax ID #20-1086926) dedicated to the advancement of community arts and operates as a non-profit, non-stock educational organization within the meaning of Section 501 (c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the regulations thereunder)

PERKS

Honestly, no donation is too small and if you are able to contribute, we offer some great incentives! We have everything from public shout outs to tickets to the show, recordings from the cast, and personalized performances. Just check out the column to the right and claim your goodies. 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Whether or not you can give us some money, we'd love a share on social media to help spread the word.

 

WHO WE ARE

Shannon Nelson (Director)

 

Shannon is an actor, director based in Los Angeles. Shannon and 6 of her closest friends created the non-profit Lucid by Proxy Theatre Group in 2000 and with them she has produced and performed in over 15 productions focusing on primarily original, new, American plays with a slight detour with a critically acclaimed production of Into The Woods set in a warehouse/found space in downtown LA. Lucid by Proxy's productions have received much acclaim including having Sam French publish Asymmetry (written by Rock Robinson) and winning multiple awards including most recently a StageScene LA Scenie Award for Shannon as Best Performance Female Actress-Drama for playing Hedda Gabler in the modern LbP adaptation, Save Me. You may recognize her from her break out role as Tess Weinhous in the cult comedy classic Drop Dead Gorgeous or from numerous TV (West Wing, ER, The Practice), web (Cannabis Moms Club, Pairings) and commercial appearances. Shannon has performed theatrically all over LA and was nominated for an LA Weekly Award (Best Female Comedy Performance) and won a StageSceneLA Scenie Award (Best Performance Female Actress-Comedy) for her performance in Absolutely Filthy.   www.ShannonNelson.com 

 

Jeff Bratz (Jamie/Sound Designer)

 

Jeff is a theatre veteran transplanted in LA. His recent Off-Broadway credits include, Game of Thrones: The Rock Musical (Robb Stark) and Marilyn & Sinatra (Frank Sinatra). Regional credits include, The Tempest (Ariel), Cabaret (Emcee), and The 39 Steps. He has appeared as a Top-15 contestant on NBC’s America’s Got Talent and currently performs with rock band RaDIUM and vocal jazz group LA Transfer. www.jeffbratz.com

 

Lisa Ferris (Cathy/Producer)

 

Lisa holds a Bachelor of Music in musical theater from Catholic University and a Master of Fine Arts in acting from The University of Nevada Las Vegas. Film Credits include, Pipe Dream: The Unlikely Success of Carol Burnett (Carol). Regional theater credits include, The Utah Shakespeare Festival: Twelfth Night (Olivia) , The Comedy Of Errors (Adriana), The Taming Of The Shrew (Bianca), Fiddler On The Roof (Hodel), and The Secret Garden (Rose). Sacramento Music Circus: Funny Girl (Emma), Oliver! (Charlotte), and Camelot (Dance Ensemble). California Music Theatre Cosmo Cabaret: A Grand Night For Singing (Comic Ingénue). Nevada Conservatory Theater: Company (Amy), and The Little Dog Laughed (Ellen). www.yogawithferris.com

 

Sacred Fools at the Broadwater (Venue)

1076 Lillian Way, Los Angeles, CA 90038

Performances: 

Nov. 11th, 17th, and 18th @ 8pm

Nov. 12th @ 7pm

To purchase tickets click: www.lastfive.brownpapertickets.com

 

Thank you!

HOW TO MAKE IT HAPPEN 
The first step is to put on the show in Los Angeles.  This limited run will serve as our “pilot episode” for other theaters and venues around the country. If they like what they see in L.A., we’ll be able to take this thing on the road (the production is “pack and play” with a cast of two that can travel easily to anywhere looking for good theater). 
We’ve already assembled our creative team, reserved the rights to the show and booked The Studio Theater at Sacred Fools in Hollywood for performances from November 11 – November 18, 2017.  Paying for the show rights, theater, rehearsal space, sets, costumes, marketing materials, and tech crew is where you all come in.
From nose to tail, top to bottom, soup to nuts - and whatever other metaphor you can come up with - putting on this production for four nights is going to cost us the price of a used 2009 Chevy Cobalt, aka $7,000.

 
WHAT YOU GET
The fantastic news for you is that helping us pay for the show is TAX DEDUCTIBLE. Our production company, Lucid By Proxy is a Not for Profit organization, so 100% of your donation will go directly to production expenses.
(Lucid by proxy Theater Group (tax ID #20-1086926) dedicated to the advancement of community arts and operates as a non-profit, non-stock educational organization within the meaning of Section 501 (c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the regulations thereunder)
PERKS
Honestly, no donation is too small and if you are able to contribute, we offer some great incentives! We have everything from public shout outs to tickets to the show, recordings from the cast, and personalized performances. Just check out the column to the right and claim your goodies. 
 
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Whether or not you can give us some money, we'd love a share on social media to help spread the word.
 
WHO WE ARE
Shannon Nelson (Director)

 
Shannon is an actor, director based in Los Angeles. Shannon and 6 of her closest friends created the non-profit Lucid by Proxy Theatre Group in 2000 and with them she has produced and performed in over 15 productions focusing on primarily original, new, American plays with a slight detour with a critically acclaimed production of Into The Woods set in a warehouse/found space in downtown LA. Lucid by Proxy's productions have received much acclaim including having Sam French publish Asymmetry (written by Rock Robinson) and winning multiple awards including most recently a StageScene LA Scenie Award for Shannon as Best Performance Female Actress-Drama for playing Hedda Gabler in the modern LbP adaptation, Save Me. You may recognize her from her break out role as Tess Weinhous in the cult comedy classic Drop Dead Gorgeous or from numerous TV (West Wing, ER, The Practice), web (Cannabis Moms Club, Pairings) and commercial appearances. Shannon has performed theatrically all over LA and was nominated for an LA Weekly Award (Best Female Comedy Performance) and won a StageSceneLA Scenie Award (Best Performance Female Actress-Comedy) for her performance in Absolutely Filthy.   www.ShannonNelson.com 
 
Jeff Bratz (Jamie/Sound Designer)

 
Jeff is a theatre veteran transplanted in LA. His recent Off-Broadway credits include, Game of Thrones: The Rock Musical (Robb Stark) and Marilyn & Sinatra (Frank Sinatra). Regional credits include, The Tempest (Ariel), Cabaret (Emcee), and The 39 Steps. He has appeared as a Top-15 contestant on NBC’s America’s Got Talent and currently performs with rock band RaDIUM and vocal jazz group LA Transfer. www.jeffbratz.com
 
Lisa Ferris (Cathy/Producer)

 
Lisa holds a Bachelor of Music in musical theater from Catholic University and a Master of Fine Arts in acting from The University of Nevada Las Vegas. Film Credits include, Pipe Dream: The Unlikely Success of Carol Burnett (Carol). Regional theater credits include, The Utah Shakespeare Festival: Twelfth Night (Olivia) , The Comedy Of Errors (Adriana), The Taming Of The Shrew (Bianca), Fiddler On The Roof (Hodel), and The Secret Garden (Rose). Sacramento Music Circus: Funny Girl (Emma), Oliver! (Charlotte), and Camelot (Dance Ensemble). California Music Theatre Cosmo Cabaret: A Grand Night For Singing (Comic Ingénue). Nevada Conservatory Theater: Company (Amy), and The Little Dog Laughed (Ellen). www.yogawithferris.com
 
Sacred Fools at the Broadwater (Venue)

1076 Lillian Way, Los Angeles, CA 90038
Performances: 
Nov. 11th, 17th, and 18th @ 8pm
Nov. 12th @ 7pm
To purchase tickets click: www.lastfive.brownpapertickets.com
 
Thank you!

story:
KITH

Our Body is a Road Map. Hear Our Story.

“I'm interested in our bodies as cargo ships of memory, of love and loss, trauma, joy, poetry, comedy and drama. I wish to create language out of bodies and probe the hidden discourse in our physicality to understand our human story. ” - Keila Cordova, artistic statement

 

WHAT

KITH is a new project and will premiere September 14, 15 and 16, 2017 at the Conwell Dance Theatre for the Philadelphia Fringe Festival for five performances.

KITH is the story of our connections to each other, our relationships. Kith or kin, is an old idiom   originally referring to one's country and family. It evolved to mean friends and family. As we develop the work, we're having conversations in our community to examine personal connections to develop and bring those explorations into the performance space, with dance, music and text and song as well.

Interested in joining the conversation? Take our short survey here.

 

WHEN 

September 14 (8pm), 15 (730pm), 16 (1130am, 330pm & 730pm)

Conwell Dance Theater - 1801 N Broad St, Philadelphia, PA 19122

 

WHO

Choreography & Direction: Keila Cordova

Keila Cordova (Choreographer/Director) grew up writing stories and watching her mother dance in Panama before migrating to California, where she was both a gymnast and a cheerleader. Keila is a choreographer, performer and writer whose works have been performed in Philadelphia; in NYC at Judson Church and at numerous festivals; in Pittsburgh at the newMoves Contemporary Dance Festival (KellyStrayhorn), and at festivals in San Diego, CA; Chicago, IL; Toronto, Canada. Keila holds a BA from UC Berkeley (Rhetoric) and an MFA from the New School for Social Research (Creative Writing). She was a 2016 NEA panelist for Dance, a 2014 & 2016 American delegate at Tanzmesse (Duesseldorf) with American Dance Abroad. She's received funding awards from the Leeway and Puffin Foundations; artistic support with Funds for New Work awards (Harlem Stage), a commission (Greenwall Foundation) and various residencies. As artistic director of 3 Pony Show, she creates dance performance works that ride the boundaries between dance and theatre.

 

Dancers/Performers

Amelia Rose Estrada received an honors B.A. in Dance and Classical Studies from Swarthmore College in May 2017.  As a dance major she completed both the dance studies and choreography concentrations. While at school she had the privilege of studying under Sharon Friedler, Gregory King, Rebecca Malcolmb-Naib, Chandra Moss-Thorne, Kim Arrow, Idan Porges, and others. During her senior year of college she started a year long dance program for children from Chester, PA in collaboration with the Chester Children's Chorus as part of her thesis on arts education and social justice. Outside of dancing with 3 Pony Show/keila cordova dances in this production, she is currently dancing with Leilani Chirino and teaches with  Dance eXchange, a program run by BalletX that is bringing movement classes into the Philly public schools.


Camille Gamble is a young artist full of passion for the arts in Philly. A Temple University graduate, she has a BFA in dance performance and choreography with a minor in psychology. She is currently working at the Performance Garage as technical director and continues to dance and choreograph in the community. other interests include teaching, sports, arts and crafts, exploring the world and enjoying life. She is interested in the physical and therapeutic benefits. movement has for people, including disabled persons.

 

Alison Liney is originally from Drexel Hill, Pennsylvania, Alison has been dancing professionally in Philadelphia since her graduation from Temple University in 2013. While earning her BFA in dance and choreography, she was lucky enough to train with incredible teachers and artists such as Merian Soto, Kun-Yang Lin, Ellie Goudie-Averill, Jillian Harris, Beau Hancock, Tiffany Mills, and Kyle Abraham among many others. Post graduation, she became a member of Enchantment Theatre Company, and has performed in and choreographed numerous shows. Most recently she appeared in the 2015-2016 national tour of Peter Rabbit Tales as the mischievous rabbit himself. Alison is looking forward to sharing the stage with these special new friends and dancers.

 

Originally from China, Olivia Naegele moved to Massachusetts when she was five, and started dancing at a young age. She always loved to move and express herself through her body. In elementary school, Naegele trained in figure skating. In high school she fell in love with dance again, which became the catalyst for her wanting to become a professional dancer.  She attended The University of the Arts in Philadelphia, where she received a BFA in Dance, while minoring in Art Therapy. Now she is a freelancing dancer in Philadelphia, dancing with various wonderful groups such as 3 Pony Show/keila cordova dances.  

 

Karmen Nicole is originally from Columbus, OH and an alum from University of the Arts.  She began dancing at the age of 12 at Balletmet Columbus and is a graduate of their pre-professional program. Prior to her recent arrival back to Philadelphia she taught classes for Danceworks Performing Arts Center that ranged from ballet to hip-hop, as well as a coach for their jazz and lyrical dance team. In addition to that, she has also taught and danced professional ballroom dance for Fred Astaire Franchise Dance Studios. In Philly she’s performed with numerous groups, including Contempra Dance Theatre, and has taught throughout Philly and surrounding suburbs with her company, Dance2go/Pop n’ Wedlock. This is Karmen’s fourth performance with 3 Pony Show/keila cordova dances, the first performance since her debut that she is not adjusting with or from child baring; in last year's performance she had just gave birth to Julian - now 15 months old, and the performance before that in 2013, she was eight months pregnant with her first child, Sebastian - now almost 4 years old. 

 
Sarah Warren, originally from Maryland, currently resides in Philadelphia, PA  where she received her BFA in Dance Performance & Choreography from Temple University. Since graduation, Sarah has performed work for 3 Pony Show keila cordova dances, The InterACTion Project and many other freelance artists in the Philadelphia area. Sarah formerly was an apprentice with NYC based company Kaleidoscope Dance Theatre and currently dances for ContempraDance Theatre, Putty Dance Project, and Nickerson-Rossi Dance (East). Sarah is looking forward to another awesome Fringe show with Keila Cordova Dances!!
 

Set & Production Design: Andrew Thompson

Andrew Thompson (Scenic Design/ Production Manager) is the Technical Director for Upper Darby Performing Art Center. During his 13 seasons as technical director for Walnut Street Theatre's Studio 3, he designed for theater and dance over the past 15 years. WSTST3 scenic designs favorites - Moon of the Misbegotten/ tour, Becoming Dr. Ruth, Elliot: A Soldier's Fugue, Glass Menagerie/tour, Proof/tour, Around the World in 80 Days/tour, The Rise and Fall of Little Voice, WST Mainstage:  And Then There Were None. WST Kids: Shrek JR, Diary of Fly, Spider, Worm, How I Became a Pirate, Other credits: Spoleto Festival USA (TD/ATD) 20 seasons,  954 Dance Movement Collective/ 3 pony show/keila cordova dances  (technical supervisor/ scenic design) Agnes Falling, Volcano My love, As Pretty Does,  Scenic Design/ Consulting for Playhouse Productions Becoming Dr. Ruth, Waist Watchers the Musical!(National Tour), Lincoln Center Out Of Doors Festival (crew chief 7 seasons), Trisha Brown Dance Company international tour (production carpenter 3 years). 

 

Composer: Pax Ressler

Pax Ressler (Composer) is a genderqueer composer, designer, director, and performer in Philadelphia. In addition to Keila Cordova's "Kith" and "Linear Default", Pax has composed and arranged for theatre companies and choral organizations, including the Arden Theatre's Cabaret Series, Ted & Co. Theaterworks, Chestnut Street Singers and more. In recent months, they assistant directed The Light Princess at the Arden, performed in 11th Hour's Road Show and Orbiter 3's Peaceable Kingdom, music directed for the Bearded Ladies Cabaret and sound designed Hero School at Theatre Horizon. Pax is the Director of Music at Tabernacle United Church in West Philadelphia.  https://tailormadecompositions.wordpress.com/

 

Lighting Design: Christine Causer

Christine's past work includes assisting and design work at The Prince Music Theatre for productions that included West Side Story, several cabaret events, and Anyone Can Whistle. Christine has a BFA from Virginia Commonwealth University and she teaches design and technical theater to future production artists at a  high school in New Jersey.  She created lighting designs for 3PS/KCD's productions of Linear Default (2016) and As Pretty Does (2013).

 

HOW

Community Conversations: Were talking to people about kinship, and carrying those conversations forward into our rehearsal process.

Surveys: We're asking everyone to talk about kinship and asking what this bond represents to each of us to feed our own conversation and development. If you're interested in joining the conversation and sharing your story, take our survey here.

 

Additional resource materials for the project include:

 

Beasts of No Nation by Uzodinma Iweala -  A civil war rages and, Agu, a school-aged boy is recruited into a unit of guerrilla fighters. Haunted by his father’s own death at the hands of militants, which he fled just before witnessing, Agu is vulnerable to the dangerous yet paternal nature of his new commander. (Book chosen to study the extreme results of a family destroyed, and the draw to recreate it even under the most dire circumstances.)

Lucky Child by Loung Ung - A close knit family torn apart by the ravages of the Khmer Rhouge in Cambodia, the youngest daughter is chosen to come to America for a new life with her brother and his wife, leaving behind a sister after their parents were killed. (Book chosen to study a family's struggle to survive the ravages of war while caught in the cross hairs of unending chaos.)

Push Push by Sindiwe Magona - A collection of short stories on family and poverty and family, each story focusing on ways political and cultural forces trap individuals in situations they couldn't foresee (Book chosen to explore the adaptability of families without resource.) 

The Song of Achilles by Madeline Miller -  Patroclus is an awkward young prince, exiled to the kingdom of Phthia. Everyone avoids him, he is barely seen, hardly wanted, and basks in is aloneness. He is everything opposite to King Peleus and his golden son, Achilles. Achilles, is everything Patroclus is not -- strong, beautiful, the child of a goddess -- and by all rights their paths should never cross. Yet one day, Achilles takes the shamed prince under his wing and soon their tentative companionship gives way to a steadfast friendship. (Book chosen to research the transformative power of friendship.)
 

 

WHERE

Conwell Dance Theater is locating on the 5th Floor of Conwell Hall, Temple University

 

Venue: Conwell Dance Theater

3 Pony Show / keila cordova dances is excited to return to Conwell in 2017!

I've been able to create and be inspired by the space and the team at Conwell. It has been a creative home for my work. Your support goes towards supporting our production and artist costs. It's a great joy to be able to dance on a stage that is so incredibly supportive of dance.

Linear Default, 2016

 

WHY

We know how fortunate we are to have such a great community. When you support KITH, you are supporting the importance of the arts, expressing value for the arts in our community and in our world.  I get to create with amazing performers on this project  and these funds will go towards artists fees and production costs. 

Dance has the power to explore the human story like no other art form. Your support means we can create KITH, document a high quality performance experience and have a professional standard video of the work to use after to support the continuation and future performances of KITH.

I would love your support at any amount of contribution. Check out the fun selection of perks we're offering! Spread the word! Help us meet our goal!

Please donate today.

Thank you!

Keila
