story:
Short Summary

JSLN Dance Company brings ballet with a difference to audiences in venues with a difference. We believe that world class ballet should be accessible to all audiences without the need to travel to bigger towns and cities and that it shouldn’t be limited to venues with perfect stages for dance.

In this campaign, we’re looking for dance lovers and supporters of JSLN Dance Company to help us continue to bring Sören Niewelt’s beautiful work to you in your home towns and villages.  Our audiences from this year’s Variations of Pointe II tour have overwhelmingly asked the company to return but we have yet to secure funding to proceed.

We would love for JSLN to become “self-funded”, through our supporters and sponsors.  This would allow us to do what we love doing and to bring you shows you love seeing. Our Facebook page alone shows almost 2,500 followers and “likes”.  This doesn’t include all the amazing feedback we’ve had from all of you during the Variations of Pointe II tour.  We performed to over a thousand of you in June and July this year. 

By contributing to our campaign, you can help JSLN continue bringing dance not just to theatres and other locations, but to those who can’t get to our performances such as elderly residents in care homes and disabled children and young people in schools.  These organisations have neither the funds to pay for a performance or workshop nor the staff required to take people to performance venues.

What We Need & What You Get

  • In order to bring our next show to you, we need to be able to cover the basics such as costumes, props, travel, insurance, publicity materials and advertising costs.
  • As you may know, our Summer 2017 tour, Variations of Pointe II only happened because our dancers agreed to work for a subsistence allowance only.
  • We must be able to pay our dancers since loyalty and love of the work only stretches so far.
  • We’re looking for you to help us out and we know that many of you have already given us donations towards our Variations of Pointe II tour and bought raffle tickets at our shows.
  • Box office sales and workshop fees can pay for our basics but will not cover salaries.
  • Our income from ticket sales, based on our previous tours, will be about £12,000.
  • We are already receiving sponsorship in kind for rehearsal studio space, towards accommodation, for music editing and photography, and our behind the scenes staff are giving their time free of charge too. 
  • We need to raise £50,000 to make this tour work and we’re asking for your help to raise this.
  • Through this crowdfunding appeal, we would like to offer you some special perks in return for supporting JSLN Dance Company rather than just asking for your donation.
  • Raffles held at our shows have proved popular, with prizes of signed pointe shoes and photos of our dancers being in great demand.
  • We would also like to bring you our 2018 calendar as a perk as well as some new merchandise items such as T-shirts.
  • We’re offering the opportunity to watch the company in rehearsal and class before the show too.  Our “Behind the Scenes with JSLN” workshops will have given a little taste of how a touring dance company works but this perk will be for a limited number of people to see the no-frills, unedited version!
  • If you’re a dance student and would like to have a special coaching experience, we’re offering private lessons with our Principal Dancer, Jessica Larbig or our Artistic Director.
  • If there is something you would like from us and can’t see in the list of perks, please contact us and let us know, we can always create other perks!
  • Every little bit helps us reach our goal, even if you can only afford to give £5 or £10.  We have almost 2,500 followers on Facebook alone so if everyone gave £10 we would be a good way towards our target!

The Impact

  • Through your feedback at our shows, we know you want to see more. 
  • JSLN Dance Company has toured the length and breadth of the UK for two seasons and our audiences are asking us to return.
  • We can’t do this without funding and sponsorship. 
  • By giving to this campaign you can help us continue to bring the joy of dance to our audiences
  • Odile promises to be an amazing ballet which will enthral all audiences.  If you enjoyed our triple bills Variations of Pointe I and II, we can promise that you will love Odile!

Risks & Challenges

  • We know that our audiences want to see more of JSLN Dance Company and we’re confident that Sören Niewelt’s new two-act ballet will amaze all of you.
  • Our biggest challenge, as it has always been, is to raise funds to bring our performances to you.
  • We have already confirmed bookings for performance venues and tickets are already on sale for our winter tour.  If we do not get sufficient funding, the biggest risk is that the tour cannot proceed.
  • While we are applying for funding from various sources, this is never guaranteed as we have found in the past.
  • Many care homes around our performance venues are looking forward to being a part of “Happy Feet”. Please help us to not disappoint the staff and residents.
  • We’re fortunate enough to have supporters in kind who are giving their services either free of charge or at discounted rates but our biggest expense is paying our dancers
  • Without well trained and highly motivated dancers, there would be no JSLN Dance Company.  It takes an average of 15 years to train a dancer, they deserve to be paid a proper fee for their work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, without funds JSLN can’t function, but there are many other ways you can help us too. We've been told many times during our last tour that we don't advertise enough or do enough publicity.  Unfortunately, we can't afford paid advertisements in the local press, nor are we able to travel to every single town or village we’re performing in to distribute publicity materials in advance.

After dancers' fees, accommodation is by far our second biggest outlay. Even with partial sponsorship for one location, we still need to find affordable accommodation for some other venues.

Please email Loretta at manager@jslndancecompany.com if you are able to, or may be interested in helping out with the following:

  • Helping with publicity for our performances by:
    • Distributing posters and flyers local to our show venues
    • Publicising the show via local press contacts
    • Publicising the show via social media sites
  • Accommodation for the company close to performance venues – there will be 10 dancers and our Artistic Director.
    • If you have an affordable rental property which sleeps 11 or are able to put up the company within an hour’s drive of the following, we’d love to hear from you:
      • Bude, Cornwall
      • St Andrews
      • Gateshead
      • Sittingbourne
  • If you know of a dance school or group, regardless of age or ability who would like a workshop with our Artistic Director and company members, please let us know.

Then, of course, even if you can’t help with any of the above and aren’t in a position to contribute, please help to spread the word about JSLN Dance Company and of course this campaign.

Thank you!
story_txt:
Short Summary
JSLN Dance Company brings ballet with a difference to audiences in venues with a difference. We believe that world class ballet should be accessible to all audiences without the need to travel to bigger towns and cities and that it shouldn’t be limited to venues with perfect stages for dance.
In this campaign, we’re looking for dance lovers and supporters of JSLN Dance Company to help us continue to bring Sören Niewelt’s beautiful work to you in your home towns and villages.  Our audiences from this year’s Variations of Pointe II tour have overwhelmingly asked the company to return but we have yet to secure funding to proceed.
We would love for JSLN to become “self-funded”, through our supporters and sponsors.  This would allow us to do what we love doing and to bring you shows you love seeing. Our Facebook page alone shows almost 2,500 followers and “likes”.  This doesn’t include all the amazing feedback we’ve had from all of you during the Variations of Pointe II tour.  We performed to over a thousand of you in June and July this year. 
By contributing to our campaign, you can help JSLN continue bringing dance not just to theatres and other locations, but to those who can’t get to our performances such as elderly residents in care homes and disabled children and young people in schools.  These organisations have neither the funds to pay for a performance or workshop nor the staff required to take people to performance venues.
What We Need & What You Get

In order to bring our next show to you, we need to be able to cover the basics such as costumes, props, travel, insurance, publicity materials and advertising costs.
As you may know, our Summer 2017 tour, Variations of Pointe II only happened because our dancers agreed to work for a subsistence allowance only.
We must be able to pay our dancers since loyalty and love of the work only stretches so far.
We’re looking for you to help us out and we know that many of you have already given us donations towards our Variations of Pointe II tour and bought raffle tickets at our shows.
Box office sales and workshop fees can pay for our basics but will not cover salaries.
Our income from ticket sales, based on our previous tours, will be about £12,000.
We are already receiving sponsorship in kind for rehearsal studio space, towards accommodation, for music editing and photography, and our behind the scenes staff are giving their time free of charge too. 
We need to raise £50,000 to make this tour work and we’re asking for your help to raise this.
Through this crowdfunding appeal, we would like to offer you some special perks in return for supporting JSLN Dance Company rather than just asking for your donation.
Raffles held at our shows have proved popular, with prizes of signed pointe shoes and photos of our dancers being in great demand.
We would also like to bring you our 2018 calendar as a perk as well as some new merchandise items such as T-shirts.
We’re offering the opportunity to watch the company in rehearsal and class before the show too.  Our “Behind the Scenes with JSLN” workshops will have given a little taste of how a touring dance company works but this perk will be for a limited number of people to see the no-frills, unedited version!
If you’re a dance student and would like to have a special coaching experience, we’re offering private lessons with our Principal Dancer, Jessica Larbig or our Artistic Director.
If there is something you would like from us and can’t see in the list of perks, please contact us and let us know, we can always create other perks!
Every little bit helps us reach our goal, even if you can only afford to give £5 or £10.  We have almost 2,500 followers on Facebook alone so if everyone gave £10 we would be a good way towards our target!

The Impact

Through your feedback at our shows, we know you want to see more. 
JSLN Dance Company has toured the length and breadth of the UK for two seasons and our audiences are asking us to return.
We can’t do this without funding and sponsorship. 
By giving to this campaign you can help us continue to bring the joy of dance to our audiences
Odile promises to be an amazing ballet which will enthral all audiences.  If you enjoyed our triple bills Variations of Pointe I and II, we can promise that you will love Odile!

Risks & Challenges

We know that our audiences want to see more of JSLN Dance Company and we’re confident that Sören Niewelt’s new two-act ballet will amaze all of you.
Our biggest challenge, as it has always been, is to raise funds to bring our performances to you.
We have already confirmed bookings for performance venues and tickets are already on sale for our winter tour.  If we do not get sufficient funding, the biggest risk is that the tour cannot proceed.
While we are applying for funding from various sources, this is never guaranteed as we have found in the past.
Many care homes around our performance venues are looking forward to being a part of “Happy Feet”. Please help us to not disappoint the staff and residents.
We’re fortunate enough to have supporters in kind who are giving their services either free of charge or at discounted rates but our biggest expense is paying our dancers
Without well trained and highly motivated dancers, there would be no JSLN Dance Company.  It takes an average of 15 years to train a dancer, they deserve to be paid a proper fee for their work.

Other Ways You Can Help
Of course, without funds JSLN can’t function, but there are many other ways you can help us too. We've been told many times during our last tour that we don't advertise enough or do enough publicity.  Unfortunately, we can't afford paid advertisements in the local press, nor are we able to travel to every single town or village we’re performing in to distribute publicity materials in advance.
After dancers' fees, accommodation is by far our second biggest outlay. Even with partial sponsorship for one location, we still need to find affordable accommodation for some other venues.
Please email Loretta at manager@jslndancecompany.com if you are able to, or may be interested in helping out with the following:

Helping with publicity for our performances by:
Distributing posters and flyers local to our show venues
Publicising the show via local press contacts
Publicising the show via social media sites


Accommodation for the company close to performance venues – there will be 10 dancers and our Artistic Director.If you have an affordable rental property which sleeps 11 or are able to put up the company within an hour’s drive of the following, we’d love to hear from you:
Bude, Cornwall
St Andrews
Gateshead
Sittingbourne



If you know of a dance school or group, regardless of age or ability who would like a workshop with our Artistic Director and company members, please let us know.

Then, of course, even if you can’t help with any of the above and aren’t in a position to contribute, please help to spread the word about JSLN Dance Company and of course this campaign.
Thank you!

story:
Project Summary

We are DanceAction, a contemporary dance company based in New York, led by Argentinian choreographer Carmen Caceres. We are currently receiving Fiscal Sponsorship from New York Live Arts. With our culturally diverse group of artists, together we create dance works that reflect critical issues in society. Our primary purpose is to interpret these issues and use our works to propel change.

While our work explores a broad variety of topics, our most recent piece “2 Minutes Hate,” reflects the political, social, and economic turmoil of the United States currently. This work, based on the novel “1984,” has been presented on several occasions in New York City.

DanceAction has been invited to perform “2 Minutes Hate” at Ticino in Danza. Ticino in Danza is a contemporary dance festival that takes place every summer in the Ticino region of Switzerland. The festival offers outdoor and site specific performances that melt into the natural landscapes, and the historical and urban sites of the region. Participating in this festival will give us the opportunity to connect with local, national, and international artists.

The Festival will kindly provide accommodation and local transportation. With your support we will be able to cover the additional travel expenses and compensation for 4 company members.

We are thrilled to take “2 Minutes Hate” abroad, and to make a social justice statement for an international artistic community.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to make this happen! Our goal is to raise $5000. With these funds we will be able to cover rehearsal space rentals in New York City, airfares from New York to Switzerland, meals in Ticino, and compensation for 4 artists.

In exchange for your generous contribution, we would like to offer you a few very exciting gifts. Review the "perks" section of the site and you will have an opportunity to enjoy DanceAction merchandise, attend a rehearsal or get free tickets to our next local performance!

Please, make a tax-deductible donation to help us get to Switzerland.

Your support can make a huge impact! “2 Minutes Hate” reflects the current social, political, and economic turmoil of the United States in relationship to the world. Sharing our work in a festival of this scale will allow us to convey our message internationally, raising awareness about social justice.

As we are a young dance company in New York we face multiple challenges. Due to the latest budget cuts made to art organizations by the federal government, such as the National Endowment for the Arts, private funding has become a vital source of support for artists. In order to continue creating and performing new works of art, we need to develop a network of financial support. This will allow us to cover rehearsal costs, production materials, and more importantly, compensation for artists.

Other ways you can help?

All contributions are truly valuable for us, and there are multiple ways of helping! Please spread the word about this project and our company to your friends and family. Stay connected with DanceAction through social media and attending our local performances and events.

Thank you so much for your help! ¡Muchas gracias por ayudarnos!

 

More About DanceAction

Artistic Director/Choreographer: Carmen Caceres

Dancers: Carmen Caceres, Thomas Gunderson Bond, Paige Louise Stella, Laura Orfanelli, Rebecca Burcher, Nicole Jones, Susan Steinman, and Aleixa Freire

Musicians/Composers: Eran Fink, Martin Fuks, Juan Sebastian Vasallo, and Juan Pablo Rosado

Singers: Sofia Juan and Larry Discenza

Graphic Designer: Rosario Caceres

Past Collaborators: Sriya Sarkar, Samsam Yung, Cuong Huy Nguyen, Ana Romero, Michael De Roos, Roma Koolen, and Anthony Rosado

Guest Teaching Artists: Sarah Chien and Emily Faulkner

DanceAction is a New York based contemporary dance company founded by Carmen Caceres in 2012. The company works as a creative platform to produce dance works in collaboration with musicians, designers, and visual artists. DanceAction participated in numerous festivals and performance series in New York and abroad, such as Performance Studio Open House (PSOH) at Center for Performance Research, Take Root at Green Space Studio, and Under Exposed at Dixon Place. DanceAction’s first full-length work, “Game Night” was part of the First International Contemporary Dance Festival of Mexico City (FIDCDMX) in August 2016. The company has recently presented an entire evening of works inspired by political activism and social justice at the Center for Performance Research, Brooklyn, NY. 

Carmen Caceres (Choreographer/Dancer) is a dance artist, originally from Buenos Aires, Argentina. She received a BA in Dance and Education at SUNY Empire State College and deepened her studies in dance at the former Merce Cunningham Studio in New York. In her native city she graduated from the National School of Dance and has studied Dance Composition at the National University of the Arts UNA.

She has been creating and presenting dance works in Argentina and NY since 2009. Her works have been presented in several venues such as Dixon Place, Green Space Studio, Triskelion Arts Center, and Center for Performance Research.

As a performer and collaborator she worked with artists Ines Armas, Isabel Lewis, Jillian Peña, Elia Mrak, Lisa Parra, Sari Nordman, Dardo Galletto, Jody Oberfelder, and Sarah Berges among others. Carmen also works as a movement and dance educator for children at diverse organizations in New York City and Brooklyn.

www.carmencaceres.com

Ticino in Danza: www.ticinoindanza.com

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

My name is Renee Necole writer and producer of "Bad Manners at the Dinner Table", this production is a labor of love and dear to my heart. Being a writer is a gift and one that I take seriously. Each production that I produce has a direct message to its viewers. "Bad Manners at the Dinner Table" is no different as I strive to bring the awareness of judgement and assumption  in this theatrical comedy when one finds out what happens when you invite your sins to dinner.

This campaign is to help the cast of "Bad Manners At The Dinner Table" raise funds to attend the Tampa Bay Theater Festival in Tampa, Florida to perform and be acknowledged as the 2018 Nominee for Best Full Length Stage Play. 

With your support, we are able to achieve new heights with this production, more exposure and the kick off to our 2018-2019 southern tour. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise $6k for this trip. All funds will go towards the travel for our 16 member cast, lodging and per Diem.

We are excited to announce that each contributor will receive a number of amazing perks as a supporter of our cause!

Should we not reach our complete goal. The funds will go towards preparation for our Southern Tour which includes securing venues, marketing & advertisement and cast travel.

 

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

This production is not only comical, but meaningful. While depicting what sins looks like in the flesh it also brings awareness to the how one can judge another. As the old saying goes "you can't judge a book by its cover", life's circumstances leads us all in different paths. You can never know ones path unless you have walked in their shoes.

This award winning stage play has sold out several shows in the Charlotte, North Carolina and surrounding regions. From Chesapeake, VA to Clover, SC now heading to Herndon, VA and Tampa, FL, we are expanding and reaching the masses.

We are a traveling theater company that truly believes that ART is Ministry and we strive to convey this message in each production. Known for its intimate feel with dinner theater and small black box audiences, this production leaves one invested. 

Risks & Challenges

With a cast of 16 it can be quite difficult to find the funding without the support of our followers and those who believe in our mission. 

We intend to continue to hold showcases in our region as well as benefit showcases to support local religious organizations seeking to enhance their ministry vision. These showcases allow us to build our fan base. However, without your support these challenges can remain a road block in our success. 

Our biggest risk are lack of ticket purchases and lack of funding for travel.

Other Ways You Can Help

We've all been blessed with two hands, ONE to help yourself and ONE to help others! WE NEED YOUR HELP. If you are unable to contribute monetary donations, we are always in need of help with sharing our mission and cause on your social media platforms, volunteering for registration at our events, crew for our showcases and marketing & advertisement support.

story:
In the spring of 2015, an idea to produce a show for the alumni of the Malverne High School musicals was born. In the 3 1/2 years since, the interest and framework has grown, but the finances have not. This campaign will help raise the money needed to secure rights, props, set materials, and other fees associated with a full-scale musical. 

My name is Dave Coonan. I am the president of the Malverne Community Theatre and a Malverne High School alumni. After watching an MHS production a few years ago, I became nostalgic. I thought, "Hey, how great would it be if we got together alumni from across the years to meet on the stage and put on a show once again?" No strings attached. No "greater cause". Just do a show for the sake of doing a show. 

Our goal is to have the performances of this show in August of 2019. At this point in time, the structure to produce a show is in place (the Malverne Community Theatre, a 501c3 organization that has the structure to deal with all the logistics that come with a show, is producing it), but we are still rallying people and trying to find the money that is needed to put on a show of this magnitude. 

Everyone who has expressed interest in this show has fond memories of their time on the MHS stage, and are fully committed to bring that part of their lives back and share it with a brand new audience. There has been so much talent across that stage - what would it look like if we put them all together?

This campaign will help to fund this community-wide event. If you'd like to read more about the idea behind the production, please see this article from the Malverne Herald: http://www.liherald.com/stories/locals-hope-to-form-alumni-musical-in-malverne,106905

---

This campaign is asking for the modest amount of $2,000. Anyone who is familiar with staging a full-scale musical knows that this amount of money is laughable, as it will barely cover the rights to whatever show we do. But I am confident in the team that we are assembling to be able to make this happen on whatever budget we establish. Plus, I'm not greedy. And if we happen to raise more than $2,000, then every dollar more is a small victory. 

The money will go towards the aforementioned rights, but also any props, costumes, set pieces, tickets, and other items associated with the production. 

What you get in return for your contribution is your name in the program, on the website, on a sign at the production, and free tickets. 

If we don't reach our entire goal, it will be difficult to stage a musical. The money raised at that point will go towards an alternate production - but we don't want to think that way. 

---

The impact of this production will be exponential for the school, the alumni network, the community, and the arts as a whole. This is an unprecedented event for our community. It bridges the gap between generations and will act as an inspiration to upcoming students to show how important the arts are in their lives. Every person who has graced that stage has been affected by it, and in turn, has developed a love for the theater arts that has only grown over time (myself especially included). 

---

There is a chance that this production doesn't pan out exactly the way we all intended. That is a risk. It happens when lots of people, money, and logistics come together. Put a several-month long commitment on top of that and it makes the process even tougher. That's reality. However, I also know that the Malverne Community Theatre has a lot of fantastically talented people working with it, and I personally have been a guiding force in over 60 productions of all shapes and sizes. I feel very confident that whatever hurdles are thrown at us, we can succeed. As long as we have the people, we can do it. No successful production happens without a team. We have a good base, but we need the rest. 

Be part of our team in any way that you can. Share this campaign. Reach out personally. Contribute. Participate. 

Thank you for reading this. I hope you consider contributing.

There is a chance that this production doesn't pan out exactly the way we all intended. That is a risk. It happens when lots of people, money, and logistics come together. Put a several-month long commitment on top of that and it makes the process even tougher. That's reality. However, I also know that the Malverne Community Theatre has a lot of fantastically talented people working with it, and I personally have been a guiding force in over 60 productions of all shapes and sizes. I feel very confident that whatever hurdles are thrown at us, we can succeed. As long as we have the people, we can do it. No successful production happens without a team. We have a good base, but we need the rest. 
Be part of our team in any way that you can. Share this campaign. Reach out personally. Contribute. Participate. 
Thank you for reading this. I hope you consider contributing.

story:
About

New Fish A Musical has been in development for nearly 3 years and after countless workshops, readings, festival showings, we are ready to take it to a full production. Getting any new piece of theatre together is expensive, but musicals are especially costly and without a long run to make ticket sales from, we won't be able to cover the cost of production so we are asking for your help to get things moving and hopefully this is just the first step.

Our first fund raiser is in The Bath Pub on March 7th with Musical Bingo as well as pizza, a raffle with some great prizes and a few songs from a few friends. We are hoping to reach our target amount through a variety of means,  crowd funding as well as corporate sponsorship, advertising, musical theatre workshops and corporate events. Please feel free to get in touch with any queries.

New Fish A Musical is a story about young adults finding their place in the world; the challenges they are faced with and how these challenges affect their mental health. We follow Anna, a Dublin girl just graduated from Drama school in London, as she transitions into the real world pursuing her ambition to become a Musical Theatre actress and her friends who support her along the way.

An Irish original, bellowing shiny show tunes from the gritty world of the struggling artist with book by Grace O'Malley and music by Ross O'Connor. Co produced by Grace O'Malley and Karen Lee.

Funding

We are determined to bring you a brand new quality production with all the bells and whistles. Your support will help us with cast and crew salaries along with the following:

Set

Lighting

Costumes

Sound

Print and advertising

Transport

Anything we reach over our target will go towards making this production even more fabulous!

Why?

So why are we doing it? Why are we putting ourselves through the stress? There is no reason on earth for tackling such an illogical, irrational, plain stupid project such as getting a brand new musical to production in Dublin, other than an enormous love and belief in what we have created.

THANK YOU!!!

We are asking for your help to get New Fish A Musical up on its’ fins. If you have ever thought of supporting the arts, here is your chance.  
Thank you so much for your support, we are beyond grateful to you for your time and consideration.
XXX



ARIGATO GOZAIMASU!

Instagram @newfishamusical 
Facebook https://www.facebook.com/newfishamusical/

story:
About the Show

Maude, a middle-aged unemployed bartender from Bakersfield, California, purchased a painting from a local thrift store for only a few bucks. Now she's convinced the painting is a long-lost Jackson Pollock masterpiece worth millions!  Lionel, an expert from New York City, flies over to her trailer park home to authenticate the artwork, but what they discover is far beyond what either could have ever imagined.

Who We Are

Off Broadway West Theatre Company is a small, award-winning, San Francisco-based non-profit. Founded in 2006, OBW strives to awaken audiences to an expanded worldview with productions of great theatre classics alongside new works from emerging playwrights. It is our mission at OBW to promote the continued development of theatre while presenting plays that will inspire you to think, laugh, and give you something to talk about long after the stage lights go down.

What We Need 

We seek $10,000 to help fund this production. As a non-profit, all of the money ends up on the stage in one way or another.  Our total production costs will amount to at least $21,000.

Estimated Budget:

  • Production Crew - $5,000
  • Actors - $2,000
  • Theatre Rental - $6,000
  • Set, Costumes, Lighting - $3,000
  • Marketing, royalties, and printing - $5,000
  • Total Production Cost - $21,000

Our Total Production Income will never cover these expenses. 

Why this Show?

  • Who ultimately gets to decide what is true and what is false? In a world filled with fake news, we are constantly challenged to figure out if what we are seeing is truthfully depicted. Bakersfield Mist directly questions authenticity in art, and by extension, our relationships to one another. 
  • We have been producing for ten years and have garnered terrific reviews and awards for our honest and fresh approach to modern and classical plays.  We're delighted to develop this excellent piece!

Risks & Challenges

The life of an independent theatrical company can be precarious. Though our shows are very well received and attended, the costs of production necessarily exceed the income we can earn at the box office. We are not grant-supported. Thus, we must rely on the help of the community. Because we are a 501(c)(3) non-profit, all contributions to Off Broadway West are fully tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.

Other Ways You Can Help!

We get it. There are lots of demands on your time and money; not everybody can afford to contribute. You can still help us by sharing our campaign via email and on social media. Please tell all your friends, and use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The Grenfell Project

This project started as a show for our final year of our Acting and Performance course at the University for the Creative Arts, where "The Grenfell Project" was been showcased at the Farnham Maltings and the Marylebone Theatre in Shepherds Bush as a piece of devised work.Through personal testimony and verbatim theatre techniques we performed this as our final year show.

A few of us decided that this is to important a topic to give up there and are aiming to tour the show so that we can spread the message across the UK. There are still over 3,000 apartment blocks around the country that are still covered in the cladding that cause the Grenfell tragedy to be so severe due to its flammability. 

What We Need 

We already have one show booked at The Bread and Roses Theatre in Clapham, but we wish to continue touring so we can reach as many people as possible. This is how donating to our show will help us tour:

  • Booking influential and popular theatres that will encourage and support our show whilst bringing people into the venue through the venue's prestige.
  • Booking rehearsal space for the cast and director to work.
  • Buying webspace for advertisements and links to our shows
  • Printing leaflets and flyers as well as programmes so all our lovely cast and crew can be credited.

The Impact

In the past, the community of Kensington and Chelsea has been divided by those who are stereotyped as being deprived financially and those who are not, with this poverty profile being a defining factor in their treatment by their council. Through this performance of testimony - from Ladbroke Grove residents, rescuers and some of our own experiences - we wish to inform the public on how and why this disaster is seen as an act of incompetence and greed. We aim to tour our piece so that a widespread message can be communicated, whilst educating those in schools and youth centers about the decisions that caused the fire, in hopes to create a more supportive generation.

Risks & Challenges

A topic such a Grenfell is an ethical conundrum. We wish to fairly portray everyone involved in this tragedy whilst trying to obtain justice for the residents of the community. Verbatim theatre has had a recent surge in popularity and with many moral issues up for debate it is important as aspiring artists to experiment and find our path to a fair and inclusive performance. As actors, it is important for us to explore how to fairly represent those whose experiences we are bringing to the spotlight and being respectful of their misfortune. We also have the job of revealing faults in the councils support for those at Grenfell whilst not attacking them on a personal level. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't in a position to contribute you can still help us out by:

  • Share this Indiegogo campaign to your friends, family, colleagues who you think might be interested!
  • Share our Facebook page!
  • Come see the show! On at The Bread and Roses Theatre from the 26th of February to the 2nd of Mach. Check their website for more information! https://www.breadandrosestheatre.co.uk

story:
The Creation

Golem is a contemporary dance performance pioneering the human body through the virtual space.   What does this mean?

It means we have a cutting-edge dance performance live onstage and in Virtual Reality. Through fresh contemporary choreography, the movement of talented dancers will be followed by motion-captioning sensors, virtual reality headsets and digital avatars to create an immersive, blow-your-mind experience between man and machine. The performance is the first of its kind, offering a live showing in VR -- “Virtual Theater” -- and onstage in a physical theater. Yes -- the show will also be LIVE in VR, viewable from anywhere on the globe with a headset.

Think Avatar, meets Minority report, meets Black Mirror performance piece - live. The brains behind this project have worked on the technology for years, but for the first time ever in the realms of art such as dance.

Golem will premiere July 25, 26, 27 at Uferstudios 1 in Berlin, Germany. This unique space is an old swimming pool transformed into a theater. We’ve selected this venue due to its immersive quality, creating a physical performance space to mirror the immersion accessible in the Virtual theater (in VR).

The Story

Golem will feature powerful choreography synergized with motion-capture VR technology to develop a stimulating visual experience. But the narrative goes even further than that.

The story centers on the concept of the self: the body in its physical and digital forms. Through contemporary dance, a fleshy human figure discovers its virtual data-body via the motion capture system. A non-linear narrative of subjectivity arises, reflective of the digital trends present in our current technosphere: vanity, narcissism, and a curation of the digitalized body. The avatar will vie and dance with it’s human creator.

The story ultimately hinges on the link between physical and digitized bodies: can the physical self stay autonomous? Or are we forever linked to our digital form?

Carly has been exploring the human body’s relationship to the world around us since the beginning of her career. She takes particular interest in the bodily engagement with technology, societal systems and the Earth beneath us. To check out her extensive work thus far, go to www.carlylave.com. 

The Technology 

The performance will feature a radical use of the Optitrack motion-capture system with accompanying body sensors and Head-Mounted Displays (HMDs) onstage. Through live projections, the dancers will interact with a motion-captured representation of their body in the virtual environment, engineered in Unity by the Kaiserslautern team. Together with Carly, the students of Kaiserslautern University are designing a specialty world and avatars for the performance.

The Collaborators

Golem pulls together visionaries across industry and academia. We have a cast of 5 dancers and more than 20 creatives spanning the fields of dance, performance philosophy, virtual design, sound engineering, computer philosophy, and lighting and stage design involved.  

Together, a cross-disciplinary team from gamelab.berlin (of Humboldt Universität zu Berlin), the Virtual Design Lab of Kaiserslautern Hochschule, and Carly Lave forged in December 2018 to envision new methodologies of using motion-capture technology and virtual reality in a performance space.

Sound: We are honored to feature the sound of ose (Arushi Jain) for the performance. As ose, Arushi brings out the vibrancy of Hindustani classical in modern electronica, primarily using modular synthesizers and her voice to craft ambient microtonal textures emphasized with distorted rhythm and disorienting glitch. Arushi is the founder of Ghunghru, a experimental record label & radio series based out of San Francisco and a graduate of Stanford University.  

Design & Film: Golem’s visual art and design is in collaboration with Indexthumb (William Hamilton), an experimental visual artist focused on combining alchemical/dream imagery and sci-fi aesthetics in film, photography, and design

The Challenge

The scale of this project is massive and involves an array of artists, storytelling professionals, and dancers. And of course all of the state-of-the-art technology (cables, multiple computers, VR Head-Mounted Displays (HMDs), and the like). In order to accomplish this, We need your help bringing this production to life! 

The funds for the execution of the project are the primary challenge we are facing at the moment. Contributions we collect will be arranged to cover various parts of the project, as all are interdependent to pull off the production. Given the expertise and pioneering technologies used in Golem, we need to raise at least $25K to cover our base costs. 

Where is that money going?? Here's a quick breakdown of some of our costs:

  • $10 - One hr of rehearsal space (we rehearse 3 x week, 2-3 hrs per session)
  • $200 - Costume materials and construction for one body 
  • $500 - Rehearsal space for the project
  • $700 - Artist fee for Lighting Designing (we also have a costume designer & visual designer ;)
  • $1200 - Compensation of one dancer for the project
  • $2000 - Lighting Rental, Installation, Labor for one week in theater
  • $5000 - Performance Venue rental

As patrons of the arts, we wish to be transparent with you about this, and feel that openness is better for all parties. We are working insanely hard to develop the first phase of the project as low-cost and budget-friendly as possible.

We have developed amazing perks that will put you on the front lines of this amazing project - you can get everything from Golem stickers to dance lessons from Carly, or a seat in the VR theatre in July. We want you to feel proud to be part of Golem as much as we are.

The Support

Our ambition is high, we know. But we are eager to bring the next wave of art & technology to the masses. We are fervent believers in the power of the people, which is why we believe in our community to help us reach this goal and support the next wave of groundbreaking art & tech.

Golem is an attempt to reckon with humanity’s engagement with digital technologies, confronting the body-machine relationship through movement of the body itself. Did we mention that the performance will be viewable live in VR?!

We also know that not everyone will have the means to donate. If you are able to share support in other acts of loving kindness, we would super appreciate:

  • Sharing the campaign link with your friends via email, text, social media - every dollar counts
  • Talk about Golem online - share the visuals (i.e the campaign videos) for promotion
  • Follow Carly on Facebook and Instagram for production updates that could be relevant to you - (maybe we even tour Golem to your part of the world!)

In any case, your support in whichever form, means the world -- both the physical and virtual 

Virtually yours,

Carly & the Golem team

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Candice, I am an aerialist/performing artist based in Northampton, MA. I have been training and performing professionally for the past seven years and look forward to many more! There is great excitement and joy found in both performing and viewing shows where the artists are able to captivate the audience entirely. Northampton and the surrounding areas are filled with an immense amount of unique talent, but lack an equal amount of opportunity to share them. It has been a great hope of mine to be able to create a platform in which performing artists may showcase their gifts in the form of a Vaudeville style variety show entitled “Vaudeville in the Valley”.

What I Need (am hoping for)

I have set a goal of $3,000.

If this goal is met, the funding will go to the following:

1. Artists involved in the show

2. Venue Rental

3. Production Costs (lighting, sound, marketing materials)

Anyone who wishes to be mentioned for their donation is welcome to be listed in our show brochure.

Truly, any support is greatly appreciated. Even if the goal is not reached my main focus is to pay the performers their professional compensation. I take great pride in what I do and look forward to putting on a fantastic show that can be appreciated by many.

 

The Impact

Art is created to be appreciated and that is exactly what this show aims to do. We are introducing a unique form of entertainment to a community that is bound to adore it. This show is the first of its kind at the chosen venue, The Northampton Center for the Arts.

On a personal note, choosing to produce a show of this kind to create a platform for others is not only a large commitment, but also a terrifying endeavor. It would mean to world to me (and many others) to be able to financially support an incredible show to be shared.

Finally, and most importantly, a successful show creates new opportunities for artists, 

Risks & Challenges

First impressions are key, correct? Well, being that this show is the first of it's kind in this area, I have high hopes of creating an excellent first impression to the show scene. Without the proper funding for an event like this, it could so easily flop. For example, artist's performances need to be highlighted with professional lighting and accompanied by a professional sound tech to display the artist's work to it's best potential. Creating a mood, and the correct setting for this kind of show is key. 

As an artist myself I will do my best to acquire all that is needed to make this show fantastic, from the welcoming of the guests to the final bow, I am up for the challenge.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help in so many ways,

You can contribute any amount of money... and we will be extremely grateful!

If you are unable to contribute funds...

You can give support by spreading the word!

Tell 1, 2 or 10 friends about the show "Vaudeville in the Valley"

Remember: you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

If this goal is met, the funding will go to the following:
1. Artists involved in the show
2. Venue Rental
3. Production Costs (lighting, sound, marketing materials)
Anyone who wishes to be mentioned for their donation is welcome to be listed in our show brochure.
Truly, any support is greatly appreciated. Even if the goal is not reached my main focus is to pay the performers their professional compensation. I take great pride in what I do and look forward to putting on a fantastic show that can be appreciated by many.
 
The Impact
Art is created to be appreciated and that is exactly what this show aims to do. We are introducing a unique form of entertainment to a community that is bound to adore it. This show is the first of its kind at the chosen venue, The Northampton Center for the Arts.
On a personal note, choosing to produce a show of this kind to create a platform for others is not only a large commitment, but also a terrifying endeavor. It would mean to world to me (and many others) to be able to financially support an incredible show to be shared.
Finally, and most importantly, a successful show creates new opportunities for artists, 
Risks & Challenges
First impressions are key, correct? Well, being that this show is the first of it's kind in this area, I have high hopes of creating an excellent first impression to the show scene. Without the proper funding for an event like this, it could so easily flop. For example, artist's performances need to be highlighted with professional lighting and accompanied by a professional sound tech to display the artist's work to it's best potential. Creating a mood, and the correct setting for this kind of show is key. 
As an artist myself I will do my best to acquire all that is needed to make this show fantastic, from the welcoming of the guests to the final bow, I am up for the challenge.
Other Ways You Can Help
You can help in so many ways,
You can contribute any amount of money... and we will be extremely grateful!
If you are unable to contribute funds...
You can give support by spreading the word!
Tell 1, 2 or 10 friends about the show "Vaudeville in the Valley"
Remember: you can use the Indiegogo share tools!
And that's all there is to it.

story:
About No Exit:

No Exit is a simple story about four complex individuals trapped in Hell through no fault but their own. This production plays within the divides of Fate and Free Will. On stage our characters experience the consequences of the theories of Existentialism,  set forth by Sartre. “Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does. It is up to you to give life a meaning."  On the contrary, you,  our Audience, will experience the show from a perspective of Fate. Our Valet will escort you to a seat at his mercy. Once seated you will have no where to look but directly forward...unless of course, you choose to take fate into their own hands and change your perspective.

Our $15,000 goal for this production is lofty, we know. With this money we will be able to create moving and compelling theater at the level this show deserves. Your contribution will help us achieve our vision by allowing us to afford the elements of our set that help elevate the story and guide our audiences' collective and singular experience. Here's a bit of what it takes to put up a masterful production: 

$3000 / $5000 - Location rental & insurance 

$5000 - Set, Props, Costumes

$1700 - Payment for cast and crew

$1800 - Rights to the script

$1,000 - Lights & Sound

$1,000 - Promotional material, programs

$1,000 - incidentals & emergency fund. 

$500 - Concessions  

 

About Noisy Nest: Theatrical Production Company

Amanda Bird founded Noisy Nest in 2014 producing and directing the company's premier production Armitage by Don Nigro later that year. Noisy Nest has become a community of diverse talents. To make sure our community thrives, we provide affordable educational programs, free weekly events (The Play Readers) and in house content creation (Holiday film festivals).  To learn more about what we do and what events are coming up visit www.NoisyNest.com

Noisy Nest pushes our artists to be audacious and risky in their work- we have high expectations and the pay off has been greater than we could have imagined. We also take our audiences into high consideration when developing productions. Our upcoming production of No Exit by Jean-Paul Sartre will seat our audiences in this inescapable hell with no where to look but into the mirrors of humanity.  

Our past shows:  Armitage by Don Nigro [Chrstina Moses (A Million Little Things, The Originals)  Hope Lauren (Supergirl, Awkward), Ashley Bacon (Orange is the New Black)] Proof by David Auburn [Chaz Bono (American Horror Story)  Zarah Kulczycki (The Nice Guys) Ashley Murray (The Valley, Sole), Almost Maine by John Cariani [Spencer Neville (Ozark)] and Be A good Little Widow by Bekah Brunstetter [Fayelyn Bilodeau (American Woman)]

story:
Short Summary

HI! Shelley Virginia and Ty Hewitt here! We are professional actors and teachers who love making theatre and love living in Alaska! We founded and are Co-Artistic Directors of CAZART,  Alaska’s newest professional theatre. Our mission is to create thought-provoking work that explores and reflects our shared humanity, inspiring interaction, and conversation within our community. 

We believe that through the medium of theatre we can, as a community, develop a deeper sense of empathy and understanding to those around us and move the conversation forward to make our world a better place.

CAZART’s first production will be Lungs, by Duncan MacMillan.… LUNGS is a smart and funny drama that follows a couple through the surprising lifecycle of their relationship as they grapple with questions of family and change, hope, betrayal, happenstance, and the terrible pain that you can only cause the people you love.

What We Need & What You Get

For this show, we are endeavoring to raise $12,000.

At CAZART we aim to produce the highest quality work while giving pre-professional theatre artists the opportunity to work with and learn from their professional counterparts. We also believe in paying artists for their work. 

The funding raised for this project will go directly towards providing stipends for our director, actors, designers, support staff, booking rehearsal/performance space, travel for out of town artists, set and costume budget, marketing materials, tour expenses, and all the odds and ends that add up when making a show!

 

The Impact

By supporting this project you will be helping to produce the highest quality theatrical entertainment while giving pre-professional theatre artists the opportunity to work with and learn from their professional counterparts.

  • Supporting the arts and arts education in Alaska
  • Providing an opportunity for professional theatre artists to practice their craft in our great state
  • Providing pre-professional artists the opportunity to remain in the state while gaining invaluable professional experience
  • Providing tickets and training opportunites those in need
  • Providing the space and opportunity for people to come together and discuss the topics of vital importance in our community

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help out but can’t donate money?

  • Donate Alaska Air miles to help us get our guest artists to our beautiful state, as well as cover touring expense so that we can go to underserved communities within our state!

  • Are you a lawyer or know one who wants to help CAZART become a not for profit organization?

  • House an artist! We currently need housing for an artist from July 23 to August 9.

story:
Short Summary

  • Introduction
Dinaka/Kiba music and dance or mmino wa setšo as is known among rural communities in Limpopo province, South Africa; is an important heritage from pre-colonial Southern Africa. While there is progress in as far as developing the art-form is concerned, a lot more still needs to be done to research, develop and preserve Dinaka/Kiba music and dance

  • Campaign description and why it's important

Dinaka/Kiba is an important heritage from pre-colonial Southern Africa. In spite the fact that the music is one of the oldest indigenous genres in Southern Africa, the art form continues to struggle to make an impact in the lives of communities due to structural challenges. The festival is strategically designed to re-engineer the art form by dealing with structural challenges in a quest to ensure that Dinaka/Kiba artists benefit economically from their talents.

  • How your funds can help achieve the goal.

The organisers wish to make this an annual ‘school’, humbly asking what defines a festival and what can it do for public space. With kind support from the National Arts Council of South Africa this year(2014), the festival aims to set the tone for proposed future developmental initiatives alongside the festival. This includes amongst many; research projects aimed at using scientific inquiry to identify problems towards innovative solutions. 


What We Need & What You Get

  • How much we need
We want to raise at least twenty thousand US dollars for the second year going forward. The money will help us relive the memory of a neglected heritage site(abandoned in 1964 when the former apartheid government forcefully removed residents)  where Dinaka/Kiba practitioners used to perform and socialize by designing culturally relevant structures which will serve as a Cultural Center of annual performance, pedagogy, social science research, cooperative economics, knowledge sharing and community development.

  • Unique perks for our funders!

We are in the process of registering a cooperative that will help Dinaka/Kiba practitioners deal with structural challenges. Once the cooperative is registered, we will be inviting people to buy Shares(an initial 20%) and help the cooperative grow and give a Return on Investment(ROI) for investors. Anyone above from 18 years can  sign up as a member. 

Application for membership and for the number of shares an application wishes to take up shall be made on the form provided for that purpose, and shall be accompanied by the entrance fee.

A share certificate(as per the cooperative constitution) shall be issued in the relevant form.

On visit funders will be welcomed by local traditional leadership, cultural practitioners, community leaders and treated to Indigenous music, dance, food, colorful costumes and souvenirs to take home. 

Also take home studio recorded debut CD titled modimo wa fase(released 2012) by Molepo Traditional Dance Group.


  • Reserve fund just in case we dont reach target.
As per the constitution, the funds will go into the cooperative's reserve funds if the entire goal is not reached.

The Impact

  • Why project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.

There are quite a handful of research publications on the philosophical foundations, theoretical paradigmatic approaches for Indigenous Knowledge Systems research, ethnographic and descriptive analyses of Indigenous music genres (see Nketia 1992; Pewa 1997; Nzewi 2007; Mapaya 2010, 2011, 2012, 2014; Galane 2009). Yet very little is written on the entrance and active participation of Indigenous music genres, in particular Dinaka/Kiba dance and music groups into the mainstream economy given the general consensus that this genre and other related are isolated and often marginalized. During the plenary session in 2013, President Jacob Zuma addressed parliament in a statement addressing the BRICS Summit theme BRICS and Africa: Partnership for Development, Integration and Industrialization. In his words, “the Knowledge Economy needs to be a learning economy as we and other emerging markets and developing countries shift from primary to industrial production, notably to enjoy beneficiation, to the supply of modern services”. The president’s utterances are important looking at rapid changes to the economy brought in by major drivers such as technology. For politicians, economists and many others in related disciplines, addressing issues of development and the production of modern services has become synonymous with a concept such as the knowledge economy. But what does the knowledge economy mean for the Arts and Culture sector?

  • Success story
In 2013, an application was submitted to the National Arts Council of South Africa for funding to hot the first Dinaka/Kiba Festival in Ga Molepo. The application was successful and a budget was allocated for the event. The event will be held as follows:
Date: 29 November 2014
Venue: Theology Sports Ground Mankgaile village, Ga Molepo, Polokwane
Time: 09:00 AM-17:00 PM South African time
 We hope to make this event an "annual school", hence need more funding and sponsorship to grow the event. 
  • Our location(Africa, South Africa, Capricorn District,  Polokwane Municipality, Ga Molepo).
The 1st Annual Molepo Dinaka/Kiba Festival takes place in Mankgaile village, Ga Molepo, Polokwane. To view the location copy and paste the following link: https://www.google.co.za/maps/@-23.9906136,29.7...
The festival was a succes and we looking forward to 2015. Like us on Facebook for more updates https://www.facebook.com/pages/Molepo-DinakaKiba-Festival/695554547205868

Risks & Challenges

  • Overcoming our hurdles
This campaign is in response to the current material conditions in which practitioners of Dinaka/Kiba music and dance find themselves in mainly due to the marginalization of these indigenous art forms by a society that has since embraced more modern kinds of genres such as jazz and the fact that there are notably fundamental problems regarding the focus of traditional music scholarship in academic fields such as ethnomusicology and musicology as the reader will notice in the literature review section to follow. In spite the fact that indigenous music and related genres are the oldest art forms on the African continent, the practitioners continue to fall by the roadside when it comes to the production, packaging, marketing and selling of quality goods and services; which are in some cases; non existent. We foresee our engagement of African musicology through our field experience with Dinaka/Kiba music and dance groups and through academe (Information Science) as a noble and unique entrance into the music research enterprise since the early days of participation by anthropologists and later on ethnologists and sociologists. 

An ideal typical revamped Dinaka/Kiba music and dance group should be registered as a Co-Operative(CIPC, 2005), have all members inaugurated as board members with the executive divided into a chairperson, secretary, treasurer, communications officer, marketing officer and other office bearers. This legal form of business will help Dinaka/Kiba music and dance groups observe the legal rights and ownership framework post 1994; where according to Galane (2009: 16) it can also help counter “the extend which it fails to protect the development of indigenous musical arts, South Africa’s musicians as well as its concomitant non protection of artists in the recording industry of South Africa”.


  • Our five year plan .
We plan to acquire at least 10 hectares (15 000 m2) of land from traditional authorities in Ga Molepo. With the advice and help of architects and space design professionals we can design low rate culturally significant structures to be used for shelter during festivals. These structures will assume a permanent life in the community, to be used throughout the year for similar and other events. Over a three year period, we can safely look at these structures as 'campuses' for an informally structured 'periodic' school that is the annual festival. Here we are asking what a festival can do for its environmental location as well as investigating whether the idea of an Independent Arts and Culture Comprehensive school can happen; in a place that is distinct from the hosts of the Cape Town International Jazz Festival, Maphungubwe Arts Festival and others. In other words, by so doing; we would be asking pertinent questions like: how does a festival take an overt cultural, political and economic position?

So, for the amounts of the two years(2014/2015) strategic plan budget, we can buy affordable material such as stainless steel, sand, cement, rocks, grass and wood (some of which can be sourced for free in the community) to design permanent infrastructure of great artistic merit, and use the remainder to pay for labour (in the form of community builders and constructors and workshops on design and architecture from expertise). Indeed, we could also apply for in-kind sponsorship for these materials to build sustainable, permanent infrastructure, thus using the bulk of the money for workshops and labour costs, a contribution to human resources stimulated by the festival itself.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Asking you help make noise about this campaign.
The initiators of the festival collectively are interested in poetry, visual art, architecture, oral history, agriculture, cooperative economics and technology. We hope that the festival is a fertile ground for community members, learners, educators, artists, scientists, business people and the general public to realise innovative and ethical experiments as a contribution to a vibrant and thriving society. Help us get the word out.
  • Please use Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!
Even if you not going to fund, at least share within your circles as that will make a huge difference.

story:
Our Story (changed and edited as of May 25th)

When we started this campaign it was to get our talented team and unique band to the US to present Haitian history through a pantomime and original beautiful songs that share the sadness, pain and love that is part of Haiti's present reality as well.  Due to different complications involving shortage and slowness of contributions as well as Haitian immigration passport imbroglio thus retarding US immigration petition and visa appointments has caused us to transform this tour from being US based to a Haitian national tour, postponing the US tour until next year. The historical drama called "3 Innocents and a spirit",

puts 700 years of history on stage in less than an hour using a dramatic soundtrack, props and costumes. The band "2 Roots"

plays original music expressing this history and social realities using melodies that express dreams for a more beautiful world using a blend of Haitian rhythms and American fingerpicking and classical violin. 

What We (Really) Need and What You Get

This funding campaign was intended to provide the roundtrip airfare from Port-au-Prince Haiti to the US and back as well as pay for the costly American Embassy appointments required to obtain the needed visas in their passports.  Now funds donated will go directly towards transportation, food and lodging and other logistics  in Haiti that are costly due to little infrastructure making transportation expensive and requiring generating our own electricity for much of the country. We plan on traveling to the north as one part and then to the south as another, ending up with a finale performance at the historical "Sugar Cane Park" in Port-au-Prince.

The Impact

This tour will provide an invaluable opportunity for this rare art form of pantomime that clearly portrays historical events to be presented in schools and universities to a multitude of communities throughout the country of Haiti. The impact of these performances will be to pursue deep spiritual insights about our wounded societies evoked through mime and music with the potential of realizing the power of love that can heal our broken world.

Risks and Challenges

We have realized the risk of not reaching our fundraising goal for the original idea of getting us to the US at this point so we have made these mentioned changes in order to keep the momentum of sharing the theater and music with as many as possible, going.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can contribute financially, but there are other ways to help! We are asking all of our friends and supporters to spread the word about our campaign. Share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, all other social media outlets, and tell our story to those you think might be interested in helping out in this way. Indiegogo has some “sharing” tools to help you do this! We appreciate all and any effort to promote our campaign!

Want to know more about us?

Visit our website at http://www.wewillrememberhaiti.org/  

Our blog with trailer and feedback photos and articles from former tours:

http://3innocents.blogspot.com

and on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/nasonje/

Listen to one of 2 Roots’ songs on our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/2rasin/
story_txt:
Our Story (changed and edited as of May 25th)
When we started this campaign it was to get our talented team and unique band to the US to
present Haitian history through a pantomime and original beautiful songs that share the sadness, pain and love that is part of Haiti's present reality as well.  Due to different complications involving shortage and slowness of contributions as well as Haitian immigration passport imbroglio thus retarding US immigration petition and visa appointments has caused us to transform this tour from being US based to a Haitian national tour, postponing the US tour until next year. The historical drama called "3 Innocents and a spirit", puts 700 years of history on stage in less than an hour using a dramatic soundtrack, props and costumes. The band "2 Roots" plays original music expressing this history and social realities using melodies that express dreams for a more beautiful world using a blend of Haitian rhythms and American fingerpicking and classical violin. 
What We (Really) Need and What You
Get
This
funding campaign was intended to provide the roundtrip airfare from
Port-au-Prince Haiti to the US and back as well as pay for the costly American Embassy appointments required to obtain the needed visas in their passports.  Now funds donated will go directly towards transportation, food and lodging and other logistics  in Haiti that are costly due to little infrastructure making transportation expensive and requiring generating our own electricity for much of the country. We plan on traveling to the north as one part and then to the south as another, ending up with a finale performance at the historical "Sugar Cane Park" in Port-au-Prince.
The Impact
This
tour will provide an invaluable opportunity for this rare art form of pantomime that clearly portrays historical events to be presented in schools and universities to a multitude of communities throughout the country of Haiti. The impact of these performances will be to pursue deep spiritual insights about our wounded societies evoked
through mime and music with the potential of realizing the power of love
that can heal our broken world.
Risks and Challenges
We have realized the risk of not reaching our fundraising goal for the original idea of getting us to the US at this point so we have made these mentioned changes in order to keep the momentum of sharing the theater and music with as many as possible, going.
Other Ways You Can Help
We
know that not everyone can contribute financially, but there are other ways to
help! We are asking all of our friends and supporters to spread the word about
our campaign. Share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, all other social media
outlets, and tell our story to those you think might be interested in helping
out in this way. Indiegogo has some “sharing” tools to help you do this! We appreciate all
and any effort to promote our campaign!
Want to know more about us?
Visit
our website at http://www.wewillrememberhaiti.org/  
Our
blog with trailer and feedback photos and articles from former tours:
http://3innocents.blogspot.com
and
on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/nasonje/
Listen
to one of 2 Roots’ songs on our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/2rasin/

story:
Who we are

The Associates met during our apprenticeship at Actors Theatre of Louisville, where we trained together in devising techniques and identified our ambition to change the trajectory of storytelling tradition. Actors Theatre furnished us with space, collaborators of every stripe, and the critical eye of an audience, and we created our first ensemble plays in a swift, one-week process. Upon completion of the apprenticeship we began devising work in New York, composing a kaleidoscopic portrait of consent that we scripted and then, doffing our playwright hats, workshopped and performed as an ensemble.

What we do

We want the audience to laugh: through surprise,  discomfort,  arousal, and constant reorientation to the truth. We are building a slip‘n slide here. The ride is messy and fun.  We have no regard for political correctness, and we hope that gives the audience a direct channel to the truth of our societal inner monologues.

Our current project, Black Protagonist, was written by the ensemble from August to December. In January, we produced an intensive two-week workshop that culminated in three performances for the public at Treehouse Theater. Those performances gave us the fodder for a revision of the piece that will continue through the First Floor Studio residency at HB Studio in June and July. We plan to mount a full, three-week production in fall 2015.

How much you matter to us

We are raising money to fund our next full year of work. Our dreams are huge, and we have great resourcefulness to match them, but your generosity gives us our best chance of realizing them. Your contributions will help us: rent rehearsal space; print scripts, posters, programs, research; pay our designers and bring their genius  to the stage in the set, lighting, sound, and projection design; apply for residencies and festivals; and reach wider audiences by promoting our work, online and on paper.


Why the video has no dubbing

Thanks to a head start, we are now raising $10,000 through our Indiegogo campaign (rather than $12,000, as we say in the video). The gift made us happy, but unfortunately we have no experience in dubbing campaign videos! We hope you'll join us in putting the remaining $10,000 together, so The Associates can get down to business.
