story:
The Essential Theatre
1112 11th Street, NW, Suite 100
Washington, District of Columbia 20001
www.theessentialtheatre.org

Celebrate Our 25th Anniversary:  Help Nina Simone Sing
 
In late summer/early fall, we will conclude our 25th anniversary celebration with a production of Simply Simone, The Music of Nina Simone, an exciting new biomusical honoring the Jazz Icon and Civil Rights Activist.
We Need Your Support  
 Your contribution will help us launch a full-scale production of Simply Simone. It will feature a smooth four piece band, dazzling lighting, costumes and movement, and a cast of four women who will bring the house down nightly.

About Simply Simone
Simply Simone, stylish and entertaining, confirms that Simone defied classification, excelling in a broad range of musical styles. The show takes the audience on Simone's journey through civil rights activism in the 1960’s and her voyages across the U.S. and abroad. It includes some of Simone’s greatest hits, such as Sinner Man, A Little Sugar in My Bowl, Gimme Some and I Put a Spell on You.

The show was created by Robert Neblet and David Grapes, with musical arrangement by Vince DiMura.

Our Triumphant 2013 Kennedy Center Reading

The Essential Theatre participates in the annual Kennedy Center Page-to-Stage (PTS) Festival. Readings of new works are performed on a shoestring budget. After a maximum of 20 rehearsal hours, actors read the script and score behind music stands, accompanied by piano. Our 2013 PTS reading of Simply Simone was so popular that it had to be moved to a bigger venue than originally planned. We hope the video sample below whets your appetite for more. The crowd’s response was ecstatic, with audience members asking when we would be doing a full production of the show. The time is now!


For the Wireheads
Butchie and Stringer Bell
Killing Butchie

story:
CLICK HERE TO
PURCHASE TICKETS!!!!

Performances of "Emotional Creature" will be on:

  March 27th @ 7pm
  March 28th @ 2pm & 7pm

(VFair starts at 7:00 pm)

Fourth Universalist Society of NYC
160 Central Park West & 76th St.

For the 7th year in a row, we, as 4thU VDay, are proud to support Eve Ensler’s organization, VDay (www.VDay.org), in their global movement to end violence against women and girls.

This year we’ll be staging Eve Ensler's powerful new musical, I AM AN EMOTIONAL CREATURE featuring female youth and young adults telling their perspective of living in the world today. In addition, we’ll be presenting WOMEN’s VOICES, an “opening act” consisting of excerpts from contemporary female playwrights' works on March 27th and 28th.

Over the past 6 years we have raised over $80,000 with our productions of "The Vagina Monologues" and "The Good Body". Of the money raised, 10% has gone to VDay’s work around the world, with the remaining 90% of the proceeds going to a variety of local organizations including Restore NYC, Safe Horizon, Center for Domestic Violence, GEMS, and Men Can Stop Rape, to name a few.

10% of the money raised for our 2015 campaign will go to support The City of Joy, VDay’s transformational leadership community for women survivors of violence, located in Bukavu, Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). (http://drc.vday.org/about-city-of-joy/) The remaining 90% of 4thU-VDay’s proceeds will go to the following local beneficiaries:

Girls Educational & Mentoring Services (GEMS) empowers girls and young women, ages 12-21, who have experienced sexual exploitation and domestic trafficking to exit the commercial sex industry and develop to their full potential. ( www.gems-girls.org ) HerJustice provides free legal assistance to women in need in all 5 boroughs of NYC, over 80% of whom are victims of domestic violence. ( www.herjustice.org )

Part of what makes this event special are the opportunities it offers to businesses and individuals in communities - to participate in this global movement, celebrate and honor the women and girls in your life and community, and to be part of a collective voice, a voice that says NO to violence against women. Our success depends, in large part, on the assistance and generosity of sponsors and donors. 

Please take a look at our perks and join our fundraiser.

In solidarity,

Team 4thU VDay

story:
At a Crossroads...

For over 36 years, Theatre of Yugen has bridged the gap between East and West; preserving the vanishing Japanese art-forms of Noh and Kyogen and making them accessible to Bay Area audiences.  Now, with a new leadership team in place, we're looking towards the future and planning the next 36 years of this vital organization.

We have the potential, and the people, to remain an integral part of the vibrant San Francisco arts community, but we can't do it without you.

Our Past

Theatre of Yugen was founded in 1978 by Yuriko Doi, as an ensemble company performing the traditional Japanese artforms of Noh and Kyogen (the only such company in the U.S. at the time). From there, Yugen grew to creating works of world theater influenced by traditional Japanese performing arts. We strive to project the aesthetic quality of yugen, or mysterious elegance, which gives our work a distinctive style.

  • Successful productions have included this lingering life, Mystical Abyss, Emmett Till, Sorya and Noh/Kyogen infused stagings of A Christmas Carol, Frankenstein, Antigone, and other classic Western works.
  • Since 1979, Yugen has toured locally and internationally, bringing these rare and beautiful theatrical art forms to audiences including schools across the Bay Area, venues large and small throughout the United States and abroad.
  • In 1991, Yugen found a home in San Francisco's Mission District, our beloved NOHspace.  This space grew into a popular venue for both Yugen productions and collaborations with hundreds of local artists and small performing arts organizations.

Our Present

                  

Theatre of Yugen has appointed a new Artistic Director, Tanroh Ishida, who brings extensive stage and film experience to the company, as well as a new artistic vision.

  • We've partnered with the San Francisco International Arts Festival to present The Genji State- an ambitious, immersive theatrical event which places audiences in the middle of a conflict between a totalitarian government and a rebel cause.  This cross-disciplinary collaboration will involve Miki Orihara (Prima Dancer for the Martha Graham company), internationally recognized music group JETSAM, and our local company members.
  • Mystical Abyss, our hit production from 2012, will tour to Denver, CO to be presented as part of an international arts symposium.  This will be the final performance for our founder, Yuriko Doi, before her well-earned retirement.

Our Future


We have so many exciting plans for the future that our largest challenge is deciding which projects to pursue. Our immediate goals include:

  • Forging strong connections with local start-up companies, individual artists and small non-profits to transform NOHspace into a Community Arts Center; a creative "hub" focused on bringing unity to this diverse and rapidly changing neighborhood. Programs to include Artist/Company Residencies,  , pop-ups, and much more!
  • Reinventing the Theatre of Yugen Mainstage; focusing on creating large-scale, immersive, & experimental theatrical experiences such as the upcoming Genji State, and an interactive popup restaurant/performance focusing on Japanese food culture planned for 2016/2017.
  • Developing education programs focused on bringing theatre arts to the underserved youth of our community locally and across the wider Bay Area.


How Else Can I Help?

If you're not able to contribute financially, there are still many ways to ensure the future of Japanese-infused theatre in San Francisco:

  • Share this campaign on social media, send an email, or tell a friend!
  • Join us for The Genji State at the SFIAF: May 28th-June 7th
  • Contact us for volunteer opportunities at NOHspace
  • Check out our list of in-kind donation needs

story:
I donated a kidney! 

Heroic you say?  More like fart-tastic... 

  • I'm Amanda Nicastro, actor, writer, all around funny gal.
  • I donated my kidney for my sister last summer!  This Spring I'm bringing my one-woman show about the best decision I ever made to the Orlando International Fringe Festival! 
  • I'm thrilled to be invited to perform - but the cost is on me and I'm going to need some help to make it happen.

This time YOU'RE the donor!

I know what it's like to make a major donation (boy do I ever...) Rest assured this money does good, is for good, and gets you something good, too!

  • The four thousand dollars goes solely towards production, advertising,  and traveling costs.  I'm putting in what I can but I'll still need help.
  • Friends from some major New York institutions are pitching in with gifts to reward your generosity.  From a night at the top comedy shows in Manhattan to an easy afternoon with Brooklyn Superheroes, you'll be in for some unique NYC treats for your generosity.
My story. Our cause.

There is a huge gap between the need for those waiting for life saving organs and the supply of those organs.

  •  My hope is that this show starts a conversation that will dispel the myths surrounding organ donation, increase awareness and increase the numbers of registered organ donors.
  • Our first run of the show at the New York Solocom Festival was a festival favorite.
  • I'll be remounting the show at the Peoples Improv Theater this Spring before heading to Orlando for the Fringe.  I'd love to see you there as I get ready for Florida!

Thank You.

The two most valuable things someone has are time and money.  I'm asking you to sacrifice both and I know that's a huge request.  I wouldn't ask if this show didn't mean the world to me.  And hopefully with your help, I'll change the world while making it laugh at the same time.  

...next summer, let's see if I try to get rid of part of my liver!

story:
Shantigar’s theatre barn burned in 2000, so workshops have been held in a 1700 square foot octagonal tent nestled in the woods. But now Shantigar's workshop tent is worn out. It's outrageously expensive to fix it, plus it costs lots each spring to put up the tent and each fall to take it down.

     Once and for all we need to put up permanent walls and a roof on the tent's frame and foundation.

     Two local carpenters, Chris and Rich, can build the walls and roof by hand with green materials. They estimate it will take $36,000. The design idea is Jean-Claude van Itallie's, the legendary playwright who founded Shantigar—which means Peaceful Home in Sanskrit—on his old farm. Shantigar is a haven of natural beauty in the remote hills of Western Massachusetts.

     For decades artists and meditators have retreated to Shantigar to contemplate, re-fuel, and take workshops in theatre, movement, writing, singing, and other creative forms. Artists have created works here and successfully launched them into opera, theatre, and literature. Writers, performers, teachers, psychotherapists, retirees, computer nerds, cooks, corporate execs, coaches, and others—have found new practices here to enrich and strengthen their lives and work in the world. Shantigar offers work-study to all who can't afford a full workshop fee. Rowe residents get a free workshop per year.

     Strengthen our community. Help us build. Put your name on the Shantigar donors list as builder, carpenter, artisan, planner, foreman, designer, architect, visionary, or benefactor.

     Shantigar is a non-profit 501(c)(3). All donations are tax deductible.


Jean-Claude teaching a workshop in the tent



Workshop in the tent taught by Emilie Conrad


"I think your campaign is a great idea. Why continue to throw money down a black hole, paying to have the tent put up and taken down year after year, struggling during workshops several times a day rolling up and taking down the sides; and feeling cold or hot so quickly.
I will be glad to support the campaign. I want to be the first to donate."

—Peter Meyer

            carpenter, artisan, planner, foreman, designer, architect, visionary, or benefactor.     Shantigar is a non-profit 501(c)(3). All donations are tax
    deductible.Jean-Claude teaching a workshop in the tentWorkshop in the tent taught by Emilie Conrad"I think your campaign is a great idea. Why
            continue to throw money down a black hole, paying to have the tent put up and taken down year after
            year, struggling during workshops
      
    
    several times a day rolling up and taking down the sides; and
    feeling cold or hot so quickly. 
    I will be glad to support the campaign. I want to be the
      first to donate."—Peter Meyer

story:
About Us and our Season

Help us get poor Jane out from under her paper bag and into the spotlight! Theatre BSMT has been connecting freshly graduated theatre artists to the professional theatre community for the past 8 years.

  • We have an exciting season planned with 3 productions at the Motel Theatre at Arts Commons
  • 2 of 3 productions are new works written by local Alberta playwrights
  • All 3 productions will have a professional mentor on board to guide the young emerging artists through the process

We are very proud of the success of our company in the past few seasons. In 2013, actress Heather Pattengale was nominated for Best Solo Performance at the Critter Awards for her performance in Badger by Andrew Torry. And, in 2014, playwright Steven Owad won Best New Script for his play The Basement Boys (which also received 3 other nominations for Best Supporting Actor, Best Actor and Best Director). We need your help to do it all again this year for a new round of emerging theatre artists.

What We Need

We have the following expenses to pay before we can even announce our season:

  • $600 for the rights to produce our first production
  • $2000 to pay for the rental space for all 3 productions
  • $1200 to pay for our rehearsal space for all 3 productions 
  • $1200 to pay for set and costumes for our first production
  • We will lose our space if we are not able to pay for our rentals within the next couple months
  • We have recently received several rejection letters from granting agencies and these are for grants that the society usually gets and has come to depend on
  • If we cannot raise the money that we need through this campaign we will not be able to move forward with the announcement of our 2015/2016 Season or be able to host our super fun Halloween Dance Party

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute but want to help? Not a problem! There are other ways that you can support our cause:

  • Tell your friends about our campaign. It's super easy with the Indiegogo share tools!
  • We are always looking for volunteers to help with our fundraising events and productions.  Contact us if you're interested. Any volunteers with ProServe are a real asset for our Halloween Dance Party
  • Thank you for considering our project and taking the time to read our story

story:
Do you believe in acceptance?  Do you believe in peaceful, positive change?  Do you believe in art fueled with purpose?  Do you believe in love?  

If you answered yes to any or all of those questions, this campaign is for YOU.  Become a Bench Believer today!  

OFFICIAL ANNOUNCEMENT 

Dayton Contemporary Dance Company (DCDC) officially joined this groundbreaking endeavor and will continue development of THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE!  A five week workshop with the world-renowned DCDC dancers will begin August 1, 2016.  We are also thrilled to announce DCDC will produce the world premiere of THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE in association with Titus Theatricals during the 2017-18 season.

Creator, Kiesha Lalama, was inspired and driven by the Confucius quote - "To put the world in order, we must first put the nation in order; to put the nation in order, we must first put the family in order; to put the family in order, we must first cultivate our personal life; we must first set our hearts right."  She worked endlessly to create a show that was meaningful and close to her own heart.  Kiesha evolved her original concept - from a small, surface based, family themed story to a deeply rooted, universal themed experience - with hopes to provide a familiar platform for uncomfortable conversations surrounding acceptance and universal love.  

After seven years of perseverance, and considering our current challenging times in society, now is the time for all of us to come together, allow for the beautiful message of this show to be delivered, and make this final journey a success.

What is THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE?

THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE is about a couple that serendipitously meet on an ordinary day at a seemingly ordinary wooden park bench. The couple falls in love, and we journey with them through marriage, parenthood, sibling rivalry, family dinners, and growing old. The Bench creates a universal photo album of memories that evoke tears and laughter. A live jazz fusion band accompanies the dancers and singers with a contemporary score that incorporates improvisational riffs throughout the inspiring and heartwarming story.

THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE was inspired by the iconic 

"Couple on Bench”.  Photo by – Michael Dickins 

How It All Started 


How To Become An Official Bench Believer 

THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE is at a crucial stage in development. After seven years of workshops, development productions, and hours of writing, we have finally reached the time to put at all together. With your generous donations, along with the support Dayton Contemporary Dance Company, we will be able to integrate the final concepts necessary to create the full theatrical experience we envision for THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE. Your donations will go directly to development cost for producing the five week workshop and world premiere.

To thank you for your generous donations, we have compiled some very exciting perks. These perks will be personalized and exclusive to donors only.  

History of THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE 

Point Park University – Pittsburgh, 2009 – Kiesha first conceived and choreographed THE BENCH as a full-length dance production for the Point Park University Conservatory Dance Company. THE BENCH received rave reviews and was honored to be named to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette’s "Best of Dance" Top Ten list in 2009.

Point Park University – Pittsburgh, 2010 – Back by popular demand, Pittsburgh Playhouse (the producing arm of PPU) stages THE BENCH for a second season with a sold-out run. This version of the production was re-worked to incorporated a storyteller and was named Pittsburgh Post-Gazette’s "Best of Dance" Top Ten list again in 2010.

Boise Dance Co-Oprotive Workshop – Boise, ID, Summer 2013 – A week-long workshop with Ballet Idaho, Idaho Dance Theatre, and Trey McIntyre Project dancers.  After incorporating original lyrics and adapting the book structure, this workshop allowed the authors to successfully explore new material.

Who Are We? The Creative Team Behind 

THE BENCH - JOURNEY INTO LOVE

  Kiesha Lalama - Creator & Choreographer 

Choreographer, Kiesha Lalama has created more than 50 works to date. Kiesha choreographed feature film, The Perks of Being a Wallflower, Sorority Row, hit television documentary Broadway or Bust (PBS) and newly released television series Outsiders (WGN). Theatrical credits include National High School Musical Theater Awards(Broadway), All Shook Up (North Shore Music Theatre), Jesus Christ Superstar (Kansas City Starlight Theatre), Into the Woods (Arsht Performing Arts Center) and Judge Jackie Justice, Ruthless! The Musical, and A Grand Night for Singing (Pittsburgh CLO).  Concert dance highlights include Shed (DCDC), Alegria (Giordano Dance Chicago), andTorque (August Wilson Center Dance Ensemble).

Lalama has created two full-length contemporary dance theater productions. The Bench received rave reviews and was named by the Pittsburgh Post Gazette’s “Best of Dance” Top Ten list in both 2009 and 2010. The Bench is currently under development with Titus Theatricals. HeartShakes for DCDC premiered in January 2015.  Kiesha is currently in the process of creating a third full-length.  

Lalama has choreographed works and events for diverse companies such as Ballet Arkansas, Dance Kaleidoscope, Eisenhower Dance Ensemble, Giordano Dance Chicago, Houston Metropolitan Dance Company, Jazz Dance World Congress, Missouri Contemporary Ballet, TEDx, the Youth American Grand Prix, Opening events for PNC Park, Pittsburgh CLO Guild Ball, WQED Elsie Awards, Richard Rogers Awards, G20 Summit, and Tech 50 Awards.

In 2009, Kiesha Lalama was named one of Dance Magazine’s “25 to Watch” and has been awarded a Leo’s Award for choreography at the Jazz Dance World Congress. The Youth American Grand Prix has named Lalama to the coveted “Top 12” for three different works and honored her with numerous Outstanding Choreography Awards.

As an educator, Kiesha serves as an Associate Professor in the Point Park University Dance Department and as the Education Director for the Pittsburgh CLO. She has taught master classes and workshops for Cirque Du Soleil, Houston Metropolitan Dance Company, Eisenhower Dance Ensemble, Oakland University, Carnegie Mellon University, Wright State University, Chautauqua Regional Youth Ballet, Booker T. Washington H.S. for the Performing and Visual Arts, NHSDF, and Dance Educators of America.

Kiesha Lalama graduated with an MFA in Interdisciplinary Arts from Goddard College and has her BA in Dance from Point Park University.  Kiesha is a proud member of SDC. 

  David Lalama - Composer 

David Lalama is a professor of music at Hofstra University and on the Manhattan School of Music faculty. He received his doctorate in music composition from New York University and is active as a clinician and performer throughout the United States.

Dr. Lalama has performed and recorded with Woody Herman, Buddy Rich, Mel Lewis, and numerous other jazz artists and continues actively to compose, arrange, and perform in the New York City metropolitan area. He is the director of the new Long Island Jazz Orchestra and has been featured in Hofstra University’s Frank Sinatra Conference as a performer and conductor along with numerous jazz education programs for Carnegie Hall (JazzEd) and Friends Of The Arts (JazzLink). His most recent CD as a member of the Joe Ascione Trio, Post No Bills, is on the Arbors Record Label. He has also been a featured guest on Marian McPartland’s Piano Jazz series on National Public Radio.

Along with performing, Dr. Lalama has also published big band jazz arrangements and articles about MIDI techniques and software. He has received composition grants from the Society of Composers, Meet-the- Composers, New York State Council of the Arts, and several American universities and has recently been cited in The Biographical Encyclopedia of Jazz, published by Oxford University Press in 1999. 

  Joel Mason - Lyricist 

Joel Mason was born in Orangeburg, South Carolina in 1960. After a tour of duty in the US Navy, spent in South East Asia, he returned home and studied acting at the University of South Carolina but didn’t finish his BFA until eight years later at the University of Rhode Island. Joel moved around the US for several years as an actor, dancer and theatrical fight choreographer before starting his graduate studies in Interdisciplinary Theater at Towson University in Baltimore, Maryland. He first came to Edinburgh in 2003 as a performer with Squonk Opera, met his wife while dancing Argentine tango and moved to Scotland permanently in 2004 where he has had success as a playwright and director. Joel lives in Dalgety Bay, Fife with his wife and son. He is the Artistic director of Liminal Theatre and the Author of Mary of the High Seas. 

Spread the Word

For us to raise our projected goal of $25,000 in 35 days, we need this campaign to go viral.  We understand that everyone is not in a position to donate, but you can still help.  

Please share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, email, phone, and the best of all word of mouth.  You can easily copy and paste web-address below to email campaign to all of your friends and family. http://igg.me/at/thebenchonstage

If you have any questions or comments about this campaign please reach out to us at info@thebenchonstage.com.  

The Small Print 

The Bench - Journey into Love is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for The Bench - Journey Into Love are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

THIS IS NOT AN OFFER TO SELL OR A SOLICITATION OF AN OFFER TO BUY UNITS IN ANY ENTITY.  OFFERS ARE MADE ONLY THROUGH OFFERING CIRCULARS. ALL FUNDS RAISED THROUGH THIS INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN ARE DEEMED TAX DEDUCTIBLE DONATIONS NOT INVESTMENTS.

story:
Burlesque From the Margins ROADSHOW project:

Help us jumpstart the first and only Burlesque from the Margins ROADSHOW! Juicy D Light and IL Nocturnal of Oakland, CA team-up to bring the West Coast a brilliant cast of black, brown, queer, and fat artists to the burlesque spotlight! Hitting the road from The Bay to Seattle, this Tour of tantalizing Teases show their audiences what Fierce Empowerment and SeXxXy Solidarity looks like!

Why do we need your money??

  • Gas!  We got 5 artists + all their glittery props ready to hit the road!
  • Safe Sleeping Spaces!  As marginalized people, we need SAFER places to sleep than your average couch-surfer.  We hope to cut costs with host homes and friends' cozy homes, but would feel A LOT BETTER about hitting them country roads with some extra funds for motels if needed!
  • Venue costs: Some venues charge producers and we want EVERYONE to see this fierce line-up!
  • YOU HATE OPPRESSION AND EXPLOITATION!!  As marginalized people, our art cannot be free.  DISCONTINUE legacies of exploitation of people of color, queers and body-unique artists by ensuring we make more than we spend!

The Impact

  • Another step away from the white, straight, thin, unattainable image of beauty!
  • Young marginalized people see us in all our power on stage and believe they can do it too!
  • Who doesn't love a hot and fun burlesque show?!!  We bring the Bay's social justice shimmey magic to Sacramento, Ashland, Eugene, Portland, Olympia and Seattle!

Risks & Challenges

  • Booking and travel has its risks and challenges!  With your help, we will be able to tackle anything that gets in our way.  
  • We will get oil changes, tires rotated and all possible car challenges addressed BEFORE we leave!  
  • We are already in touch with venues in each of the cities above: All excited to host our project with open arms with love and justice!  Our networks extend throughout the burlesque and stripper commUnity and we are confident in our ability to use our communication skills with hosts to adjust our plans if challenges arise. 

Other Ways You Can Help... We can use any of the following service donations:

  • Photagraphy
  • Graphic Designs
  • Costume Designers
  • Share this crowd funding with your networks!

THANK YOU for your interest in supporting this grassroots project! <3 iL and Juicy

story:
The Troupe

Founded in 2007 by Artistic Director and Choreographer Kate Thomas, Ballet Neo celebrates the beauty of classical ballet while exploring the discipline through its neoclassical repertory. 

With your support we can 

  • Support for our dancers - talented artists who work very hard for very little  rehearsal and performance salaries 
  • Additional staff - Company Manager/Rehearsal Director salary
  • Create new ballets- studio space and artistic fees
  • Produce a 2016 New York City season - theater rent, light and stage design, press representative 
  • Guest artists to attract a larger audience
  • New costumes for existing repertory works

Our $10,000 goal

  • Offers necessary funds for dancer and artistic salaries
  • Additional support must come from grants, ticket sales and donations 

Ballet Neo has a large contemporary ballet repertory and beautifully trained dancers. All that is needed to broaden our audience is the funding.  We hope to find the necessary support through donations from  corporate and government grants, fellowships and from  individual arts advocates through campaigns such as this. 

Please support us in our goal to:

  • Host a Fall/Winter 2015 Gala Fundraiser at a large venue
  • Produce a full Spring 2016 Performance Season
  • Support artistic salaries 
  • Earmark your donation as you wish- dancers wages, new work, costumes, etc.

Growth and its challenge

  • Reaching a  larger audience requires additional press, venue, and personnel development
  • New and selected repertory requires finances for the additional rehearsal time 
  • Ballet Neo's challenging repertory requires dancers of the highest quality 
    • Help keep us together. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Offer your skills to Ballet Neo

  • Join our Benefit Committee 
  • Ask about becoming a Board Member
  • Spread the word about our plans through your contacts

The Troupe
Founded in 2007 by Artistic Director and Choreographer Kate Thomas, Ballet Neo celebrates the beauty of classical ballet while exploring the discipline through its neoclassical repertory. 
With your support we can 


Support for our dancers - talented artists who work very hard for very little  rehearsal and performance salaries 
Additional staff - Company Manager/Rehearsal Director salary
Create new ballets- studio space and artistic fees
Produce a 2016 New York City season - theater rent, light and stage design, press representative 
Guest artists to attract a larger audience
New costumes for existing repertory works

story:
THEATRE N16...

Theatre N16 was founded in May this year as a hub for the theatre makers of tomorrow to gather in Stoke Newington and produce new exciting work without any of the high overheads normally associated with theatre.

The opening season featured over one hundred actors, playwrights, directors and all round creatives. All of the in house shows were produced with all the artitsts receiving a fee and all companies paid no hire costs to the theatre itself, taking half of the box office receipts. 

Theatre N16 are sad to announce they are moving from N16 but ecstatic to be going for a full makeover as they move to SW12, to the Bedford pub in Balham.

This move is going to cost the company a few thousand pounds to get everything up and running again.

Theatre N16 receive no funding, no grants and no backing and have so far survived on small donations from friends and family, box office tickets and the (small) pocket of founder Jamie Eastlake.

To continue as a hub for the theatre makers of the future they desperately need the help of those who support the arts and support their vision.




What We Need 


  • New lighting equipment. During our opening season all of our lighting was rented, our aim is to buy everything for our reopening in September to keep long term costs down.
  • Rent. We are delighted to be moving to the Bedford and need the funds to help us pay for such a glorious space. 
  • Staffing. Running a theatre is tough and we need a small pot to start with to help build a wage structure for the future. 

The Impact

This money will help the new chapter of the Theatre to get off to the best possible start. We are here for the long haul and want to be the place to turn to in troubled times. A place to help playwrights, actors, directors, designers, technicians, literally all theatre people. Our new space will become a hub to give free space hire to companies and opportunities for all artists. 





Other Ways You Can Help

If you haven't got any pennies please feel free to share our campaign on social media. Feel free to follow us on twitter, like us on facebook and tell people about the future of our theatre. Thankyou. 


You can read more about exactly who we are in this article: 

http://www.themnr.com/blog/2015/6/16/theatre-n1...

story:
We are the creators of the Monologando Contando Ando festival, with which we seek to open spaces for the Latino community in New York City, in addition to raising funds for the artistic work of our theater company.
For seven years we are working on art and culture, with their support we will raise funds to hold Festival Monologando Contando Ando.
The people who help us to realize this dream, will have their names written in our programs as Angeles.
With your contribution will make a culture open to the entire Latino community in New York.
We need 3,500 dollars to assume in some the expenses that the event Monologando Contando Ando requires.
Cost of theater and other.
Art with a purpose, help! Is our motto,
God bless you.
 

 

 

Somos los creadores del festival de Monólogos  Monologando Contando Ando, con el cual buscamos  abrir espacios para la comunidad Latina en la ciudad de New York, además reunir fondos para el trabajo artistico de nuestra compañia teatral.

Desde hace siete años estamos trabajando el arte y la cultura, con su apoyo recolectaremos fondos para realizar Festival Monologando Contando  Ando.

Las personas que nos ayude a realizar este sueño, tendran su nombres escritos en nuestro programas como Angeles.

Con tu aporte hara una cultura abierta a toda la comunidad Latina en New York. 

Necesitamos 3,500 dolares para asumir en algo los gastos que el evento Monologando  Contando Ando requiere.

Costo del teatro y predication. 

El arte con un propósito, ayudar! es nuestro lema,

Dios lo bendiga.

story:
About The Musical

CITY SQUARE is a new musical written and produced by Marvin Thompson Jr.  Directed by Elizabeth Jones, CITY SQUARE tells the story of 5 strangers who gather  to save a community landmark from demolition.  While everyone is in favor of progress, who will preserve the past?  Personalities, situations and feelings all intersect in CITY SQUARE.

WIth music and lyrics by Marvin Thompson Jr., and choreography by Jessica Thomas, CITY SQUARE promises to excite audiences of all ages when it premieres in April, 2015.

Cast members Ben Will, Bryce Pinchum, Daron Van Buren, Zachary James Morgan , Jasmine Louise and Director Elizabeth Jones.

Run Dates

April 24th @ 7:30p, April 25th @ 7:30p, April 26th @ 3p

1515 Broadway Theatre
1515 Broadway St., Detroit MI 48226

We Need Your Help

Reaching our goal of $4,000 will allow us to bring CITY SQUARE to the stage in the best possible way.  We've put in our personal finances and called in a few favors from friends; along with that, your donation will go towards:

  • Rehearsal space
  • Theatre rental
  • Lighting
  • Set design
  • Printing & graphic design
  • Cast/crew honorariums
  • Legal fees
  • Videography & photography
  • Free tickets for local youth and community groups
As our thanks to you for your contribution to our project, we're offering some great perks and rewards!  Check out what we're offering over to your right >>>>>>>>>>> No donation is too small, and every penny will go a long way in making CITY SQUARE a great production.  

Director Elizabeth Jones, Production Assistant John Crutchfield, Zachary James Morgan, Bryce Pinchum & Dorothy Nelson.

The Difference You'll Make

Your donation will make a difference in the following ways:

  • Helping independent writers, directors, actors & actresses bring their talents to the stage.
  • Exposing communities to new artistic projects.
  • Providing an opportunity for local youth to experience a live theatre production. 

Zachary James Morgan, Jasmine Louise, Dorothy Nelson, Bryce Pinchum & Daron Van Buren.

Other Ways To Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution, no worries-you can still help!  

  • Follow us on social media; "liking" our posts, sending tweets, reposting pictures and video clips.
  • Telling your friends and family about our project.
  • Referring us to any resources that may be able to assist us in the production.

Thanks

We appreciate you taking time to view our page, and we look forward to seeing you during the run of CITY SQUARE!

story:
My name is Soumaila Diara. Before launching this campaign I have been a freelance writer in Mali for 8 years. In addition to writing climate-related news for Thomson Reuters Foundation, some of my stories have been published by international news organizations, including USA Today and the Guardian.

On his first travel in West Africa in the 18th century, Mungo Park wrote a book that removes. The British Geographic Society explorer failed to find the source of unknown River Niger, but discovered slavery roads and a crusade, hostile mindset from some tribes.

This ballet will be a multicultural enterprise gathering dancers from Africa and the West. It will be performed with dance and music from different cultural backgrounds. 

The ballet which will be an adaptation of Park’s book can be a major play reaching international audience. The mixture of African and Welsh musical traditions can bring a particular sense to the dancers’ performance.

We need at least US dollar 100 000 for the project development. Part of this money will be used to finance the trip of 2 or 3 Westerns artists who will have to work on the show preparation with Malian artists. Your contribution is needed for that and for the transportation of all the ballet crew on tour in US and Europe.

With your help I can make a success of this project, which is based on a history shared by three continents. It is a matter of cultural dialogue in a world full of so many grieves. Thus, the show makes a clear definition of Africans’ responsibility in slavery trade, instead of insisting on victimization.

Any project has risks that can lead to failure. And the real risk of failure here is the lack of money, which can be avoided by the contributors. Your help can make the difference. Money isn’t the only way to help us. You can spread the word, using Indiegogo tools of communication.

story:
A little about me (the director of "IamI"):

I am an actor, writer, musician, and  director currently working towards his MFA at California Institute of the Arts. I have also received my B.A. in Creative Writing from CUNY:City. 
I am committed to making work that voices the complexities of his generation, a generation which must adapt to a gratuitous influx of information. I am also committed to illuminating the sameness of the human spirit, a sameness that is being brought to light by the anonymity of cyberspace.

How do I pronounce "IamI"?

(Eye-um-eye)

What is "IamI" about anyway?

"IamI" is a play about the marvel of being alive. It takes place in a realm known as the Eversphere. In this realm, beings acquire immortality. The Eversphere becomes a place where individuals are able to reflect on what it means to live if they are unable to die.  

"IamI" includes completely original content, ranging from its originally-composed, elaborate musical underscore to its highly-developed visual aesthetic.

Now that that's out of the way, what will my money go to?

 Your money will go to making it possible for "IamI" to be performed at both the Hollywood and Edinburgh Fringe Festivals.

I am asking for funds to cover the new materials that will have to be bought in order to restructure "IamI" for a smaller venue, as well as miscellaneous missing materials (e.g. costumes and a mobile set), equipment rentals, venue rental fees, and transportation of goods within the L.A. county and abroad.

Any additional funds that are acquired will be put towards future projects of the Alternative Art Styles producing arm.

Wait, what is Hollywood Fringe and Edinburgh Fringe again?

Edinburgh Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world, based in Edinburgh, Scotland.

Hollywood Fringe is a festival for the performing arts, based in Los Angeles, CA. It is an open-access, community driven event that celebrates the freedom of expression without a curative barrier.

 Ok, but why does Alternative Art Styles need my help producing "IamI"?

"IamI" was first performed in an academic setting, CalArts' Modular Theater, which allowed me and my team free access to a venue and equipment that would have normally cost us thousands of dollars. Even so, this larger-scale production of "IamI" cost $7000+ . Many of the materials that were bought for the greater product of "IamI" were destroyed after the production came to a close. There were not sufficient enough funds to keep everything in storage.

"IamI" has been accepted into both Hollywood Fringe and Edinburgh Fringe, but will be severely stifled if it does not receive adequate funding.

Why is "IamI" important to contribute to?

"IamI" seeks to express latent energies in all of us that occur when we encounter a life that has come to an end. Your contribution will make it so this play can be performed around the world and possibly help onlookers release some of those latent energies within themselves. You're contribution will go towards helping people move on and see death in a new light.
Here is a video that may highlight our aims more specifically: https://vimeo.com/124593956

Risks and challenges

As far as the project goes, my actors, my design team, and I are prepared to execute "IamI" to the best of our ability no matter the circumstance. The greatest challenge we have faced in this process is finding one another. Since we have already conquered this hurdle, all that is needed is passion, of which we have copious amounts. Where there is a will there is a way. We have the will and the training, help us pave the way.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute sharing is always the most effective alternative!

story:
[French translation at the end]

To those who are reading this – my name is Vernice Miller, I am the artistic director of A Laboratory for Actor Training Experimental Theatre Company (ALAT) based in Brooklyn, NY. I’m reaching out to you because I believe that now, more than ever, our communities can benefit immensely from the power of theater and social change.

An international group of artists under the direction of ALAT’s literary director, Seth Baumrin, have joined forces to create an exciting new performance steeped in ALAT's mission of creating dynamic theatre that is socially relevant and theatrically engaging,called Port d'Alger 1962 – about how young people find joy even when surrounded by war.

Over the last decade Baumrin’s work took on a powerful dynamic as he developed a methodology called Subpoetics that gave rise to Port d'Alger 1962. Taking inspiration from his most recent exploration in Paris, we are now working towards concretizing this international group to continue refining and presenting Port d’Alger 1962 in Vienna this October -- 26-30. With a company that is comprised of artists from Africa, the Balkans, India, Persia, Western Europe, and the United States, our aim is to use the transcultural, multilingual composition of our group to make theatre a weapon to fight ethnic stereotypes resulting from xenophobia. The problem is, these international artists can’t pull this off on their own in a timely manner.

This is where your support is crucial.

Since this is a multi-ethnic, multi-national group that sometimes goes off the map (in Kosovo the work was done in secret; one member of the Paris team was imprisoned in Tehran for doing experimental theatre), our governmental funding opportunities are limited. Our 10 member team is looking for support from those who care about art and social justice, as well as recognize the power theater has in creating social change. Your support for shared housing, transportation, and theatre rental costs in Vienna at 500 euros for each member amounting to 5000 Euros (about 5500 USD),can help us fulfill our dream tocreate collaborations that challenge stereotypes that divide our communities, and instead provide a stimulating kaleidoscope of narratives that draw us closer together.

I hope you find this project worthy of support. Any sized contribution from $5 to $500 will be immensely appreciated.

For more info about the performance, read on:

Port d'Alger 1962, is a performance piece that was built on the principles of Subpoetics, which is a methodology developed by Baumrin that relies on cubist concepts of subjectless art going back to the early 20th century. Subpoetics create images of beauty and the grotesque, stimulating audiences on a visceral level regardless of culture or ethnicity. 

Here’s how you can find out more:

https://www.facebook.com/subpoetics?ref=profile

Here’s who in the group:

Subpoetics team

Seth Baumrin is a professor of theatre at John Jay College of Criminal Justice/City University of  New York and the author of “The Les Kurbas Legacy in 21st Century Ukrainian Performance”; “Performances at a Symposium ‘Theatre as a Laboratory for Community Interaction’ at Odin Teatret”; “Ketmanship in Opole; Jerzy Grotowski and the Price of Free Expression”; “Anarcho-Radical Roots; Eugenio Barba’s Early Experimental Theatre as Intervention.” Baumrin has also directed over sixty productions: like Offenbach’s Tales of Hoffman, Milhaud’s Medée; Lorca’s As Five Years Pass; Calderon’s Life is a Dream; and McCullers’s The Member of the Wedding.

Madeleine Bongard co-develops and participates in projects that question occidental social themes like sexuality, maternity, and neo-nomadism. She performs in many countries throughout Europe. She believes in theatre as a process of deepening connections and understanding between people.

Alireza Daryanavard is an actor/director originally from Iran whose works were seen in the Bushehr Theatre Festival, Shiraz Theatre Festival, Tehran Theatre Festival, Bushehr Underground Theatre Festival, Persian Gulf Theatre Festival in Tehran, and now in Vienna, where Alireza has been awarded political asylum, he performs in the Museums Quartier and Brunnenpassage.

Eva Goldenberg (coordinator of Paris Subpoetics workshop) says “a significant part of my artistic path was my training with Zygmunt Molik (who was an actor in Grotowski’s original Theatre Laboratory). It was the possibility to experiment deeply with my own living instrument through vocal and physical channels. It all led me to contemporary dance which again requires that unavoidable necessity of being present.”

Fatma Guetary is a Tunisian actress who lives in Paris. She says “I have done all my dramatic training in France. My main artistic experiences are: Training with Jack Waltzer, a lifetime member of the Actors Studio; acting in Tsunami a play about the 2011 Tunisian Revolution, by Fadhel Jaïbi at Théâtre Le Mondial in Tunis; andLes Patients by Chloé Donne at Théâtre du Nord Ouest in Paris."

David Matthews is an illustrator and animator whose work has been a driving force in Vienna’s BrunnenpassageCommunity Art projects. David says, “I'm from Delhi, studied in Falmouth, and now work out of Vienna in comics, book design, and animation.” 

Anne Mourier, completed her acting studies in L'école du Théâtre National de Chaillot, and has worked with many theatre companies in Paris and Berlin such as Les Affranchis, Kofradia Theatre, Theatre Forum Kreuzberg, and L'Escalier4. This year she directed her first short film Je suis comme je suis.

Sylvain Paolini, an actor and theatre educator, trained at l’école Jacques Lecoq in Paris, belongs to the Theatre du Rabot, a Burgundian company with which he creates street theatre and contemporary performance. In 2014, he was among the founders of the festival "Rabotage!" Paolini also belongs to the Paris collective L'Escalier4.

Neja Tomšič is a visual and performing artist and the director of MoTA - Museum of Transitory Art in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Neja was also a performer in the original Skrip Orkestra which was described by its director Jelena Rusjan as “a theatrical exploration of the obscure forces of violence, personal responsibility, and lost childhoods through the variegated aesthetics of kitsch-noir.” 

Anne Wiederhold, Co-founder and artistic director of Brunnenpassage Vienna is an actress and has worked for many international productions, especially in experimental physical theatre. Anne, originally from Germany, has lived in Vienna for over 10 years. She is author of the book: Art Practices in the Migration Society - Transcultural Strategies in Action at Brunnenpassage in Vienna, 2015.


________

Pour ceux qui lisent ceci, je suis Vernice Miller, le directeur artistique du « Laboratory for Actor Training Expérimental Theater Compagny » (ALAT), à Brooklyn, NY. En ces temps mouvementés, je pense que, maintenant plus que jamais, nous avons un besoin immense de la force du théâtre et de changement social.

Un groupe d’artiste international, sous la direction de Seth Baumrin (directeur littéraire à l’ALAT), s’est réuni pour créer une performance, « Port d’Alger 1962 », ou comment les jeunes peuvent trouver la joie même en temps de guerre. Cette performance s’inscrit dans la mission de l’ALAT de créer un théâtre dynamique, engagé et social.

Durant ces dernières années, le travail de Seth Baumrin a pris une tournure puissante et dynamique, en développant une méthodologie appelé « Subpoetic »; donnant naissance à « Port d’Alger 1962 ». Suite à son travail d’exploration le plus récent, à Paris, nous travaillons maintenant à la concrétisation de ce projet international et, au développement et à la présentation « Port d’Alger 1962 » àVienne du 26 au 30 octobre. Notre compagnie est un groupe multi-ethnique, venant du monde entier: le Maghreb, l’Inde, les Balkans, l’Europe occidentale, la Perse, et les Etats Unis. Notre objectif est de mettre à profit la mixité de nos cultures et de nos langues pour s’élever contre les stéréotypes et les conflits quidécoulent du racisme. Le problème, est que ces artistes ne peuvent pas le faire seul.

C’est pourquoi votre soutien est crucial.

Comme c’est un groupe multi-ethnique et international qui parfois sort des sentiers battus (au Kosovo nous avons du travailler en secret; un de nos collaborateur à été emprisonné à Téhéran pour avoir travailler sur du théâtre expérimental), nos chances de recevoir des subventions gouvernementales sont limitées. Notre équipe a besoin du soutien de ceux qui ce soucient de la justice sociale et de l’art et,voient le théâtre comme un moyen de créer un changement social. Votre participation pour le logement, le transport et la location du théâtre à Vienne; c’est à dire 500€ par personne et donc un total de 5000€ (ou environ 5500$), peut nous aider à poursuivre notre rêve de créer une collaboration qui questionne les stéréotypes qui nous divisent en tant que communauté et, qui met en lumière un kaléidoscope d’histoires qui nous rapproche les uns des autres. J’espère que vous trouvez notre projet digne de votre soutien. Quelque soit le montant de la participation 5 $ ou 500 $, nous vous serons infiniment reconnaissants.

Pour plus d’informations sur la performance:

« Subpoetics » est une méthode de travail développé par Seth Baumrin, basée sur les concepts cubistes et de l’art abstrait du début du 20ème siècle. Le but est de créer des histoires accessibles à un public cosmopolite. En travaillant sur le materiel intérieur de l’acteur, en utilisant la façon dont le corps danse, et l’exploration des langues, nous créons aussi bien des images de beauté que grotesques; subpoetics touche l’audience à un niveau inconscient, au delà des barrières culturelles et ethniques

.

https://www.facebook.com/subpoetics?ref=profile
story_txt:
[French translation at the end]To
those who are reading this – my name is Vernice Miller, I am the artistic
director of A Laboratory for Actor Training Experimental Theatre
Company (ALAT) based in Brooklyn, NY. I’m reaching out to you because
I believe that now, more than ever, our communities can benefit immensely from
the power of theater and social change. 
An international
group of artists under the direction of ALAT’s literary director, Seth
Baumrin, have joined forces to create an exciting new performance steeped in ALAT's mission of creating dynamic theatre
that is socially relevant and theatrically engaging,called Port
d'Alger 1962 – about how young people find joy even when surrounded by war.

Over
the last decade Baumrin’s work took on a powerful dynamic as he developed a
methodology called Subpoetics that gave rise to Port d'Alger 1962.
Taking inspiration from his most recent exploration in Paris, we are now
working towards concretizing this international group to continue refining and
presenting Port d’Alger 1962 in Vienna this October --
26-30. With a company that is comprised of artists from Africa, the
Balkans, India, Persia, Western Europe, and the United States, our aim is to use
the transcultural, multilingual composition of our group to make
theatre a weapon to fight ethnic stereotypes resulting from xenophobia. The
problem is, these international artists can’t pull this off on their own in a
timely manner.
This
is where your support is crucial.
Since
this is a multi-ethnic, multi-national group that sometimes goes off the map
(in Kosovo the work was done in secret; one member of the Paris team was
imprisoned in Tehran for doing experimental theatre), our governmental
funding opportunities are limited. Our 10 member team is looking
for support from those who care about art and social justice, as well as
recognize the power theater has in creating social change. Your support for
shared housing, transportation, and theatre rental costs in Vienna at 500 euros
for each member amounting to 5000 Euros (about 5500 USD),can help us fulfill our
dream tocreate collaborations that challenge stereotypes
that divide our communities, and instead provide a stimulating kaleidoscope of narratives
that draw us closer together.
I
hope you find this project worthy of support. Any sized contribution from $5 to
$500 will be immensely appreciated.
For
more info about the performance, read on:

Port
d'Alger 1962,
is a performance piece that was built on the principles of Subpoetics, which
is a methodology developed by Baumrin that relies on cubist concepts of
subjectless art going back to the early 20th century. Subpoetics create
images of beauty and the grotesque, stimulating audiences on a visceral level
regardless of culture or ethnicity. 
Here’s how you can find out more: 
https://www.facebook.com/subpoetics?ref=profile
Here’s who in the group:

Subpoetics team
Seth Baumrin is
a professor of theatre at John Jay College of Criminal Justice/City University
of  New York and the author of “The Les
Kurbas Legacy in 21st Century Ukrainian Performance”; “Performances at a Symposium ‘Theatre as a Laboratory for
Community Interaction’ at Odin Teatret”; “Ketmanship in Opole; Jerzy
Grotowski and the Price of Free Expression”; “Anarcho-Radical Roots; Eugenio
Barba’s Early Experimental Theatre as Intervention.” Baumrin has also directed
over sixty productions: like Offenbach’s Tales
of Hoffman, Milhaud’s Medée; Lorca’s As Five Years Pass;
Calderon’s Life is a Dream; and McCullers’s The Member of the Wedding.
Madeleine Bongard co-develops and participates in projects that question
occidental social themes like sexuality, maternity, and neo-nomadism. She
performs in many countries throughout Europe. She believes in theatre as a
process of deepening connections and understanding between people.
Alireza
Daryanavard is an actor/director
originally from Iran whose works were seen in the Bushehr Theatre
Festival, Shiraz Theatre Festival, Tehran Theatre Festival, Bushehr Underground Theatre Festival, Persian Gulf Theatre Festival in
Tehran, and now in Vienna, where Alireza has been awarded political asylum, he
performs in the Museums Quartier and Brunnenpassage.
Eva
Goldenberg (coordinator of Paris Subpoetics workshop) says “a significant part of my artistic path was my training with Zygmunt Molik
(who was an actor in Grotowski’s original Theatre Laboratory). It was the
possibility to experiment deeply with my own living instrument through vocal
and physical channels. It all led me to contemporary dance which again requires
that unavoidable necessity of being present.”
Fatma Guetary
is a Tunisian actress who lives in Paris. She says “I have done all my dramatic
training in France. My main artistic experiences are: Training with Jack Waltzer, a lifetime
member of the Actors Studio; acting in Tsunami
a play about the 2011 Tunisian Revolution, by Fadhel Jaïbi at Théâtre Le Mondial in Tunis; andLes Patients by Chloé Donne at Théâtre du Nord
Ouest in
Paris."
David
Matthews is an illustrator and animator whose work has been a driving force in
Vienna’s BrunnenpassageCommunity Art projects. David says, “I'm from Delhi, studied in Falmouth, and now work out of Vienna
in comics, book design, and animation.” 
Anne Mourier, completed her acting studies in L'école du Théâtre National
de Chaillot, and has worked with many theatre companies in Paris and Berlin
such as Les Affranchis, Kofradia Theatre, Theatre Forum Kreuzberg, and
L'Escalier4. This year she directed her first short film Je suis comme je suis.
Sylvain
Paolini, an actor and theatre educator, trained at l’école Jacques Lecoq in
Paris, belongs to the Theatre du Rabot, a Burgundian company with which he
creates street theatre and contemporary performance. In 2014, he was among the
founders of the festival "Rabotage!" Paolini also belongs to the
Paris collective L'Escalier4.
Neja Tomšič is
a visual and performing artist and the director of MoTA - Museum of Transitory
Art in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Neja was also a performer in the original Skrip
Orkestra which was described by its director Jelena Rusjan as “a theatrical
exploration of the obscure forces of violence, personal responsibility, and
lost childhoods through the variegated aesthetics of kitsch-noir.”  
Anne
Wiederhold, Co-founder and artistic director of
Brunnenpassage Vienna is an actress and has worked for many international
productions, especially in experimental physical theatre. Anne, originally from Germany, has
lived in Vienna for over 10 years. She is author
of the book: Art Practices in the Migration Society
- Transcultural Strategies in Action at Brunnenpassage in
Vienna, 2015.________
Pour ceux qui lisent

mouvementés, je pense que, maintenant plus que jamais, nous avons un besoin

story:
Summary

Part musical. Part rock concert. Fully enthralling. This groundbreaking Obie-winning Off-Broadway smash also won multiple awards for its hit film adaptation. It tells the story of "internationally ignored song stylist" Hedwig Schmidt, a fourth-wall smashing East German rock 'n' roll goddess who also happens to be the victim of a botched sex-change operation, which has left her with just "an angry inch." This hilarious and unexpectedly touching story is dazzlingly performed by Hedwig in the form of a rock gig/stand-up comedy routine backed by the hard-rocking band "The Angry Inch." Using songs and monologues, Hedwig tells her story, a transcontinental search for "The Origin of Love" and her other half. It's a funny, rocking ride, and ultimately inspiring to anyone who has felt life gave them an inch when they deserved a mile.

What We Need & What You Get

Our team has made all of the necessary arrangements: the show has a cast and production crew, the rehearsal and performance space has been secured, and the rights and royalties have been approved. All that's missing is the funding - that's where you come in!

The show is currently scheduled to perform three times May 22-24, 2015 at the Ethnic Cultural Theater in Seattle, WA.

Reaching our fundraising goal of $3,000 would cover our entire budget and allow us to price our tickets with a Pay What You Can model. This would make Hedwig and her story accessible to everyone in our community regardless of income level.

Great pains have been taken to make sure that we are able to put on an excellent show while still being cost-effective. Here is a general breakdown of how the money from this fundraiser would be spent:

  • $1350 - Space rental
  • $800 - Performance rights/royalties & script rental
  • $700 - Production budget (sets, costumes, etc.)
  • $150 - Marketing
  • TOTAL: $3000
In exchange for giving to our campaign, you'll get a wide variety of perks! All of our donation levels come with tax deductibility and karma points. Depending on how much you give, you'll also receive:

  • Your name on our website and show programs
  • Signed posters
  • Tickets to a secret pre-show warmup gig
  • Tickets to the show in the best seats
  • Post-show drinks with the cast
  • A guaranteed interaction with Hedwig during the show
All donations are tax-deductible, and we need your address and contact information in order to make this happen. If you want your donation to be tax-deductible, please send us your address by selecting one of the donation levels and filling out the information, or send us an email at info@boldprint.org to make sure we obtain the necessary information. 

Bold Print Theatre Company has enough funds in the bank to do the show if this campaign raises $2,000. Because of this, it is possible that we will not receive enough funding to do the show. If that is the case, we will donate half of the funds to the Transgender Law Center, and the other half will go to Bold Print Theatre Company's operations in order to make our next fundraising campaign a little easier. Either way, your donations will be tax-deductible guaranteed!

The Impact

Using the show's fusion of musical theatre and rock concert, we plan to put deliver an interpretation of this classic show that promotes and empowers folks in the trans* community. Trans* people are underrepresented in popular forms of artistic expression; when they are, harmful stereotypes are often used to entertain at the expense of a marginalized group of people. This particular production of Hedwig and the Angry Inch aims to deliver theatre that is both captivating and responsible to the community it represents.

Specifically, we plan to do this by reaching out to members of the trans* community both on campus and in the general Seattle area for dramaturgical help in order to achieve the most culturally respectful version of this show we can create. We also plan to donate 20% of all ticket sales to the Transgender Law Center, an incredible organization dedicated to furthering the interests of trans* people in the United States.

Who We Are

Hedwig and the Angry Inch is produced by Bold Print Theatre Company. BPTC's mission is "to support and provide creative space for emerging young local theatre artists. We aim to present theatre that is dynamic, visceral, and engaging to our community. We work towards artistically and financially empowering the individuals we serve."

Bold Print Theatre Company's 2015 Seattle Company includes: Michael Joseph Hanley, Seton FitzMacken, Zane Suarez, Daniel Ericksen, Andrew Gryniewicz, Marty Sisk, Nathan Wornian, Alyssa Karounos, Kellyn Traenkenschuh, Megan Brewer, Thomas Allen, Simon Tran, Rachel Perlot, Larkin Hubrig, Rhoya Selden, Jack Conger, Colton Sullivan, and Erica Ream.

The creative team for Hedwig and the Angry Inch is as follows:

CAST

  • Hedwig - Michael Joseph Hanley*
  • Yitzhak - Adele Lim
BAND

  • Guitar - Jack Dearth
  • Bass - Stephen Bailey
  • Keyboard/Bandleader - Vasilis Konstantinides
  • Drums - Jake Cunningham

PRODUCTION TEAM

  • Director - Rachel Perlot*
  • Music Director - Jack Conger*
  • Choreographer - Kellyn Traenkenschuh*
  • Stage Manager - Larkin Hubrig*
  • Scenic Designer - He Yu
  • Costume Designer - Rhoya Selden*
  • Hair & Makeup Designer - Maya Head-Corliss
  • Sound Design/Live Sound - Jake Israel
  • Props Master - Zane Suarez*
  • Assistant Stage Manager - August Franzen
  • Graphic Design - Emma Broback
(* indicates a member of Bold Print Theatre Company)

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is able to make a financial contribution to this campaign. If you are one of these individuals, no worries at all! There are other ways you can help us out that don't involve money. For example, you can:

  • Share this campaign using social media!
  • Email info@boldprint.org to find out how to volunteer your time and talent to help our organization!
  • Talk to your friends about the show and this campaign!
----------------------------------------
Bold Print Theatre Company is powered by Shunpike.

story:
Overview


Hi. I'm Ralph Tufo, the playwright and composer for the musical, The Katrina Roadhouse. While working on several rebuilding projects after Hurricane Katrina, I heard the real-life stories of the survivors and the obstacles they had to face in rebuilding their lives and their communities.  I was extremely impressed with their resilience and determination.  I decided that these personal stories needed to be told. As a musician who's played Cajun and Zydeco music for the past 30 years, I thought what better way to relate these personal experiences and struggles than in a musical incorporating the culture of New Orleans and its road to recovery.

The debut performances will commemorate the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina and will  serve as a fundraiser for Common Ground Relief which for the past ten years has provided New Orleans residents with assistance in rebuilding, advocacy, and environmental improvements. Admission to the performances is free while contributions will be duly accepted for commongroundrelief.org.

What We Need

Contributions  will help to cover the necessary  production costs:

  • stipends for director, actors, band, and stage crew
  • audio/visual rentals and DVD duplication
  • donation for venue use
  • marketing/advertising/printing
  • props, costumes, and set design
  • miscellaneous costs
Perks to Contributors
  • A $20 contribution will give you an autographed Katrina Roadhouse postcard and a button.

  • A $50 contribution will give you the above plus a limited edition baseball cap with the play's logo.

  •  A $100 contribution will give you the above plus the studio CD recording of the songs in the play performed by the Squeeze Box Stompers ( 15 songs).


  • A $200 contribution will give you the above plus a special patron listing in the program book and a personal invitation to the cast and crew party on 9/13 in Winthrop, MA. A Bon Temps Rouler party will be hosted by the Squeezebox Stompers. There will be plenty of Cajun/Zydeco music and dancing.


How Your Contribution Will Make A Difference

  • Your contribution will enable us to put on this production and raise funds for Common Ground Relief.
  • With a successful production, we hope that in the future, community theater groups and schools will want to use the play as a fundraiser for any organization that helps national or international residents recover from natural disasters. We plan to create DVD's of the performances and make them( as well as the script and music) available to these groups free of charge.
  • In 2009, a small staged reading(using an earlier version of the script) at North Shore Community College in Lynn, MA  raised $2,500 for Katrina Relief, so performances of the play could be replicated from small scale readings to full productions depending on the resources of the performing group.
Other Ways You Can Help
  • Please spread the word about this project via social media and word-of-mouth.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools as well.

story:
Summary

I absolutely love to write and participate in musicals. Growing up, my best memories and most profound growing moments happened while participating in theatre, and I want to create opportunities for others to have these amazing experiences. I've learned, however, that producing a show is very expensive, hence, I decided to create an Online Theatre Company.

What Is An Online Theatre Company?

Well, that's a great question. What sets us apart from any other theatre company that happens to share videos of their performances online? 
  • All of our content is original, therefore we can freely (and legally) share the performances of our productions in their entirety.
  • We will have shows that are strictly online; such as movie-musicals, a monthly improv show streamed from StageIt.com, and a possible musical web-series
  • We'll gather songs and scenes to create exclusively online material.
Of course we'll still perform live, staged shows, but almost all of these will be filmed and available to view online.

Breakdown of Funds

  • Equipment (Camera, Microphones, Lights, etc.) - $2400
  • Cast and Crew for 3 projects - $4900
  • Venue Rentals - $2400
  • Props and Costumes - $900
  • Indiegogo Fees - $400

Moving Forward

This campaign is meant to be a springboard for our theatre company. Through ticket sales and show royalties, we hope to perpetuate enough funds to keep us going and performing for years to come.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, please consider these other very helpful items:

  • Share this campaign with friends and family through social media!
  • Check out and share our website: Frankly Productions

Thanks for checking us out!

story:
Why We Do It

In this documentary we chronicle the lives of  US street dancers as they train, live and compete in the world of street dance. We go behind the scenes and take a look at the lives of these high level street dancers to catch a glimpse of how they live, work, play, and how their life's journey have lead them from local heroes earning street cred, to international icons battling for respect, love of competition and an undying passion for their style of dance.

These stories often go untold but like Hoop Dreams showed us the tough path of inner city basketball, and Rise brought us the story of Krump, Champ will show us what it takes to walk the path of the champion street dancers. 

The producing team behind Champ are industry professionals who have developed relationships with the performers and have exclusive access to enter their lives in hopes of inspiring others as they were once inspired themselves. 

This documentary will deliver a high quality behind the scenes look at the life of Christopher 'Pharside' Jennings the founder of the world champion Academy of Villians; Boogie Frantick leader of the Mighty Zulu Kings; Marie Poppins a killer animator from France who now calls her US home, and the former World Champ JSmooth of Machine Gone Funk, who looks to repeat and bring the title back to the US as he did in 2006. 

We look at the origins of popping as the dancers and OGs share their inspirations for moves, and hints of what is to come. Accessing some truly inspirational and influential people who have made a world of difference in the street dance and mainstream worlds.


What We Need & What You Get

Help us bring this untold story to life, in appreciation for your support we have created some one-of-a-kind exclusive gear to represent the dance. Whether you choose a T-Shirt, a Hoodie, a Snap Back, or something else ...you can represent your favorite popper, the whole group or the movie. Or why not be bold and come along as part of our crew and be there when we shoot the beginning of our story at the next event in the UK! 

Whatever you decide to do we will appreciate it. 

Every dime we raise will be used to hire & maintain a dedicated crew who will follow the dancers through their lives as they make their way from tournament to tournament, fighting to be the best and move their unique dance form forward into the mainstream by staying old school and innovating.

We have 3 types of swag/gear. 

  • FOLLOW THE FILM - You can become part of the movement and choose a perk that will carry you along the story and behind the scenes; or
  • REP YOUR TEAM WITH GEAR - You can rep the movie with Tees, Snap Backs, Hoodies, etc; or
  • MAKE THE MOVIE WITH US - You can choose to be a baller and take part in the movie as a producer, enjoying the movie making process and taking part infront and behind the camera.


The Impact

Our mission is to show the fans and aspiring poppers, breakers, animators, bboys, and crews what it takes to become the Champ. As these artists open up their lives to us we will have a personal look at how they juggle family, relationships, bills, and life itself in pursuit of their dream. 

The truth behind these dancers will show you the dedication to mastery of their art form, whether they're waking up for the 4:30am sessions putting work at the gym, late night sessions, training in other forms to bring something new or hitting cyphers to stay sharp day in and day out.  

Creating a film like Champ does not warrant major interest from traditional financiers, not interested in the sub-culture, we must reach out to our community the dancers and artists and those people who have and will continue to support street dance. Your support will be bring this film to the big screen.  

OGs behind the Camera

The production team behind Champ are well seasoned veterans of the game. The Producers & Director have delivered film and tv to the masses and have the know how and more importantly, passion to make a truly great film. Each of the producers involved in Champ have worked closely with artists, actors, and crews to create some of the top television and films out today. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Creating a grass roots project & campaign has many layers. If you can't spare the coin, please join.

  • Join the campaign! via Social Media help drive our presence throughout the world by using the Share Tools!!!
  •  Like & Share our Facebook page, with new battle videos coming each week, let's make that page explode!
  • Become an ambassador for the film, let ALL dancers know about us, and let's get behind the teams and the film and get some dope swag!

story:
THE PROJECT  

 Summerland is an original musical by Anika Johnson, Barbara Johnston and Suzy Wilde, produced by Wexford Performing Arts. The Breakfast Club meets Peter Pan meets the Lord of the Flies in this ground-breaking show about 8 high school students who find themselves stranded between worlds after a bus accident. Incredibly moving, often hilarious and compelling from start to finish, Summerland explores and celebrates what it is to be a teen today. 

FIVE REASONS THIS PROJECT IS EXCITING                      

1. Created by Canada's newest writing team Johnson, Johnston and Wilde

  • They have been featured on the Golden Globe-nominated series Orphan Black, received accolades at the Edinburgh Fringe (2013 Fringe Review Top 10), Toronto Fringe (2014 NOW Toronto Outstanding Production), and Summerworks. In addition they tour Canada in the Spice Girls Tribute band; Wannabe. Anika Johnson's song writing was recently featured in Theatre Sheridan's hit site specific musical, 'Brantwood'.  

2. Produced by Wexford Performing Arts

  • Wexford Performing Arts has been producing high quality, full-scale theatrical productions for over 30 years and is home to the award winning Wexford Gleeks.  The Wexford Gleeks are a nationally recognized ensemble who were recently featured in two documentaries: The award winning TVO documentary 'Unsung - Behind the Glee' and 'The Real Glee' by Global television's 16:9. This past year 'The Gleeks' have performed at events for Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, James Earl Jones and Goldie Hawn and been heard on CBC's Sounds of the Season.  Graduates from the Wexford's Performing Arts program have gone on to star in film and television, Shaw, Stratford and on Broadway.

3. Toronto Arts Schools Unite

  • The cast of Summerland will unite students from Wexford Collegiate School for the Arts, Etobicoke School of the Arts, The Randolph Academy's Pre-College Program and Sheridan College.  

4. We're breaking the mold

  • The show will be performed on an epic scale rarely seen in Canada, with a huge cast of talented young artists, a live band, and innovative design.
  • You get to be part of the show! Our original production, taking place at Harbord Collegiate begins with a site specific component in the school halls.  

5.  It's the perfect summer show!

  • Summerland is the perfect show to see in the Annex on a summer’s night in July; it will fill you with nostalgia, touch you with longing and awaken old dreams.

WHAT WE NEED:

Money!

  • Summerland will have a cast and crew of over 100.
  • Putting on a full-scale, professional level musical comes with a hefty price tag. Your contribution will help subsidize rehearsal space rental, sound and lighting, costumes, our set, props and everything else needed to bring Summerland to life. 
Every dollar counts! We appreciate any amount you're able to give. Look to the right for the fun gifts of gratitude you will receive in return!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word!

  • Tell your friends and family to come see our show! You can find more info about it and book tickets starting June 11th at www.fringetoronto.com or call (416) 966-1062.
  • Share our website www.summerlandthemusical.com!
  • Share our Indiegogo campaign on facebook, twitter or Instagram!
