story:
Who We Are

Peasants of the Guild started in May of 2014 with 5 passionate students and the question "what does morality look like in a modern lens". These students have pursued this concept and are devising a show entitled "Id-ol-Matic". By incorporating their diverse interests and unique talents, these students have created a comedic and intriguing piece, intended for international audiences. They have been creating, rehearsing, and exploring for the past 8 months. Fast forward to February 2015 and they have been invited to perform in the Bienal Arte Joven Theater Festival in Buenos Aires Argentina, September of 2015!

What We Need

They have the show, now they need the funds. With your support, these funds will allow Peasants of the Guild to travel to Argentina, purchase props and lights, and see theatre from all around the world. Every contribution helps and brings the ensemble closer to telling a story that is extremely important in modern culture around the world. Peasants of the Guild is deeply grateful for any help you can offer!

                   

What You Get

We have some awesome rewards for you so please check them out! Our perks give you an inside view of our devising process, our unique talents, and the hard work we put into this piece. We also have opportunities for you to receive pieces of our show, our script, and fun photos and souvenirs from the theatre festival in Argentina.

The Impact

These students have a great love of theater and want to share it with the world! Combined, they have 40+ years experience in show business and this opportunity is one of their greatest triumphs yet! Your support will allow these students to bring their passion and performance from New York City to Buenos Aires. Our project is valuable because it is a student organized show with an important message about modern morality. 

Risks & Challenges

We haven't encountered many risks and challenges. We have been accepted to the festival and have housing when we get there! Primarily, our biggest challenge is raising the funds to travel and produce this show. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, we understand! We are college students and we get it! Please take the time to share our campaign and our story with your social media. Our website is www.peasantsoftheguild.weebly.com and the Indiegogo campaign can be shared directly! If you would like to write about us, our email is peasantsoftheguild@gmail.com. Again, every bit of support helps and means the WORLD to us. Thank you!

story:
The Fat and Greasy Citizens Brigade (FGC) is the resident theater company of the Grace Episcopal Church in Georgetown. The company's mission is to provide accessible theater for everyone, and we do so by providing free outdoor productions of the works of William Shakespeare each summer. DC has so many great free outdoor summer activities like Screen on the Green and Jazz in the Sculpture Garden. We are bringing free outdoor theater to the city--where people can lay out blankets, pack a picnic and enjoy a performance out under the stars!

This summer in its third season, FGC will be mounting a production of William Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" with performances running for two weeks June 11, 12, 18, 19, 20, 25, 26 and 27, 2015. The performances will be held nightly at 8 p.m. at Grace Episcopal Church in Georgetown (1041 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC 20007), doors will open at 7 p.m. for picnicking and relaxing pre-performance. 

Your tax-deductible donation will help to provide funding for: 

- Our Venue 

- Set 

- Costumes 

- Props 

- Marketing

We really appreciate any help that you could give! By supporting The Fat and Greasy Citizens Brigade you will be a part of bringing free, outdoor, live theatre to DC! 

Thank you! 

-Alexis Truitt, Managing Director & Heather Cipu, Artistic Director 

For more information and updates please visit our facebook page or our website.

story:
From Brown and Down to Green and Clean!!

The Vienna Union Hall, built in 1888, still supports a large, one hole outhouse which is at least 80’ from the main door.  Currently, the hall used for arts and entertainment for the greater mid-Maine community, requires patrons in need of relief to  trudge out through mosquitoes, blackflies, wind, rain, hail, sleet or snow to the outhouse.. (which is the reason we must keep our shows short). Can we any longer go to the Union Hall for performances? It all "Depends". If only we can upgrade and go green with a new composing toilet and handicap accessible building close to the entrance all will be well.

Our Union Hall was built in the small village of Vienna, Maine as a gathering place where townsfolk could unite. Historically the hall was built by the men of Vienna for the women of Vienna but is now a wonderful all community hall, complete with stage and balcony (and of course the outhouse). Labor for the building and upkeep of this historic hall has been done almost entirely by donations and the volunteering of local folks loving this old building.

Here people have met for dances and dinners; they have laughed and socialized in the hall on and off for over 127 years. The Hall has hosted Wild West shows, local theater, Professional Shakespearean theater, auctions, weddings and receptions, boy scout meetings, youth gatherings, Revels, dance performances and musicians from far and wide.  Over 1300 people come through the hall in a year. We may be one of the oldest continuously used theaters with no water and still using an outhouse.

Right now the old outhouse, built on top of ledge and listing to the side, is a cause for concern with the usual outhouse aroma and flying papers in wild wind storms. The seat of honor is hard to get to, having been built in a separate small building in the far back of the hall...with no electricity and no heat the trip is especially fierce in the coldest months. The path is rough and stony and once arriving, the building is not one where guests care to linger.  Our patrons are getting older, Maine having the oldest population in the nation, and does not meet the handicap accessible rules governing public buildings. Having coped with this outbuilding for the last 127 years we feel it is time to upgrade.

Help us move from brown and down to green and clean! Our vision for this great community building is a small, clean, well-lighted and warmed composting toilet building right off the handicap ramp on the side of the hall.

What We Need & What You Get

What we have!
We have already recruited skilled volunteer carpenters to build the new outbuilding and tear down and replace the ramp leading from the toilet house to the hall. For the building itself we need only materials. A site evaluator has volunteered to design the site and get permits and a volunteer to install the new composting toilet. The electric heat unit has been donated.
What we need:
We need some earthwork done with an excavator to prepare for the building.
We also need a licensed electrician to install the lights and  and heat. All new public buildings must be handicap accessible!
For the building we need to raise
$10,221 - building materials including footings, roofing, sheathing, handicap door and interior grab bar, electricity and earthwork
$3,000 - ramp materials
$3,079 - Envirolet® Waterless Remote System - We need a waterless system since we have no water in the building!
Total amount we need to raise $16,300

Here is what the building will look like:

And here is our dream toilet!

We have opted for the flexible funding option so that if we are unable to meet our goal.. (can this really happen ??oh no...) we will put the funds received in a savings fund which we will continue to grow until we are able to move on with our toilet project.

If, perchance,  we are able to raise more money than our estimated compost house expenses, the remainder of what we receive will go to support local professional artists, musicians and performers of all kinds by hiring them to perform at the fabulous Union Hall.

Check out our perks: your name immortalized in a new toilet house or in the hall or maybe a great CD from one of our shows or season tickets to the performances and a even a very cool T-Shirt.

The Impact - You can warm our buns.

Creating this new wonderful composting toilet has been the dream of people in our community for many years. Before every show at the hall people from far and wide take the time to make sure they don't drink too much, and use their home toilets before stepping out the door. Much of our audience is on the cusp of old age and walking in the dark over rough gravel with a full bladder can be very stressful. (We do hand out flashlights for the trip!)

Here's our existing one-holer...All fixed up and decorated to the nines, but it is hard to make a silk purse out of of sow's ear. And most of all hard to convey the cold breezes and odors blowing up from beneath that nice seat.

Why Help???

It's Tax Deductible!

The Vienna Union Hall Association is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization,  so all of your donations are tax deductible.

You make the world a more beautiful place.

Not only will our project help people feel better but it will also contribute to making wonderful organic compost for flowers around the hall (rather than creating the great  dilemma of what to do with  a full outhouse). 

What do we do with  the resiDooDoo now? We can hire the "cucka sucka" to pump out the hole and truck it away.  We can honey dip and truck it to a disposal site on our own. We can bag it a haul it off to a disposal site.  We can hope it goes away by itself (not too likely). None of these options get the DooDoo where it will help beautify our world. But composting will!

Support a Participatory Community Culture

 Small town life still defies the extinction of community and a first hand connection to the arts.  The Union Hall connects people in a historic place without the use of electronics. Keep this connection alive and well in rural America!

Where will the old outhouse gogo?

The old outhouse will not go to waste. No way would we let a pile of rubble be gone without finding a great use for it. We will clean up the icky waste underneath and close the hole. Then the Hall will have a wonderful storage shed for props and tools. Something we are sorely lacking at this time!

Success Stories

Throughout the years the Union Hall Association's momentum has passed from hand to hand but has always been focused on building, maintaining, renovating  and improving our hall. We have raised money from town suppers and auctions to

 insulate and sheetrock, (while preserving historic graffiti), refinished and painted the interior, had bench cushions made, repaired benches, installed new windows, upgraded from a wood stove to gas heaters and overcome the setback of a fire when the hall was struck by lightning the night before a fundraising auction was scheduled. Many more projects, too numerous to mention,  have been finished at the hall but the toilet has always been a problem too big for us to tackle alone.

We Shall Overcome? But How?

In our small town, population of only 550+,  residents must, and do, take on multiple roles (as people used to do before specialization) to keep things running.  One of our carpenters is also the plumbing inspector, site evaluator and a performer on stage.  Our other carpenter is a boat builder and musician. Our parking coordinator is also a fireman that helped save the building after the lightning strike.  Helping save old walls of graffiti at the hall was led by the town archeologist who studied ancient red-paint people's drawings. We are diverse. We are determined. We are flexible, and we are able to meet challenges that would stop our potty project from coming to a successful conclusion.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Can't afford a donation at this time? You can still help us by spreading the word to others.

    • Send a link to our campaign to all of  your email, facebook and twitter contacts and ask them to pass it on,,,

    And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
From Brown and Down to Green and Clean!!
 The Vienna Union Hall, built in 1888, still supports a large, one hole outhouse which is at least 80’ from the main door.  Currently, the hall used for arts and entertainment for the greater mid-Maine community, requires patrons in need of relief to  trudge out through mosquitoes, blackflies, wind, rain, hail, sleet or snow to the outhouse.. (which is the reason we must keep our shows short). Can we any longer go to the Union Hall for performances? It all "Depends". If only we can upgrade and go green with a new composing toilet and handicap accessible building close to the entrance all will be well. Our Union Hall was built in the small village of Vienna, Maine as a gathering place where townsfolk could unite. Historically the hall was built by the men of Vienna for the women of Vienna but is now a wonderful all community hall, complete with stage and balcony (and of course the outhouse). Labor for the building and upkeep of this historic hall has been done almost entirely by donations and the volunteering of local folks loving this old building. Here people have met for dances and dinners; they have laughed and socialized in the hall on and off for over 127 years. The Hall has hosted Wild West shows, local theater, Professional Shakespearean theater, auctions, weddings and receptions, boy scout meetings, youth gatherings, Revels, dance performances and musicians from far and wide.  Over 1300 people come through the hall in a year. We may be one of the oldest continuously used theaters with no water and still using an outhouse.Right now the old outhouse, built on top of ledge and listing to the side, is a cause for concern with the usual outhouse aroma and flying papers in wild wind storms. The seat of honor is hard to get to, having been built in a separate small building in the far back of the hall...with no electricity and no heat the trip is especially fierce in the coldest months. The path is rough and stony and once arriving, the building is not one where guests care to linger.  Our patrons are getting older, Maine having the oldest population in the nation, and does not meet the handicap accessible rules governing public buildings. Having coped with this outbuilding for the last 127 years we feel it is time to upgrade. Help us move from brown and down to green and clean! Our vision for this great community building is a small, clean, well-lighted and warmed composting toilet building right off the handicap ramp on the side of the hall.    What We Need & What You Get What we have!We have already recruited skilled volunteer carpenters 
to build the new outbuilding and tear down and replace the ramp leading from the toilet house to
 the hall. For the building itself we need only materials. A site evaluator has volunteered to design the site and get permits and a 
volunteer to install the new composting toilet. The electric heat unit 
has been donated. What we need:We need some earthwork done with an excavator to prepare for the building.We also need a licensed electrician to install the lights and  and heat. All new public buildings must be handicap accessible!For the building we need to raise $10,221
 - building materials including footings, roofing, sheathing, handicap 
door and interior grab bar, electricity and earthwork $3,000 - ramp materials $3,079 - Envirolet® Waterless Remote System - We need a waterless system since we have no water in the building!Total amount we need to raise $16,300
Here is what the building will look like:

And here is our dream toilet! 
We have opted for the flexible funding option so that if we are unable to meet our goal.. (can this really happen ??oh no...) we will put the funds received in a savings fund which we will continue to grow until we are able to move on with our toilet project.
If, perchance,  we are able to raise more money than our estimated compost house expenses, the remainder of what we receive will go to support local professional artists, musicians and performers of all kinds by hiring them to perform at the fabulous Union Hall.
Check out our perks: your name immortalized in a new toilet house or in the hall or maybe a great CD from one of our shows or season tickets to the performances and a even a very cool T-Shirt. 
  The Impact - You can warm our buns.

Creating this new wonderful composting toilet has been the dream of people in our community for many years. Before every show at the hall people from far and wide take the time to make sure they don't drink too much, and use their home toilets before stepping out the door. Much of our audience is on the cusp of old age and walking in the dark over rough gravel with a full bladder can be very stressful. (We do hand out flashlights for the trip!)



Here's our existing one-holer...All fixed up and decorated to the nines, but it is hard to make a silk purse out of of sow's ear. And most of all hard to convey the cold breezes and odors blowing up from beneath that nice seat.  
Why Help???
It's Tax Deductible!
The Vienna Union Hall Association is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization,  so all of your donations are tax deductible. 
You make the world a more beautiful place. 
Not only will our project help people feel better but it will also contribute to making wonderful organic compost for flowers around the hall (rather than creating the great  dilemma of what to do with  a full outhouse).  
What do we do with  the resiDooDoo now? We can hire the "cucka sucka" to pump out the hole and truck it 
away.  We can honey dip and truck it to a disposal site on our own. We can bag it a haul it off to a disposal site.  We can hope it goes away by itself (not too likely). None of these options get the DooDoo where it will help beautify our world. But composting will!


Support a Participatory Community Culture
 Small town life still defies the extinction of community and a first hand connection to the arts.  The Union Hall connects people in a historic place without the use of electronics. Keep this connection alive and well in rural America!

Where will the old outhouse gogo?
The old outhouse will not go to waste. No way would we let a pile of rubble be gone without finding a great use for it. We will clean up the icky waste underneath and close the hole. Then the Hall will have a wonderful storage shed for props and tools. Something we are sorely lacking at this time! 

Success Stories
 
Throughout the years the Union Hall Association's momentum has passed from hand to hand but has always been focused on building, maintaining, renovating  and improving our hall. We have raised money from town suppers and auctions to  insulate and sheetrock, (while preserving historic graffiti), refinished and painted the 
interior, had bench cushions made, repaired benches, installed new windows, upgraded from a wood stove to gas heaters and overcome the setback of a fire when the hall was struck by lightning the night before a fundraising auction was scheduled. Many more projects, too numerous to mention,  have been finished at the hall but the toilet has always been a problem too big for us to tackle alone. 
 


We Shall Overcome? But How?
In our small town, population of only 550+,  residents must, and do, take on multiple roles (as people used to do before specialization) to keep things running.  One of our carpenters is also the plumbing 
inspector, site evaluator and a performer on stage.  Our other carpenter is a boat builder and musician. Our parking coordinator is also a fireman that helped save the building after the lightning strike.  Helping save old walls of graffiti at the hall was led by the town archeologist who studied 
ancient red-paint people's drawings. We are diverse. We are determined. We are flexible, and we are able to meet challenges that would stop our potty project from coming to a successful conclusion.     Other Ways You Can Help Can't afford a donation at this time? You can still help us by spreading the word to others.   Send a link to our campaign to all of  your email, facebook and twitter contacts and ask them to pass it on,,,
  And that's all there is to it.

story:
Help Gritty City cover our challenging summer expenses AND provide amazing free programming that keeps our youth safe, energized, traveling to new places, and growing as young performers throughout the summer months.

WHAT WE DO:

Gritty City Rep (GCR) trains Oakland youth, aged 14-22, for at least one full school year, to perform high quality, professional theatre.  Participation in our company is COMPLETELY FREE, so young people who traditionally can't access serious, long term, rigorous programs like ours can participate! We produce two shows each year:  a modern in the fall, and Shakespeare in the spring. Most of our performers start out with little or no theatrical experience. By the time they have worked with GCR for a year, they have developed as actors, their confidence is through the roof, they have strengthened their community, their support systems have grown, and they have set and achieved challenging, long-term goals. We complete our third season of shows at the end of June and begin our second year of amazing FREE summer programming in July!

WHY WE NEED HELP:

Summer is expensive, and we are committed to making sure that we provide free year-round programming to Oakland youth. Gritty City Repertory is a place where youth are safe and engaged during the long summer months that school is out.  Many young people cannot afford expensive summer programming - or even inexpensive summer programming - and that's where we come in!  For the second year in a row, we are providing a 100% free two week summer camp, taking our Ensemble on a day retreat to the redwoods, and traveling to Oregon for the Ashland Oregon Shakespeare Festival!

Eight of our performers will be visiting Ashland with us for two days as theatre tourists - but three more of the GCR Ensemble will be representing Gritty City Repertory at the super prestigious and competitive two-week-long Oregon Shakespeare Festival Summer Seminar for Juniors!

This year, our performers Masud and Ayah were accepted into this nationally attended, 65 student program. And Dashawn, who attended last summer, was one of only 8 students asked to return as a senior assistant!  We are honored and proud. 

Gritty City Repertory will pay all tuition not covered by scholarship, purchase clothing and personal items needed for the trip, drive our performers to Oregon, and feed them on the way there. Their driver will spend one night in a hotel in Oregon before making the 7 hour drive back home the next day.

Then, two weeks later, we will rent a van and bring our Ensemble on the return trip to Oregon!  We will leave in the early hours of the morning and arrive in time to see Sweat at 1:00, and Much Ado About Nothing at 8:00!  Our tickets have been generously donated by the Oregon Shakespeare Festival Education Program - thank you OSF!  We will spend the night in a youth hostel, and in the morning, support our fellow company members by attending their Swan Song performance that closes the Summer Seminar.  Then, we'll all pile into the van and head back to California.  Gritty City Repertory will once again cover all costs - van, gas, food, and lodging.

We also take our Ensemble on a day retreat to Butano State Park, where we hike in the redwoods, frolic in a waterfall, play on the beach, cook a community meal, and generally connect with nature and each other.  It's an amazing community building experience, and a very new environment for many of our performers.  Again, Gritty City Rep covers all costs - transportation and food for the day for the whole group. 

In April we were awarded a generous grant from the Akonadi Foundation that covers most of our expenses for our FREE two-week summer camp - thank you so much Akonadi!  We are still working on raising the last few hundred dollars in order to be fully funded for camp.  This year's summer camp will run from July 20-July 31, and serve 20 youth - current and aspiring Ensemble, as well as other Oakland youth just looking for a great free summer experience.  Camp will focus on the collision between capoeira, acrobatics, and physical theatre, and close with an exciting free exhibition at the Flight Deck!

Finally, we are a resident theatre company at the Flight Deck all year round, so even though we don't have regular rehearsals and shows throughout the summer, we are hard at work writing grants and designing our fall production - we still have to pay our monthly rent, and cover staff salaries!  

Help us cover those challenging summer expenses AND provide amazing free programming that keeps our youth safe, energized, traveling to new places, and growing as young performers throughout the summer months.

$10,000 will:

  • Get our campers and a huge group from our Ensemble to and from Ashland!
  • Cover all extra expenses for our three ensemble members to attend the OSF Summer Seminar for Juniors
  • Get our Ensemble to and from Butano State Park for our one-day retreat to the redwoods
  • Cover our last few Summer Camp 2015 expenses
  • Pay our July and August rent at the Flight Deck
  • Cover a portion of our summer staff salaries

I CAN'T AFFORD IT, BUT I STILL WANT TO HELP - CAN I?

You can help Gritty City Rep support youth with amazing summer programming by passing this page along to anyone you think might be interested, posting on your social media, and generally spreading the word.

PLEASE SHARE THESE LINKS:

OUR WEBSITE:  www.grittycityrep.org

OUR FACEBOOK:  https://www.facebook.com/GrittyCityRep

WHAT DO I GET?

Help us out and we would LOVE to hook you up!!  Here are some of the fabulous rewards you get - as if good karma and the satisfaction of supporting Oakland youth and the arts weren't enough!

$10+ gets you onto our website and into our playbill as a GCR donor!

$25+ gets you a huge shout out and thank you on facebook!

$50+ gets you a free cookie or brownie at our next show!

$100+ gets you free wine at our next show!

$250+ gets you two free tickets to either production in our 2015-2016 season!

$500+ gets you a GCR t-shirt!

$1000+ gets you all of the above AND our eternal gratitude!

QUESTIONS?

Feel free to ask the project creator directly if the above info doesn't answer all your questions.

story:
Presents

Vivid Tapestry, an evening of bold and physically vibrant, contemporary dance woven together by Artistic Director Katie Stevinson-Nollet. Presented in the Edward C and Ann T. Roberts Theater at the Handel Performing Arts Center, 35 Westbourne Parkway, Hartford, CT.  Friday, May 29th and Saturday, May 30th at 7:30 PM and Sunday, May 31st at 2:00 PM. www.hartford.edu/tickets

Vivid Tapestry is an evening of four colorful dance works and a music and dance collaboration with featured guests Oboe Duo Agosto performing Daughter of the Sea, a work with movement performed by musicians Ling Fie Kang and Charles Huang, composed by Andrea Clearfield. Inspired by the love sonnets of Pablo Neruda, Daughter of the Sea is a beautiful, touching and charismatic work. 

 Oboe Duo Agosto

Dance works:

Recently performing with the Hartford Symphony Orchestra, the evening will open with Danse Macabre, inspired by the tales of Dances of Death in the Middle ages, and performed to the music of Jordi Savall.  with my last breathe, a touching duet about love and loss, premiered at the Provincetown Dance Festival in October and returns to the stage in Vivid Tapestry.  Flit, is a charming quintet inspired by the lifecycle of butterflies with an original score by Bill Solomon. Fandango lights up the stage with a vibrant, sinuous love triangle to the titillating score of L. Boccherini.

Who are we?

Full Force Dance Theatre has been performing original contemporary dances for audiences since 1991, and has been a 501(c) (3) non-profit organization since 2002.  Its mission has been to promote contemporary dance within the Greater Hartford area, and abroad, through artistic excellence, creativity, and collaboration.

FFDT has presented work throughout the United States and abroad under the choreographic leadership of Katie Stevinson-Nollet.  A few venues include the 92nd Street Y, the Provincetown Dance Festival, Jacob’s Pillow Inside/Out series, Joyce SoHo, Dance New Amsterdam, Florida State Dance Festival and San Diego State University.  Locally, in Connecticut,  you may have seen us at the International Arts Festival in New Haven, the University of Hartford, the Charter Oak Cultural Center, Saint Joseph University, and the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art.  

In its constant effort to bring together artists of all genre’s and creative styles, FFDT has invited many guest artists to collaborate and create original works on the company.  FFDT has enjoyed bringing together local artists, internationally renowned composers and musicians, and established and emerging choreographers from around the country.  Always willing to explore new creative endeavors, it recently presented a multi-media performance at the Wadsworth Atheneum integrating dance, film and a live soundscape composed and performed for its performance. 
www.fullforcedance.org

We need your help:

Full Force Dance Theatre needs your help in raising funds for Vivid Tapestry.  We are trying to raise  2000.00 to help pay our dancers.  Producing a show can be expensive and all too often the people who put in the most work are the least paid:  the dancers.  We are working hard to try to provide a stipend for our dancers.  But we are a little shy of our goal and need your help. 

There are several ways you can show your support:

1. Come to the show. Your support in the theater is most important. Without you we would not exist. Sharing our love of dance is why we are here. 

2. Monetary donation. Any and all donations are graciously received and will be acknowledged in our program. 

3. Spread the word. Please share the news about the company, concert, and this link through your favorite media link: Facebook, Twitter, email, etc. 

Please support your local dance artist.

With  sincere appreciation,

Katie Stevinson-Nollet, Artistic Director

and the Dancers of Full Force Dance Theatre:

Kristen Himmelberger-Balsamo, Tiana Mancuso, Brianne Taylor, Giovanna Carrain, Christopher LeFleche, Kristen Schranze, Marjorie Gross, Katie Bittner

story:
Welcome to Grin Theatre Company - an exciting, refreshing and different fringe theatre company based in Liverpool that has its main focus on everything LGBT. Grin Theatre helps promote new creative talents in areas of writing, performance and theatre direction. Created four years ago and helping to empower all creatives within the theatre community on Merseyside.

Queertet is the jewel in Grin's rainbow crown, now in its fourth year and about to enjoy another three night run at the famous Unity Theatre in Liverpool. Queertet is all about giving voice to new talent every year by showcasing 4 short LGBT plays in one night.How to describe Queertet? - well its fair tp say its a variety box of theatrical magic which is always upbeat, colourful, entertaining and most of all proud. Queertet has enjoyed great sucess over the past 3 years and it really does kick start the Liverpool Pride season with lots of theatrical pazazz, fizz and audience delight. All the plays are written by new writers to the stage and carefully selected to provide the optimum effect of euphoria and entertainment throughout the evening. Queertet makes people grin and Grin Theatre is proud to present this yearly feast of theatre.

Want to support us?

Grin is presenting 4 new LGBT plays as part of our Queertet 2015 Programme at the Unity Theatre, this July 2015 - but we need your support to help pay for the costs of materials, venue hire and payments to our actors. We really need your love and support with this. Its so important to hear LGBT voices especially within fringe theatre and especially when arts funding is in so short supply and with your help, we can really make that difference and make our voices heard.

A big Grin Thank You.

story:
Help The Phoenix and 2by2 Readers Theatre bring joy and laughter to those who cannot get out to attend the theatre--through creation and replication of a readers theatre.

Christine Mosere and Melanie Calderwood of The Phoenix Theatre (with over 30 years experience producing theatre) and Dan Jacoby of 2by2 Readers Theatre (would you believe he has over 40 years experience and is only 50!) have discovered that many senior centers, assisted living centers, and hospitals are on such tight entertainment budgets that bringing in high quality theatre (or any theatre for that matter) is not usually within their budget.

We brainstormed and realized that together we could work magic! So we are combining efforts and raising funds to help subsidize the cost of bringing theatre on the road to those who cannot get out to enjoy it in the Pacific Northwest/Puget Sound Region. 

$8,800 will get us up and running and on the road for 6 months. After the initial push, it'll cost so much less to keep it up and running.

  • We need $2,000 upfront for the cost of building and printing brochures, registering for licenses, securing rights and copying materials, as well as other miscellaneous fees (securing initial music stands, actors, rehearsal fees, etc).
  • 80% ($6,800) will be used to subsidize the cost of bringing our talented performers (2-4 at a time) and productions to 18 senior/assisted living centers and 4 hospitals. That's 3 to 4 a month!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, it is okay; we can still subsidize the cost of bringing theatre to senior and assisted living centers--just fewer of them. The more raised the more people we can reach.

The Impact

Art brings joy and understanding to the world. It can make life worth living.

A popular saying “laughter is the best medicine” turns out to be true! Numerous research has shown that there is a healing power to laughter.

  • Laughter protects the heart. (Recent University of Maryland Medical Center study of heart disease.)
  • Laughter relaxes the body and puts you in a better mood. It decreases pain, anxiety, and stress. (Nonprofit Health Resource—NPHR)
  • The Phoenix Theatre has been making people laugh since 2008. 2by2 Readers, although new, was formed by community activist and artist Dan Jacoby--who has been directing and producing theatre for over 20 years and in the business for over 40. 
  • This partnership is based on a successful Northeast model started by Ron Jacoby (yes, Dan's father!) 
  • To impact the most people, we have decided to replicate this program so actors across the country can bring theatre to those who cannot attend with ease. We will put together a booklet that shows all the steps to take and includes public domain 30-45 minute scripts that play well for this demographic. More artists, all over the country, can serve more people unable to get to the theatre!

Risks & Challenges

There are risks with everything. We are lucky that the risks are minimal with this type of project. We've been producing theatre for years and understand the cost of doing business. 

We've done the research and local senior centers are ready and waiting for us to start. In fact, three senior/assisted living centers want to book our program. Unfortunately, they don't have the funds available and are anxious to be subsidized. 

However, one risk may be underestimating the costs of getting this partnership up and running. The best way to find out is to jump in and discover what is needed. The worst that could happen is that we need to cut back in the number of Centers/Hospitals we can serve the first six months.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? Please get the word out! Indiegogo has sharing tools! Ask us if you need help.

story:
Do You Want To Fund A Super-villain? 

Hi, I'm Diane Crotty, the writer and performer of Spandex Blues. 

First of all, congratulations on coming this far- It shows you have fine taste. (Either that or villanous tendencies, which is sort of the same thing.) 

Secondly, I'd like to thank you for coming and tell you about my new show, Spandex Blues, which I'm asking you to fund. (I mean, I'm thrilled you're here and you are looking very well, I have to say, but it's really the funding I'm after). 

Ahem. 

Spandex Blues is the story of a super-villain who comes from a family of super-heroes; It's set in a Dublin not all that different from the one you know and it's about the sort of family problems everybody understands. 

Anxiety. 

Trauma. 

The fact that your older siblings won't let you build a ray-gun.

Our anti-heroine, E, is on the verge of a major breakdown. A job's gone South and she doesn't know what to do. But thanks to her trusty hench-person, Henchie, and you, the audience, she might find her way out of the pickle in which she's found herself.

Or things might get a whole lot worse... 

Why Should You Fund Us?  

Spandex Blues started as a way to talk about Irish families without having to involve the usual suspects: kitchen sinks, alcoholism and a suspiciously malevolent universe. 

It's since grown into a labour of love, one wrapped in spandex and neon. 

I've been trying to get this script off the ground since 2013 and I'm finally close to making it a reality; The show will premiere in Dublin's Smock Alley Theatre in January 2016. But before that can happen, we need some funds. Not a lot, just enough moolah to pay for:

  • Rehearsal Space.
  • The Deposit on the Venue. 
  • Insurance.
  • Costume & Props. 
In giving us funding, you ensure that myself and the other artists working hard to get this show running will not be out of pocket, and will be able to deliver the best work we can. You also get the chance to become part of our villainous little family and to see a uniqiue piece of work, stagger, Bambi-like, to its feet. 
So g'wan, you know you want to. After all, you can start for the price of a pint... 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute- I understand, really, I do- but that doesn't mean that you can't help:

  • You can make noise about the campaign. Share the videos, like them. (Just please don't report me to the Gardai). 
  • Tell your mammy and all your friends about us. Say lovely things about us, even if you don't mean them. 
  • Come along to see the show in January- We'll be delighted to have you
  • You can also use the indiegogo share tools, but tell your Mammy first.

story:
Bound to Rise takes place in the time of America's robber barons, the country's "Gilded Age." It was a time when thousands of children were living in the streets and the rich arranged "poverty socials" dressed in made up rags drinking champagne out of beer buckets. It was a striking contrast between overcrowded tenements and opulent mansions.

Bound to Rise is drawn from the "strive and succeed" novels of Horatio Alger which were popular during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.  He is given credit for creating the concept of the American Dream, and throughout his books, while the names were different, the moral was always the same - no matter how poor you can achieve success through hard work and determination.

Medicine Show Theater Ensemble is the oldest experimental theater in New York City now going into its 47th year of creating thought provoking productions. 

The original score for Bound to Rise was composed by Robert Dennis (Oh! Calcutta! the "Milk" song from Sesame Street, etc.) with lyics and book by Stephen Phillip Pollicoff in collaboration with Medicine Show.

While the play is a comedy and has a happy ending, this portrait of New York City in the 1880s- and 1890s is even more relevant today as a new era of billionaires and the top one percent take over the country.

Bound to Rise will be performed at the Medicine Show Theater on January, 26,  2017 and ends Feb. 26 and your support will make it a success.

As you know the Arts is underfunded in America and Medicine Show Theatre Ensemble has felt the blunt of this over the last few years.  As one of the few experimental theaters still in existence it depends on public support to survive.

story:
Hey everybody :) Beleza aka Nico Zen here and I wish to share with you today this exciting creative project I am launching here in Venice, Los Angeles, California. 

 

I have created an awesome healing modality whereby I combine the healing power of touch with the emotional vibration healing of the Bach flower essences. This modality heals clients on both a physical and emotional level, leaving the mind and body feeling rejuvenated, refreshed, and invigorated to live out one’s unique soul goals.

 

 

My funding goals are to garner enough start up capital to expand my existing client base, launch a new website, and hire out technology support for marketing, social media and mobile web app development. 

 

I know I can grow my business exponentially. Please will you help me today to make this heal and reveal dream a reality?

 

A little bit more…

 

The Bach flower essences helped me to rediscover all the intuitive and creative power I have within me to create through the beautiful language of dance hence ballet. 

 

Sadness and depression are a heaviness that can wear many names and this fact is one reason why the Bach flower essences are so powerful and transforming. These powerful energetic healing tools allow you to deep dive into your healing, where each essence corresponds to a very specific emotional response.

 

For instance:

 

If you are feeling a complete sense of overwhelm, if you feel incapable at the enormity of a task because of a great inner anxiety in feeling you cannot do everything yourself and/or you are in a position at work where you have a tremendous amount of responsibility attached, like a president, cfo, or film director, then you can take the flower essence ELM to alleviate these symptoms and make you feel confident, responsible and organized.

 

In cases of PTSD one can take the essence STAR OF BETHLEHEM and feel an immediate release from sadness and a greater capacity to open up. A third example I can give from my own healing work is using the essence SCLERANTHUS or ALÈNE as it is called in French. Being both a poet and a dancer, I sometimes found it hard to begin projects and make choices, always seeing obstacles down the road between one option and the other and unfortunately leaving me too long in the nether of indecision consequent. Through using the flower essence ALÈNE I became adroit at choosing between two options, making good choices and acting quickly, knowing what I want and having no regrets in the choices I make. 

 

I hope you can see from these examples how this course of healing is worlds better than going to a doctor and saying “I feel sad” in some sort of a grey haze where  neither you nor the doctor really have any idea what is going on. Flower essence therapy provides acute relief to emotional suffering. Feel better now. Transform through healing!

So In closing…

 

If you have read down this far into the campaign, first:

 

THANK YOU!

MERCI BIEN!!

 

We live in a media saturated, attention deficit world and your genuine interest in my campaign means the world to me!

 

I leave you with some resonant quotes from the seminal treatise “Heal Thyself” the book authored by Dr. Edward Bach laying out the vision and mission statement he originally envisioned when first developing this method of homeopathy in the early twentieth century. I hope they leave you as inspired and encouraged as they did me when I first discovered this brilliant and humble man’s work nearly a decade ago. 

 

Chapter 1, page 1

 

“

… it is humbly hoped that it will be a guide to those who suffer, to seek within themselves the real origin of their maladies so that they may assist themselves in their own healing...the main reason for the failure of modern medical science is that it is dealing with results and not causes...Disease will never be cured or eradicated by present materialistic methods, for the simple reason that disease in its origin is not material. What we know as disease is an ultimate result produced in the body, the end product of deep and long-acting forces, and even if material treatment alone is apparently successful this is nothing more than a temporary relief unless the real cause has been removed.”

 

Chapter 2, page 13

 

“ Then follows a fourth great principle, that so long as our Souls and personalities are in harmony, all is joy and peace, happiness and health. It is when our personalities are lead astray from the path laid down by the Soul, either by our own worldly desires or by the persuasion of others, that a conflict arises. This conflict is the root cause of disease and unhappiness. No matter what our work in the world — bootblack or monarch, landlord or peasant, rich or poor— so long as we do that particular work according to the dictates of the Soul, all is well; and we can further rest in whatever station of life we are placed, princely or lowly, it contains the lessons and experiences necessary at the moment of our evolution, and gives us the best advantage for the development of ourselves.”

 

Chapter 5, pages 27-28

 

“True, it may be the calling of any one individual to devote his life to one other alone, but before doing so let him be absolutely certain that this is the command of her Soul, and that it is not the suggestion of some other dominant personality over-persuading her, or false ideas of duty directing him. Let she also remember that we come down into this world to win battles, to gain strength against those who would control us, and to advance to that stage when we pass through life doing our duty calmly and quietly, undeterred and uninfluenced by any living being, calmly guided always by the voice of our Higher Self. For many their greatest battle will be in their own home, where before gaining their liberty to win victories in the world they will have to free themselves from the adverse domination and control of some very near relative.

 

Any individual, whether adult or child, part of whose work it is in this life to free herself from the dominant control of another, should remember the following: firstly, that his would-be oppressor should be regarded in the same way we look upon an opponent in sport, as a personality with whom we are playing the game of Life, without the least trace of bitterness, and that if it were not for such opponents we should be lacking in the opportunity to develop our own courage and individuality; secondly, that the real victories of life come through LOVE and gentleness, and that in such a contest no force whatever must be used: that by steadily growing in his own nature, bearing sympathy, kindness and, if possible, affection—or, even better love— towards the opponent, she may so develop that in time she may very gently and quietly follow the call of conscience without allowing the least interference.”

 

This final quote harkens to my mind the profound speech, “The Great March to Freedom” given by the venerable, prolific and divine Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on June 23, 1963 in Detroit, Michigan. In this speech the husband of Coretta Scott talks of his naiëve dream of the white oppressor transforming the society of segregation, both seen and unseen, to one where racism no longer exists and exploitation is acknowledged and undone, to one where the oppressed can look with love towards a future where equality is a reality and can get up and stand up to a system of injustice without hatred eating at their insides, towards a complete societal transformation where love and tolerance are normal interactions. For injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere!

https://tidal.com/track/20090882
 

Thanks again, for your genuine interest in my campaign. Please donate NOW to make this heal and reveal dream a reality. Please like and share this campaign widely on all your favorite social media platforms, text and email or give the old school phone a friend option a ring.

 

Sending love, light and infinite abundance to everybody.

 

Merci bien,

Nico c Beleza

story:
THE BIG GOAL:

Hello! Thanks so much for reading and finding out more about what we are doing! 

First question you have, is surely who are we? 

Well, 45North and Ellandar are two independent London-based theatre companies, we both like to make multidisciplinary work (which is a fancy way of saying we make shiny new theatre). Together we’ve been making work for the past 18 months and in 2020 we have some big goals. The biggest goal, so far, is to take not one, but TWO new productions to Australia for Fringe World Festival in Western Australia and Adelaide Fringe, after both festivals programmed our work! This is super-duper exciting but in order to do this, we need your help to remove some of the pesky financial barriers that get in the way of us sharing our work and making an international debut. 

Photo Credit: Ali Wright

HOW YOU CAN HELP:. 

We’re raising £7500.00 to cover the cost of flying five performers to Australia and back. These guys are incredible and as such we’re committed to ensuring that they get what they deserve, which is Equity UK approved rates and a nice place to stay when they arrive downunder! Supporting their expenses abroad is a vital part of this project’s success but definitely not something we can achieve on our lonesome. 

Photo Credit: Jack Parker

THE JOURNEY SO FAR:

There are two shows heading to Australia and we can hear you asking, what are they?

 Post-Mortem

Check out this video from the amazing Jack Parker below:

Post-Mortem is a new play by Iskandar R. Sharazuddin (who is also the co-founder of Ellandar), he’s also performing in the piece. It has been directed by Jessica Rose McVay (who is the Creative Director of 45North). This show is the cornerstone of our relationship as two companies. It is the first collaboration between Iskandar & Jessica as a creative team and as producing partners. 

But…what is it about?

Didn’t you just watch the video?

Post-Mortem is an unflinching, complex, and comedic look at the giddy joy of young love, the trauma which outlives it, and the lies we tell ourselves when love dies. It is the story of Alex and Nancy, who meet 10-years after the end of their obsessive and lovesick teenage relationship at their mutual best friends’ wedding. They are suddenly confronted with each other’s mismatching memories; each one has a different version of events as to how ended all those years ago. They begin a dissection of their lives and ask questions like, who hurt who? And who is holding on to that trauma too tightly? 

We premiered this show at in London and Edinburgh Fringe and some people seemed to really like it, case in point: 

★★★★★ Sue in the Stalls 

★★★★★ Three Weeks Edinburgh

★★★★★ The Mumble

★★★★ Broadway Baby

★★★★ The List 

★★★★ Spy in the Stalls 

★★★★ Edinburgh Culture Review

(un)written · (un)heard

The second show is called (un)written · (un)heard. It’s a second collaboration between Iskandar and Jessica but this time they decided to get a bunch of other creatives involved, including two early-career female choreographers and some grossly talented dance artists. Watch our promo video here (again from the luminous Jack Parker): 

What is that one about? 
 

Uhm… did you even listen to us? Ah, you’re a text-based person. GREAT! 

Well. This one is a WORLD PREMIERE which we’re bringing to Fringe World Festival at the Girls School. It is a dance-theatre work about Dorothy Lawrence…

Who?

Yeah, we thought you’d say that. Dorothy Lawrence is the only known British woman soldier who served on the front line in World War I. She should be a big deal but she’s not. Why? Why else…? Because her story was heavily redacted by the War Office, the post-war British government, and the patriarchy. This show is our attempt to right a wrong, to give a platform to an unwritten and unheard story of a woman who should have a great legacy. Sadly, Dorothy’s life ended in a lunatic asylum where she spent 40 years of her life, we want to share this tale of resilience and strength and place this woman at the centre of her own narrative, once and for all. 

BUT…AUSTRALIA?

Photo Credit: Jack Parker

Mmhm. Point. 

Well. Ellandar Ltd. was actually co-founded in Western Australia in 2010 where we made work until 2016. We still feel pretty Australian. In fact, we feel like we grew up at The Blue Room Theatre, which is the first venue on our whirlwind downunder tour.

The Blue Room Theatre is a home for independent theatre in Western Australia. It supports amazing local talent and international artists. It is such a special moment for us to bring some work back to where it all began.

(un)written · (un)heard will be at the Girls School. A new (old) venue which is doing some really cool stuff. Seriously, this is where the cool kids of theatre will be…

Finally, in Adelaide we’re going to be calling Holden Street Theatres, who present a crackly, electric, and damn explosive season of theatre at the Fringe every year. We’re pretty stoked to be there! 

As Ellandar is returning to where it all began for us, where we grew up we want to bring back home some of the collaborators we've met along the way. So, 45North a company with an ambition to shake the theatre world with exciting female-led work can introduce themselves with a bang! 

THAT’S A LOT OF MONEY…

You’re telling us!

And the way this works is if we don't achieve our target we're going to struggle to support ourselves while we're in Australia. So, please check out our rewards and drop us whatever you can! It’s Christmas…nearly. So, don’t buy any of us anything, just support us on our way to achieve this massive goal! It’s always a big deal to ask friends and family for money, we know, but we’re extremely proud of the work we make together and we’re so excited to share it with Australian audiences for the first time. Every penny, cent, dollar, and pound means so much to us. So you know… harness the saying:

“In for a penny, in for a pound” 

AND, if you’re in the U.K. then your support will mean a tremendous amount. These shows will have future lives in Ol’ Blighty after we conquer Australia so you’ll be serving our future and for that we’ll be forever grateful. 

For now thanks and bye from the team at 45North & Ellandar. 

Emily, Iskandar, Jessica, and Simon!
story_txt:
THE BIG GOAL:Hello! Thanks so much for reading and finding out more about what we are doing! First question you have, is surely who are we? Well, 45North and Ellandar are two independent London-based theatre companies, we both like to make multidisciplinary work (which is a fancy way of saying we make shiny new theatre). Together we’ve been making work for the past 18 months and in 2020 we have some big goals. The biggest goal, so far, is to take not one, but TWO new productions to Australia for Fringe World Festival in Western Australia and Adelaide Fringe, after both festivals programmed our work! This is super-duper exciting but in order to do this, we need your help to remove some of the pesky financial barriers that get in the way of us sharing our work and making an international debut. Photo Credit: Ali WrightHOW YOU CAN HELP:. We’re raising £7500.00 to cover the cost of flying five performers to Australia and back. These guys are incredible and as such we’re committed to ensuring that they get what they deserve, which is Equity UK approved rates and a nice place to stay when they arrive downunder! Supporting their expenses abroad is a vital part of this project’s success but definitely not something we can achieve on our lonesome. Photo Credit: Jack ParkerTHE JOURNEY SO FAR:There are two shows heading to Australia and we can hear you asking, what are they? Post-Mortem
Check out this video from the amazing Jack Parker below:Post-Mortem is a new play by Iskandar R. Sharazuddin (who is also the co-founder of Ellandar), he’s also performing in the piece. It has been directed by Jessica Rose McVay (who is the Creative Director of 45North). This show is the cornerstone of our relationship as two companies. It is the first collaboration between Iskandar & Jessica as a creative team and as producing partners. But…what is it about?Didn’t you just watch the video?Post-Mortem is an unflinching, complex, and comedic look at the giddy joy of young love, the trauma which outlives it, and the lies we tell ourselves when love dies. It is the story of Alex and Nancy, who meet 10-years after the end of their obsessive and lovesick teenage relationship at their mutual best friends’ wedding. They are suddenly confronted with each other’s mismatching memories; each one has a different version of events as to how ended all those years ago. They begin a dissection of their lives and ask questions like, who hurt who? And who is holding on to that trauma too tightly? We premiered this show at in London and Edinburgh Fringe and some people seemed to really like it, case in point: ★★★★★ Sue in the Stalls ★★★★★ Three Weeks Edinburgh★★★★★ The Mumble★★★★ Broadway Baby★★★★ The List ★★★★ Spy in the Stalls ★★★★ Edinburgh Culture Review(un)written · (un)heardThe second show is called (un)written · (un)heard. It’s a second collaboration between Iskandar and Jessica but this time they decided to get a bunch of other creatives involved, including two early-career female choreographers and some grossly talented dance artists. story:
THE STORY 

W.A.R. is an original musical production in the making by one of Atlanta’s most treasured and brilliant directors, Freddie Hendricks.  

ABOUT THE DIRECTOR 

Freddie Hendricks was the founder and former Artistic Director of The Freddie Hendricks Youth Ensemble of Atlanta (YEA), Atlanta’s premier African American youth theater company.  Hendricks has been transforming the lives of young people and artists for decades. His body of work includes over 20 critically acclaimed productions that tackle contemporary issues such as child abuse, teen pregnancy, HIV and AIDS, youth violence, and apartheid. His latest creation, W.A.R. (We Anit Right) follows suit by tackling issues within the African American community and Mental Health. W.A.R. is the beginning of a movement in finding our truth, battling our inner struggles, and winning the war for self-love. Click here to learn more about Hendricks. 

ABOUT W.A.R 

In a world where our internal wars inevitably trigger external conflict, this revolutionary production takes you on a journey that explores and asks questions about the terrain of our humanity. Through music representing the heartbeat of the dirty south, movement with a funky militaristic cadence, breathtaking multi-media, and riveting storytelling culminating in a life-changing feel-good experience. Set on an urban street where we all must rise because the court is in session. The judge sets the stage as the defense team begins to present the case of why WE AIN’T RIGHT. The prosecution team argues if it ain’t broke then why fix it. As the two sides battle, a gritty ensemble takes the stand as the sound of war echoes through the street. In this battle for the love of self where the people speak, the audience is the jury and love is the winner.

RALLYING THE TROOPS

If you are going to win a W.A.R, then you need a mighty army of supporters who are willing to get in the trenches with you. We are rallying the troops to get involved with this production by becoming a sponsor, investor, or by contributing. We are grateful to already have a brigade of amazing artists, theater professionals, musicians, and producers working behind the scenes to produce this masterful piece. We just need your help advancing this production to the next rank.  

At the helm of the team is Executive Producer Dr. James Berry. Dr. Berry is working with Hendricks to launch this fundraising campaign. If you are interested in joining the production team, becoming an investor, or sponsor, email fhx2021@gmail.com if you have additional questions.

BOOTS ON GROUND 

​Production will not start without an approved detailed budget. The budget contains all elements of the equipment: costumes, set, location, actors, and crew for starters.  The current estimate is $500,000  for a 10-day shooting schedule, subsequent editing, and delivery materials. 

Support the production by becoming a sponsor. The higher the rank the more perks that you receive for your level of commitment. Click here to see the full benefits of each sponsorship level. Our goal is to workshop the production and film it to be pitched to a major network. We want to bring the message of self-love and healing to audiences worldwide.

The use of funds raised will go towards pre-production, production, post-production & publicity. After the completion of the film screenplay, films bible, film's look book, and a sizzle reel, W.A.R. has many distribution options. We will pitch the film to the major networks – NBC, CBS, FOX, ABC as well as cable companies such as FX, HBO, HISTORY, SHOWTIME, AMC, USA, TBS – AND STREAMING – NETFLIX, AMAZON, HULU.

Your generous contribution will go towards the following:

  • Writer's 
  • Production 
  • Talent
  • Music
  • Sound
  • Set
  • Lighting
  • Wardrobe
  • Travel
  • Facilities
  • Promotion/publicity/advertising
  • Administration

TIMELINE:

 

Click here to learn more about how to become a sponsor.

 

LOVE IS THE ANSWER

The state of internal conflict that inhabits our minds and infects our spirit and debilitated our soul and eventually leads us to a demilitarized zone where love is the enemy. – Freddie Hendricks

As a part of our community outreach initiatives, we will be working with various organizations in the community whose mission is mental health and wellness. Our goal is to provide workshops with actors and the general public that address the themes from the production.

POSSIBLE SNAFU

With every battle, there will be some challenges. Not having enough resources to advance the show to the next stage is the main issue that we are facing. No contribution is too small. Thank you in advance. 

STAY CONNECTED 

We want you to stay connected with the show. Join us on social media, ask folks to get the word out, and use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out.

https://www.freddiehendricks.com/

Click the link below for full sponsorship benefits. 

Check the website for full benefits  https://www.freddiehendricks.com/w-a-r.

story:
Hey there!

Maggie and Annaliese here. We're back! Did you miss us? We sure missed you! After a successful crowdfunding campaign this past spring, and a full run of Shakespeare's The Tempest, we are back seeking support for our next adventure! Coming up in February 2020 - Shakespeare's Measure for Measure, and we are just $7,000 shy of our goal to fully fund this exciting piece!

What is Measure for Measure and why is it relevant?! 

Known as one of Shakespeare's problem plays, we will immerse the audience in this unfinished conversation on justice, corruption, morality, and mercy.

The Duke of Vienna vanishes abruptly leaving Lord Angelo as his successor. In his stead, Angelo enacts his own sense of justice causing mass chaos throughout the city. The only person who can stop him now is a nun-in-training, named Isabella. A story of power, those who abuse it, and those who suffer at their hands. Does this sound familiar?

This piece, directed by the vibrant Michael Fleischer and with an entirely female production team, will not shy away from male toxicity. We intend to lean into what makes this piece a problem play. Exploring a broken justice system built by men, how and when people can use their voice, and a battle of wills between two people who claim to be guided by faith in a Vienna dominated by egos, idols and debauchery.

The magnitude of this story and the sobering reality of the ending can only be brought to reality with your help!

What We Need

Let's break it down folx! $7,000.00 will provide:

  • 50 hours of rehearsal space
  • All construction materials and labor needed for the set and the costumes
  • Paying every single artist involved: the actors, the design team, and the production team
  • Insurance, printing costs, marketing and manpower

What You Get

The satisfaction of helping young artists create meaningful work to impact modern audiences....

ALSO SWAG! See what rewards come with the different giving levels to the right of this campaign!

... But like, a dope immersive theatrical experience that will make you think and leave you wanting and give you something to do in the dead of winter.

The Impact

On a more serious note, this particular piece is very personal and meant to create space and conversation around the toxicity that is coming to light in the world at large and specifically in entertainment. This campaign and your involvement can and will make this possible. 

This is an opportunity to speak up in the #metoo movement and present a difficult conversation that does not yet have a resolution.

This will be our 5th fully mounted theatrical production with a limited run. 3 years in, as a little but fierce company, we exist entirely due to continued financial support - we would be unable to do any of this without you! We are humbled and grateful and ask for your support yet again as we forge ahead.

Challenges

The reality is that space rental costs in NYC continue to be the largest hurdle for our small company when it comes to our productions. While we are working towards being a self-sustaining company, we haven't grown to that place YET! We have big dreams (including our desire and plans to partner with prison outreach Shakespeare initiatives, provide ongoing workshops for adults and children, and build accessibility in the communities around us) and these dreams require big funds. We operate on an extremely low budget in the theater community keeping our productions under $12,000.00. Every donation makes a difference! We've had amazing responses to our productions and community events, we continue to foster the collaborative nature of our company, and with each year we are growing in our abilities and expertise in this field. We are incubator members of the Alliance of Resident Theatres (A.R.T./New York), we are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, and we are a proud contributor to the Indie Theater Fund. 

Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Here are some additional ways to show your support:

Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign! Share, post, re-post, and use those social media platforms to reach those people you know, and those you really don't know.

Any amount you can donate, be it $5, $50, $500, is an immense help to us and our forward momentum. 

 

No Name Website

Instagram: @wearethenoname

Facebook: @wearethenonamecollective

story:
ARISTOS: THE MUSICAL sings the story of doomed heroes Achilles and Patroclus through a heartbreaking pop/soft rock score. An Iliad adaptation written by young Stanford alumni Muse Lee and Aaron Reed, Aristos enjoys a devoted global fanbase that has carried the fast-rising new musical from reading to production to album.

Though COVID-19 halted our Bay Area premiere, Aristos sings on. Our album, slated for a winter release, involves nearly fifty cast and creative team members from around the world. A diverse group that ranges from ages 13 to 70 and hails from seven different countries, the artists rehearse online and record safely from their own homes. 

ARISTOS will be holding a four-week fundraiser in order to recoup our production costs. Not only will this cover the labor and expertise of our team (performers and producers alike) as well as the hardware required for recording, but this will also help us to distribute our album across as many platforms as possible - including Spotify, Apple Music, and more.

This fundraiser would also go towards the production of affordable merch such as stickers, t-shirts, and more!

We have a goal of $3,000. It sounds like a lot, we know. (Believe us, we know.) But ARISTOS has and always will be a project based in community. Our community launched us over a year ago when this musical was a casual staged reading born from a single song, and our community has carried us all the way to our international cast album with professionals around the world. And we know our community can carry us just a little further - home to Ithaca.

Thank you so much for your support, and we can't wait to sail to Ithaca and share our album with you!

story:
“Love on the Dole portrays what life means to a young man living under the shadow of the dole, the tragedy of a lost generation who are denied consummation, in decency, of the natural hopes and desires of youth.” – Walter Greenwood

Changing Face Collective presents Love on the Dole by Ronald Gow & Walter Greenwood; a play that captures the painful reality of the 1920s governmental welfare cuts to the working class and the rise of socialism. It follows the story of Sally Hardcastle – the modern woman -who becomes her family’s sole breadwinner. In love with political activist Larry Meath, she dreams of escape from the murky streets of Salford.

Although first performed over 85 years ago, Love on the Dole draws many parallels to our political and social climate now, reminding us that history is in a constant state of repetition. This government’s austerity driven ideology – a bitter symptom leftover from the 2008 financial crisis – is reminiscent of the savage cuts of the 1929 Great Depression.

Directed by Lucy Curtis, the play is a collaborative production by Changing Face Collective. The Brixton-based collective specialises in documentary theatre, international new-writing and rediscoveries. Love on the Dole will follow on from the company’s sell-out run of Where Will We Live? at the Southwark Playhouse.


What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we're hoping to raise £1,300 and your contribution will go towards covering the following costs:

- Rehearsal Spaces

- Leaflets and Posters

- Programmes

- Technician Hire

story_txt:
“Love on the Dole portrays what life means to a young man living under the shadow of the dole, the tragedy of a lost generation who are denied consummation, in decency, of the natural hopes and desires of youth.” – Walter Greenwood

Changing Face Collective presents Love on the Dole by Ronald Gow & Walter Greenwood; a play that captures the painful reality of the 1920s governmental welfare cuts to the working class and the rise of socialism. It follows the story of Sally Hardcastle – the modern woman -who becomes her family’s sole breadwinner. In love with political activist Larry Meath, she dreams of escape from the murky streets of Salford.
Although first performed over 85 years ago, Love on the Dole draws many parallels to our political and social climate now, reminding us that history is in a constant state of repetition. This government’s austerity driven ideology – a bitter symptom leftover from the 2008 financial crisis – is reminiscent of the savage cuts of the 1929 Great Depression.
Directed by Lucy Curtis, the play is a collaborative production by Changing Face Collective. The Brixton-based collective specialises in documentary theatre, international new-writing and rediscoveries. Love on the Dole will follow on from the company’s sell-out run of Where Will We Live? at the Southwark Playhouse.

What We Need & What You Get

 
With your help, we're hoping to raise £1,300 and your contribution will go towards covering the following costs:
- Rehearsal Spaces
- Leaflets and Posters
- Programmes
- Technician Hire
- Set Design and Props
- Costumes 
- Casting and hopefully a wage for the actors involved

Our Cast (So Far)
Sally Hardcastle - Jess Cummings
Harry Hardcastle - Sam Heron
Larry Meath - Oliver Scullion
Helen Hawkins - Lucy Curtis
Sam Grundy - Thomas-Jan Johnston
Charlie - Alex Eagles

story:
ABOUT LONE STAR
Four years ago, a few creative Texans met in New York City. Still struggling to find a theatre home, they decided to build it for themselves. Since then, Lone Star has built an active community of theater artists and audiences--people from Texas, people who love people from Texas, and people who wish they were from Texas. 

Lone Star has developed the work over 25 playwrights through its Texas Reads Series, presented the work of 4 composers in the annual Concert Series, and fostered dozens of new artistic collaborations through our community events. 

THIS SEASON

This year marks the beginning of Lone Star's Artist in Residence Program. Our inaugural Robert Askins Playwriting Fellows are Alan Charnock, Nilsa Reyna, Judith Leora, Emily Comisar, Benjamin Wright, and David Davila. 

Here's our line-up:

Alien Sex Comedy by Alan Charnock (November 19th)
David Davila and the Magic Time Machine by David Davila (January 25th)
Switzerland by Emily Comisar (February 22nd)
Showpony by Judith Leora (March 21st)
4th Annual Texas Reads Short Play Festival (April 18th)

COMMUNITY FIRST

From the beginning, Lone Star was never just about the art. We firmly believe that creating space for artists and audiences to build personal relationships with one another improves the entire theater experience. That's why the first Monday of every month, we host Lone Star Happy Hours. Everything we do, we do with a little bit of flair and a whole lot of Texas hospitality.

THE BUDGET

The $3000 raised here will cover our programming budget for the season.  There are four readings scheduled (a total cost of $1,500) and one concert (another $1,500). We will be engaging in other fundraising activities through-out the season to cover administrative and overhead costs.

Lone Star Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­‐‑profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Lone Star Theatre Company must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the good and services received is tax-­‐‑deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
An Experiement In Storytelling

URPO Arts is a collective of passionate dancers, musicians, actors, artists, and other various storytellers who seek to inspire and motivate others.

Our debut production, This Too Will Be Swept Away, will be premiering at the 2016 Orlando International Fringe Festival. The show is the story of a group of strangers, down on their luck, who find each other along the same path, all seeking a chance for change. TICKETS AVAILABLE NOW

Your Donation

We are seeking funding to cover all the startup costs associated with putting on a Fringe show. The upfront fees of the festival, which can be overwhelming for smaller acts, allows the Fringe to return 100% of the profits back to the artists. While we will get 100% of every dollar you give us, in the way of ticket sales, we won't see that till after the festival has come to a close. We're seeking to cover the production's immediate costs. Things like the venue fees, advertising costs, and of course pizza. It was good enough for the Turtles, right?

Beyond Fringe

“This Too Will Be Swept Away” is the first production of this scale from URPO Arts and the first step in taking on a new way of telling the story. Oh yes we dream of the Fringe and beyond. The team has been drawn together much in the way the players are drawn together in the show. We've come to a point where it's time to take this crazy dream of performing for a living and bring it to the world.
