story:
In 2000, under the nom de porn "Philip S. Wilson," writer / producer Mike Horowitz (Burn Notice, Prison Break) wrote an episode of the adult cable program Kama Sutra (which actually aired on television). He followed up with a sequel episode for a different adult program, Lady Chatterly’s Stories (which he co-wrote with Mikki Gillette), but it was tragically rejected for being too crazy. 

Those scripts sat, unloved, in his hard drive for years, until they were resurrected in 2015 for a one-night-only staged reading. The passionate response was undeniable, making it clear that it was just a matter of time before CARNAL DESIRE made a triumphant return to the stage, which it did in February of 2016. Not unsurprisingly, the encore performance caught the eye of a booker for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and when asked if we would be interested in taking CARNAL DESIRE to Scotland, our response was a polite but enthusiastic, "F*** yes."

The Cast

We're proud to announce our Fringe cast includes* (in alphabetical order, counterclockwise from top right) Brice Beckham, Laura Carswell, Riley Rose Critchlow, David Fickas, Josephine Ganner, Will Harris, Hillary Arlene Jones, Matthew Stauter, Adrienne Visnic, Kincaid Walker and Kirk Zipfel. More may be added as circumstances permit, so keep the bed warm! Oh, the anticipation.

*With 27 shows and possible guest stars stepping in, roles may rotate and some cast members will not be in all performances.

What We Need & What You Get

See for yourself! Here's something we made for a donor who claimed the "Brice & David Write You a Song" perk:


And here's another something for a donor who claimed the "Sexy VM Greeting From Brice" perk:


JUST ADDED: MERCH!

Grab some garb perks to show off your perky parts!

And look for this ALL NEW Fringe Concert T as a separate perk:


While very exciting and immesurably worthwhile, our trip to Scotland comes with large financial hurdles.  

Overall, our goal is to raise $40,000. That includes $25,000 from our Indiegogo campaign and an additional $15,000 from our Los Angeles Fundraising events:

  • June 10th: I MADE YOU A SEX TAPE - Drama 3/4's ongoing music variety series, "I Made You A Mix Tape," got a sexy makeover on June 10th at the legendary Hotel Cafe. The night featured a fantastic lineup of musicians and comedians and was a house-rocking success!
  • July 14th: CARNAL DESIRE LA - our last local show before we board the plane to Edinburgh included an after party with silent auction, adult beverages, surprise guests, giveaways and more! We had a sold-out crowd, and everyone left the theater clutching their sides and clamoring for more!
Where is this all going? Well, we're glad you asked. Our actors are generously donating their time and the show is designed to minimize production costs (no set, one crew member, rights to the scripts generously donated by Philip S. Wilson himself). Still, our trip across the pond includes several expenses that we can't cover without your support:
  • Being a part of the Fringe! $6800 : We have booked one of the Fringe Festival's hottest comedy venues - the Pleasance Theatre - for 27 performances between August 3rd and August 29th. This fee includes Fringe management, theatre deposit, rental, Fringe programs, and fees. We will also be splitting our ticket sales with the venue to cover the remaining rental so if we can help to offset this cost we can donate a higher percentage of our ticket sales to the causes listed below.
  • Lodging - $14,000:  This is our biggest cost. CARNAL DESIRE requires a cast of at least 7 actors, although ideally we would love to bring 10-14 cast members to make this production truly come to life. We will be renting a 5-6 bedroom house (or equivalent combination of flats) to squeeze our cast, crew and production team into for the run of the show. These prices run steep as space is at a premium during the festival.
  • Marketing - $4200: Built into the Edinburgh package is Edinburgh publicity! We know our friends in LA love us, but we're new to the Scotland scene so it's important to get the word out. 
If we exceed our fundraising goal, additional funds will go towards:
  • Helping with flights: Plane tickets from Los Angeles to Edinburgh average at about $1,200 - $1,400 each. We would love to help our core cast and production team with that cost.
  • Merchandise and advertising: Helps get the word out and increase our ticket sales!
  • Food: Actors need to be fed.
  • Travel expenses: internet hotspot, international cellphones, laundry services, ground transportation, baggage fees, Scotland's finest cocaine, etc. 

The Impact

Not only will your contribution help us bring this monumentally profound piece of performance art to the Edinburgh masses, but we also plan to use the relationships we build and the show's success to give back to the theatre community, specifically the USC School of Dramatic Arts.

  • We will be contributing a portion of our revenue to help fund an Independent Student Production at the USC School of Dramatic Arts in the 2016-2017 school year. The more we can offset the cost of our own theater rental, the more we can donate.
  • Many members of the cast and production team behind CARNAL DESIRE are USC alumni. Their hope is to bridge relationships that will eventually help bring student projects to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival once again, in memory of the late Theatre professor John Blankenchip and his long legacy of excursions abroad.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone can donate their hard earned cash and we get it! There are other ways to show your support for CARNAL DESIRE:

  • Share this campaign! Help us spread the word and share this page on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Reddit, or whatever else the kids are using these days. In fact, Indiegogo has some helpful built in tools to make it even easier to share the love!
  • Scotland connections! Know anyone in the UK? We'll have A LOT of seats to fill at the festival, so if you happen to know anyone who lives in the Edinburgh area - or any other performers or festival-goers who will be traveling to the Fringe as well - we would LOVE for you to spread the word about CARNAL DESIRE to the locals.
Thank you for your contribution to this grand adventure. We will forever discuss your sexual prowess.
With gratitude,
The CARNAL DESIRE team

story:
At Swim, Two Boys is a novel written by Jamie O’Neil and adapted for the stage by Tim Scott. It tells the story of Dun Laoghaire boys Jim and Doyler and their friendship on the brink of Irish independence. The play will be performed from the 6-18 June in the Samuel Beckett Theatre.

The project has been in the making for the last couple of months and even before the first performance we have been offered to extend the run by a week. While we are thrilled about this, it poses some financial problems, as we had not taken a second week into consideration in the budget. Most of the set, the costumes and some of lights need to be hired and the second week doubles these expenses. In order to cover them we would kindly ask for your help. Your donation will contribute considerably to the quality of the production.

story:
On behalf of Theatre Paradok, thank you for taking the time to look at our campaign page!

  • Theatre Paradok are an Edinburgh University based performing arts society that aim to put on productions that are experimental without being exclusive. Each semester we vote on a play, dedicate our time to it, and perform it. Since our conception in 2004, Paradok have performed in venues all over the city, often in places you wouldn’t expect to see theatre and expanded greatly.We thrive off the challenging and exciting. We like theatre that’s engaging, energetic and immersive. Above all, we value enthusiasm, collaboration and pure joy.

  • This year, our Edinburgh Fringe show is to be 'Mrs Dalloway', adapted and directed by Ellen Harris. This contemporary take on the classic novel explores the private consciousness we stream through our phones and computers as we interact. As the characters talk, trail-off to check a text, and half-listen to each other, the audience is privilege to what they are distracted by: Facebook stalking, weird YouTube videos, choosing a filter, and the rest. This multimedia production has a fantastic cast and crew and is set to be really exciting.

  • Putting on a show at the Edinburgh Fringe is hugely important to Paradok as it is the perfect platform for its ethos: a place where the dangerous and the experimental is embraced.
  • However it comes at huge cost - from Fringe Registration to venue hire to publicity - which is where we need YOUR help! 
  • Fundraising for shows can become really hard over the Fringe Festival as there are hundreds of shows doing the same, our usual pool of the student body are replaced by tourists and venue hire becomes extortionate.

Fundraising

Whilst we expect to raise 1/3-2/3 of the budget from ticket sales, we need to raise at least £500, and here is a breakdown of where the money goes:

  • Tech! One of the most exciting elements of this production is the film projection that relates to the internet activity of those on stage, however this requires considerable costs in equipment hire.
  • Publicity  - Posters, t-shirts, flyers - and buying advertising in the Fringe programme - are all vital to making sure we get people in to watch the show!
  • Fringe registration
  • Venue Hire
  • Insurance

Please do donate in any way you can, and please share this around!

With much love and thanks.

story:
Nepa Dance Academy

Everyday many students had been practicing their passion, DANCE, in the rented hall of NDA; however, the tragic earthquake in the country didn’t allow pursuing it. The house where NDA rented the flat for dance has been claimed to be at risk and because of this NDA has to move its practice hall somewhere else. As we don’t have any property or land, the practice has been completely disrupted. We are trying to collect fund and rebuild our academy to create more talented kids and also to encourage the lovers of dance to pursue their passion.

Nepa Dance Academy, NDA has been tremendously working hard since last five years to uplift dancing culture in the country by teaching varied forms of dance form from classic to modern, from ethnic form to international styles. About 40% of the students here are learning with scholarship and from remaining students only $6 per month is taken from each for regular training.

NDA has always been encouraging dancers and has produced lots of talented dancers who have successfully made their stand in different arena of dancing. Some of our students have won different titles in various contests in the country like: Kid Queen Nepal Miss Talent, Master Star, Clinic Plus Beautiful hair talent contest, Miss Nepal Miss Talent and many more. Likewise, our student has been finalist of Dance India Dance as well. Students of NDA have performed in different programs like welcoming Shah Rukh Khan in Nepal, out of valley programs, talent contest and many more. Many of our students are National level champions. Our students have always been our pride and it has always been a great experience to teach dance for little kids and so the elder ones.

NDA, itself, has organized a dance reality show Mega dance competition which took heights among the public. NDA has conducted different workshop program and has also taken students abroad for workshop and culture program. Not only nationally but internationally as well NDAians have won the heart of people whether it is a culture exchange program or purely a dance competition.

A school has provided hall for 2 months for practice and there is no place then after to continue the training. Therefore, we are planning to build a whole new building of NDA with full facility but it seems to be a very difficult task with our source of income and budget. We aspire to continue this journey of dance to another level and we can only do it with the support from our well wishers in this time of crisis.

Talent, Master Star, Clinic Plus Beautiful hair talent contest, Miss Nepal Miss
Talent and many more. Likewise, our student has been finalist of Dance India
Dance as well. Students of NDA have performed in different programs like
welcoming Shah Rukh Khan in Nepal, out of valley programs, talent contest and
many more. Many of our students are National level champions. Our students have
always been our pride and it has always been a great experience to teach dance
for little kids and so the elder ones.
NDA, itself, has organized a
dance reality show Mega dance competition which took heights among the public. NDA
has conducted different workshop program and has also taken students abroad for
workshop and culture program. Not only nationally but internationally as well
NDAians have won the heart of people whether it is a culture exchange program
or purely a dance competition.
A school has provided hall for 2
months for practice and there is no place then after to continue the training. Therefore,
we are planning to build a whole new building of NDA with full facility but it
seems to be a very difficult task with our source of income and budget. We aspire
to continue this journey of dance to another level and we can only do it with
the support from our well wishers in this time of crisis.

story:
NOTE:  Our funding needs have changed.  Rather than seeking $17, 400, we now only need $8,475.  This will be enough to pay for the venue and performance rights.

Blind Ambition 

Hi!! My name is Lee and I am a legally blind director having partial vision in one eye and none in the other.  I am partnering with my friend and co-producer, Jordan, to pursue our dreams of artistic excellence by bringing Neil Simon's "Barefoot in the Park" to the beautiful Fremont Centre Theatre in Pasadena, CA this summer.  Through the years, I have worked through struggles such as vision loss, being orphaned, and an ongoing battle with depression.  In the midst of these challenges, the opportunity to cultivate my passion in theatre has given me strength to make it through  As theatre has been a driving force for Jordan as well, here we are ready to make some magic!  We have successfully pulled this off previously in 2013 with our production of "Almost, Maine", so we know we can do it again! But this  is not possible without YOUR HELP!

Thank you for your interest in this project!

Lee

(Read my full story:  https://leepugsley.wordpress.com/2015/05/26/a-dream-that-drives/)

Why "Barefoot in the Park"?  

Neil Simon's "Barefoot in the Park" takes a comical look at the lives of newlywed couple, Paul and Corie.  He's a serious lawyer and she's a free-spirited woman ready for fun.  After a six day honeymoon, they find themselves grappling with the realities of married life in a small, fifth story New York apartment.  While hilarious, this story relates to anyone who is married and in relationships.  It confronts us with that moment when we realize what we expected from the other person is not always what we get.  Once we discover this, we are faced with the question "Where do I go from here?" and that is exactly what this play sheds light on.  It is also the reason we want to bring this show to Los Angeles audiences.  

What We Need...

"Barefoot in the Park" is slated for a 4 weekend engagement running from August 21st through September 13th at the Fremont Centre Theatre in South Pasadena, CA.  This is an incredible opportunity, but a Goliath of an undertaking.  In order to give it wings, we need:

  • $6,600 - Fremont Centre Theatre Venue Rental for a 4 weekend run 
  • $1,875 - Performance Rights (15 performances) 
  • $2,500 -  Marketing (media, PR, flyers, promotional manager).
  • $2,000 - Tech (lighting, house manager, set)
  • This is a Flexible Fundraiser. Any funds given will go right towards the production, regardless of reaching our goal or not. 

The Impact!

If we reach our goal (or beyond), it will be BECAUSE OF YOU and this is the difference you will make:

  • Up to 1,200 people will be given the gift of laughter through high quality entertainment, which explores relevant issues and timeless themes
  • It would be a stepping stone for us to build a non-profit theatre company that is able to give back to the community, support fellow artists, and allow us to continue pursuing our passion. 
  • It would allow us to continue producing shows at the Fremont Centre Theatre, thus becoming a resident company at the venue.  We would be able to continue bringing classic and contemporary works to the stage and eventually branch into new works as well.
  • It would pave the way for us to be able to offer free acting workshops, artist scholarships, theatre camps, 24-hour playwright festivals, etc.
  • A community of people and businesses would be united.  When the arts are present, a community thrives
  • It would be a dream come true for Lee and Jordan and the tears of joy would start flowing!
“Wow, this is so great. Snow in New York, isn't it romantic? 
"Only if you love empty theatres." - Neil Simon

What YOU Can Do!!!

Even if you are unable to contribute funds, SHARE, SHARE, SHARE!!!  This is seriously just as important as anything monetary!!  Help us create excitement by giving us a shout-outs on: 

  • E-mail blasts
  • Conversations with family and friends
  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Instagram
  • Youtube
  • Snapchat
  • Vine
  • A huge tattoo on your back
  • Dumping a bucket of ice water on your head
  • Naming your first born child after a character in Barefoot in the Park

Any questions? 

Contact us! 
  • Jordan: https://www.facebook.com/jordanthickling
  • Lee: https://www.facebook.com/leeypugsley?fref=ts
  • Check out the Fremont Centre Theatre: http://www.fremontcentretheatre.com/
  • Check out Rampid at:  http://rampidproductions.com/ 
  • Almost, Maine: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-qP-SO2ji-w

story:
Chicken Bank Collective.
Weaving Communities Across Borders through the Art of Movement.

Tejiendo comunidades entre fronteras a través del arte del movimiento.

Please look below for translation in Spanish. Para la versión en español dirígete hacia abajo.

One year ago, a small group of dance artists from México and the US sat together and imagined the possibility of continuing our work together, of meeting 3 times a year to make new work, to share with our communities, to teach and perform and to make dance films that give us and our audience a broader view of our art form. 

Individually, we are each active artists in our own communities.  Together, we are a collective committed to collaboration, holding ourselves and each other to our highest standard.  We all bring a unique voice and spirit to this collective and this is what strengthens our work. 

We believe that through our work as artists and collaborators, we are sharing and demonstrating a way of being and working together for common goals. These goals are to encourage creativity, empathy, compassion, generosity and trust. As we work collectively, each of us shares our own perspective and approach to art making. By collaborating, each artist supports and is supported while expanding and stretching into new territory. 

In October 2014, we raised just enough money to cover our expenses in order to hold our first CBC residency in Boulder, CO.  Since then, our work has continued and we have gathered a 2nd time in Boulder for dance making and performing, building our new website, creating a schedule and budget for the next 12 months and embarking on this, our first annual fundraiser!  

Hace un año, un pequeño grupo de artistas de la danza y el movimiento de México y Estados Unidos, nos reunimos para imaginar la posibilidad de continuar nuestro trabajo juntas, reuniéndonos tres veces al año para crear un nuevo proyecto que pudiéramos compartir con nuestras comunidades a través de la docencia,  la presentación de nuestro trabajo escénico y la creación de video danzas que nos permitan, así como a nuestros públicos expander las perspectivas de nuestra disciplina.

Individualmente, somos artistas activas en nuestras respectivas comunidades. Juntas somos un colectivo comprometido con la colaboración,  nos apoyamos mutuamente hacia nuestros mayores estándares.

Creemos que a través de nuestro trabajo como artistas y colaboradoras, estamos compartiendo y demostrando una manera de trabajar juntas para alcanzar metas comunes. Estas metas son incentivar la creatividad, la empatía, la compasión, la generosidad y la confianza. En nuestro trabajo colectivo, cada una comparte una perspectiva única y un acercamiento particular al proceso creativo  y artístico.

En octubre del 2014, logramos reunir el suficiente dinero para cubrir nuestros gastos y consolidar nuestra primera residencia en Boulder, Colorado (EUA). Desde entonces nuestro trabajo ha continuado y nos hemos reunido por segunda ocasión en Boulder para la creación y presentación de una obra de danza, para construir nuestra página web y para desarrollar la calendarización y presupuesto de nuestros siguientes 12 meses de trabajo; y embarcadas en esto: nuestra primera recaudación anual de fondos!

This is it: ONE ANNUAL FUNDRAISER!
Esto es definitivo: una única campaña de recaudación al año!!!!

By contributing, you will help us cover the costs for:

Colorado Residency, USA. April 2015 
2 weeks based in Boulder, CO with one workshop at Colorado College, a performance of our new work ALLOY  + a storytelling concert by Paola Suculima De La Concha Zindel in Colorado Springs, 2 additional performances of ALLOY + Paola's concert in Boulder (here's our trailer!). 

West Coast Residency, USA. October 2015
3 weeks in Washington, Oregon and California to make, film and perform Zap McConnell's new project, Secondary Succession.  Secondary Succession will use the ruins of coastal military forts as visual landscapes for a new dance for film. Once created to protect the borders during WWI and WWII, now encroached on by the natural world and often repurposed as state parks and artist centers, these architecturally intriguing structures are already telling many stories.  We will listen, then tell our own.
WEEK 1: We will begin by exploring movement, installation and site specific response to the influences of: military history, moss, Japanese internment camps, Northwest Native American tribes, reservations, parachutes and hot air balloons, Fukushima, the jet stream, pirates and redwoods.Then we will film.
WEEK 2: We will work on building a garden at a permaculture based sustainable community in exchange for space, as we create a live performance based on our film creation. Then we will perform the show there and in Portland, OR.
WEEK 3: Some of us will remain on the West Coast and crush the editing of the film; taking advantage of our time together. When the 3 weeks is up, the project is completed! Then we share it; at planned showings in each of our communities and applying to Dance for Film Festivals. 

Cholula Residency, México. February 2016
2 weeks in Cholula, Puebla, México where Cinthia Pérez Navarro will direct CBC in her new project, Permeabilidad Espontánea.  In this work, we will experiment with our permeable bodies when interacting with subjects that are currently raiding Mexicans and Americans across our borders. Permeabilidad Espontánea, rises as a multidisciplinary contemporary dance work that will underline and unveil social and environmental justice issues through the participants’ kinesthetic senses and as a collective response from our individual perspectives.  In Cholula, we will create, perform and offer workshops in the community.

Charlottesville Residency, USA. May 2016
2 weeks in Charlottesville, VA to conduct the annual business of CBC, as well as  share all that we have created in the last year through workshops and live performance.

During each and every residency, we are committed to reaching out to our hosting community with classes and performances.  As much as possible, classes will be free and open to the public and performance ticket prices will be donation based. 


Residencia en Colorado, EUA 2015

2 semanas de base en Boulder, Colorado; un taller en el Colegio Colorado (Colorado College), la presentación de nuestra nueba obra ALLOY + un concierto y cuentacuentos dirigido por Paola de la Concha Zindel en Colorado Springs; y dos presentaciones adicionales de ALLOY + el concierto de Paola en Boulder. (Aquí nuestro trailer!)

Residencia en la Costa Oeste, Estados Unidos. Octubre, 2015.

3 semanas en Washington, Oregon y California para construir, filmar y presentar el nuevo proyecto de Zap McConnell, Secondary Succession. Secondary Succession usará las ruinas de los fuertes militares como paisajes visuales para un nuevo film de danza para la cámara. Creado originalmente para proteger las fronteras durante la Primera y Segunda Guerras Mundiales, este espacio se encuentra actualmente tomado por el mundo natural. Frecuentemente estos espacios son retomados y reactivados por el estado para convertirse en parques  o centros artísticos. Estas intrigantes esculturas arquitectónicas, tal y como se encuentran, ya tienen tantas historias que contarnos. Nosotras escucharemos para después relatar la propia.

SEMANA 1: Comenzaremos explorando movimiento, instalación y trabajo in-situ,  respondiendo a las influencias de la historia militar, el musgo, los campamentos de reclusión japonesa, las tribus nativas de Norteamérica, las reservas, paracaídas y globos aerostáticos, Fukushima, el jet stream, los piratas y los bosques de los gigantes sequoyas. Después filmaremos.

SEMANA 2: Trabajaríamos construyendo un jardín de permacultura en una comunidad sustentable a cambio de espacio, mientras creamos una presentación en vivo basada en la creación audiovisual. Luego presentaremos en este lugar y en Portland, Oregon.

SEMANA 3: Algunas de nosotras permaneceremos en la Costa Oeste para terminar el proceso de edición y así aprovechar nuestro tiempo juntas.  Cuando terminen las 3 semanas el proyecto quedará concluído y estrá listo para ser compartido en presentaciones que programaremos en nuestras respectivas comunidades y aplicaremos a festivales de videodanza.

Residencia en Cholula, México. Febrero 2016.

2 semanas en Cholula, Puebla, México, en donde Cinthia Pérez Navarro dirigirá CBC en su nuevo proyecto: Permeabilidad Espontánea. En este trabajo, experimentaremos con la permeabilidad de nuestros cuerpos al interactuar con temas que actualmente se encuentran ....mexicanos y estadounidenses en el cruce de nuestras fronteras. Permeabilidad Espontánea, se erige como una obra de danza contemporánea, colaborativa y multidisciplinaria que subrayará y develará problemáticas en relación a la justicia social y ambiental a través del “sentido kinético” de los participantes y como una respuesta colectiva de nuestras perspectivas individuales.  En Cholula crearemos,  presentaremos la obra y ofreceremos tallertes a la comunidad.

Residencia en Charlottesville, Virgina. EUA. Mayo 2016

2 semanas en Charlottesville, Virginia para dirigir los asuntos administrativos de CBC, así como compartir lo que hemos creado a lo largo del año a través de talleres y presentaciones.

Durante todas y cada una de nuestras residencias, nos comprometemos a dar de vuelta y retribuir con clases y presentaciones a la comunidad que nos recibe. Tanto como sea posible, las clases y presentaciones serán gratuitas o propondremos que sean por donativo voluntario. 


We can't do this without you.  Thank you so much for your support!
No podríamos hacerlo sin ti. Gracias por tu apoyo!

Who we are and what are we all up to:

Zap McConnell, Pittsboro, NC, USA
Dancer, Choreographer, Director, Teacher, Filmmaker, Visual Artist, Activist

Paola Suculima De La Concha Zindel, Cholula, Puebla, México 
Dancer, Choreographer, Director, Filmmaker, Singer/Songwriter/Storyteller, Visual Artist, Activist

Cinthia Pérez Navarro, Cholula, Puebla, México
Dancer, Choreographer, Director, Teacher

Julie Rothschild, Boulder, CO, USA
Dancer, Choreographer, Director, Teacher

Denisse Cárdenas Landeros, México City, México
Dancer, Choreographer, Director, Teacher

Gabriela Bosquenegro, San Cristóbal, Chiapas, México
Filmmaker, Director, Photographer, Performer

Quiénes somos y qué hacemos:

Zap McConnell, Pittsboro, Carolina del Norte, EUA
Bailarina, coreógrafa, directora, docente, realizadora audiovisual, artista visual y activista. 

Paola Suculima De La Concha Zindel, Cholula, Puebla, México 
Bailarina, coreógrafa, directora, docente, realizadora audiovisual, cantautora, cuentacuentos, artista visual y activista. 

Cinthia Pérez Navarro, Cholula, Puebla, México
Bailarina, coreógrafa, directora y docente. 

Julie Rothschild, Boulder, CO, USA
Bailarina, coreógrafa, directora y docente. 

Denisse Cárdenas Landeros, Ciudad de México, México
Bailarina, coreógrafa, directora y docente.

Gabriela Bosquenegro, San Cristóbal, Chiapas, México
Realizadora audiovisual, Directora, Fotógrafa y Performer

PERKS:

T-SHIRT + TOTE BAG!

Beautiful Handmade Sconce by Zap McConnell (This is an example of Zap's work. Each light is unique.)!

Original Drawing by Paola De La Concha Zindel (this is an example of Paola's artwork)!

quedará concluído y estrá listo para ser compartido en presentaciones que
programaremos en nuestras respectivas comunidades y aplicaremos a festivales de
videodanza.
Residencia en
Cholula, México. Febrero 2016.
2 semanas en
Cholula, Puebla, México, en donde Cinthia Pérez Navarro dirigirá CBC en su
nuevo proyecto: Permeabilidad Espontánea.
En este trabajo, experimentaremos con la permeabilidad de nuestros cuerpos al
interactuar con temas que actualmente se encuentran ....mexicanos y
estadounidenses en el cruce de nuestras fronteras. Permeabilidad Espontánea, se erige como una obra de danza
contemporánea, colaborativa y multidisciplinaria que subrayará y develará
problemáticas en relación a la justicia social y ambiental a través del
“sentido kinético” de los participantes y como una respuesta colectiva de
nuestras perspectivas individuales.  En
Cholula crearemos,  presentaremos la obra
y ofreceremos tallertes a la comunidad.
Residencia en
Charlottesville, Virgina. EUA. Mayo 2016
2 semanas en
Charlottesville, Virginia para dirigir los asuntos administrativos de CBC, así
como compartir lo que hemos creado a lo largo del año a través de talleres y
presentaciones.
Durante todas y
cada una de nuestras residencias, nos comprometemos a dar de vuelta y retribuir
con clases y presentaciones a la comunidad que nos recibe. Tanto como sea
posible, las clases y presentaciones serán gratuitas o propondremos que sean
por donativo voluntario. 


We can't do this without you.  Thank you so much for your support!

No podríamos hacerlo sin ti.  Gracias por tu apoyo!

Quiénes somos y qué hacemos:Zap McConnell, Pittsboro, Carolina del Norte, EUABailarina, coreógrafa, directora, docente, realizadora audiovisual, artista visual y activista. Paola Suculima De La Concha Zindel, Cholula, Puebla, México Bailarina, coreógrafa, directora, docente, realizadora audiovisual, cantautora, cuentacuentos, artista visual y activista. Cinthia Pérez Navarro, Cholula, Puebla, MéxicoBailarina, coreógrafa, directora y docente. Julie Rothschild, Boulder, CO, USABailarina, coreógrafa, directora y docente. Denisse Cárdenas Landeros, Ciudad de México, MéxicoBailarina, coreógrafa, directora y docente.Gabriela Bosquenegro, San Cristóbal, Chiapas, MéxicoRealizadora audiovisual, Directora, Fotógrafa y Performer

T-SHIRT + TOTE BAG!

Beautiful Handmade Sconce by Zap McConnell (This is an example of Zap's work. Each light is unique.)!

Original Drawing by Paola De La Concha Zindel (this is an example of Paola's artwork)!

story:
Riveting Roses is Charleston's newest neoburlesque troupe, striving to uplift ourselves and our community via a dialogue initiated through movement and physicality. Classy but not classic, our performances move ourselves and our audience beyond the aesthetic to provoke thought, expose conflict, and transcend boundaries.

Our Fall 2015 production, "The Girliest Show On Earth", will pay homage to the glorious sideshows of the past.  A little strange, a little magical, and a lot entertaining - join us for all the astounding wonders!

Funds raised will be used for production costs and custom merchandise.

story:
a Leopold Group Collaboration with Zoe Nelson

We were thrilled to be asked to contribute to visual artist Zoe Nelson's upcoming exhibition.  Nelson's paintings are striking, emotive, and vibrant.  Having cut large shapes out of her canvases, she wanted to see bodies through the paintings (and vice versa).  That's where we come in.  Working with the same ideas that inspired Nelson's paintings (absence, wholeness, hole-ness, energetic shapes, and two-sided-ness), the Leopold Group has created a dance installation to accompany Nelson's work. But we're asking for your help to compensate the dancers for their hard work, time, and artistry. 

  • The dancers of the Leopold Group have rehearsed 6 hours a week for 5 months to prepare for this event.  
  • There are 5 dancers involved and they are all spectacular: Amanda Dye, Michelle Giordanelli, Alyssa Gregory, Rachel Molinaro, and Natalia Stamm
  • While you will not have to pay for a ticket (all shows are FREE!), consider making a donation towards the compensation of these dance artists. 

The beauty of this collaboration is how it has simplified our expenses.  We do not have to cover theater rental, lighting design, costumes, and some of the other big performances expenses (since we will be dancing in the midst of Zoe's existing art exhibit).  The downside is there will be no ticket revenue to help us compensate the dancers for their hard work.  We'd be eternally grateful if you would help us raise funds to compensate the five performers.

Dates/Times/Locations

The McAninch Art Center at the College of DuPage, Cleve Carney Art Gallery (Fawell and Park Blvds, Glen Ellyn Illinois) (http://www.cod.edu/gallery/ or (630) 942-2321)

  • Exhibit opening on Sunday Oct. 18th, a short (20 minute) performance around 6:15pm (this is a time change, from 7:15pm to 6:15pm)
  • Extended performances on Saturday Nov. 7th and Saturday Nov. 14th at 1pm
  • All events are free and open to the public!

The Impact

Not only is this opportunity an exciting artistic collaboration for the Leopold Group, it allows us to connect with new audiences - audiences from the College of DuPage neighborhood and gallery-going audiences who might not be familiar with modern dance.  For a small company, growing our audience is essential to our survival.  This project happens to be the perfect storm of artistic intrigue and audience outreach.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to the show!  It's FREE!  See you there :)

story:
“It is in collaboration that the nature of art is revealed.”   - Steve Lacy

Lost and Found in Collaboration

a laboratory presentation

produced by Michelle Ava & Tony Bernardi

Sunday November 1, 2015 at 8 pm - Jack Guidone Theater

On November 1, 2015 we launch The Joy of Collaboration Initiative, with an interdisciplinary artistic laboratory presentation that showcases the synergy of multiple diverse artistic expressions and demonstrates the dynamics of collaboration.

A number of short works in progress bring to light the joys and rewards of creative collaboration, cooperation, and interdependent relationships.  Here music and movement theater provide a visceral medium that allows audiences to experience the transformative challenges and rewards of partnering and co-creating in an exploratory space.


Joy of Collaboration

exploration, evolution, and expansion of expression through collaboration

Bringing decades of experience in collaborating with numerous choreographers, dancers, and movement enthusiasts, Michelle Ava introduces her new initiative, the Joy of Collaboration.  The vision of this 21st century endeavor is to create a space for integrating artists and artists’ works from a diverse tapestry of styles, disciplines, and forms.  This integrative dance laboratory space will promote and support interdisciplinary and intergenerational workshops, conferences, and performance productions that reflect our culture today. The aim is to promote learning and exploration in artistic collaboration and showcase innovative ideas that can make a significant contribution to the arts.

Michelle Ava’s methods, developed over four decades in teaching and the performing arts, enrich and ignite the launch of Joy of Collaboration.  Central to the idea of a laboratory space is the concept of "playshops" that provide a thoughtful but permitting space for exploration.  Innovative methods of facilitation and art direction guide playshop participants on how to collaboratively create and artistically extend beyond their boundaries.  These playshops freely incorporate expressive disciplines and artistic media such as improvisation, modern dance, music, structure and composition, form development, and mind body modalities among others.

The dancer, choreographer, spiritual explorer, and teacher, Michelle Ava, brings to the Joy of Collaboration initiative an informed holistic approach enriched by her lifelong journey of collaborations. Her passion that resulted in founding Joy of Motion is a testament to her dedication in guiding countless students to discover their own authentic dance. Now, by providing a space to explore the challenges and joys of integrating diverse artistic forces Michelle’s work enters its next evolutionary phase. This phase offers collaboration methods that explore and contrast artistic styles while illuminating interactions and their emotional contents. Collaborators are encouraged to experiment with invention and inspiration utilizing traditional and non-traditional improvisation techniques.  These methods deepen the connection with self, with others and with the environment in which artists coexist and co-create.  Experiments in this space can result in artistic growth opportunities for all collaborating parties. These opportunities often bloom into short-term or long-term relationships as well as performance productions that showcase this ensuing artistic magic – the unexpected miracles propagated by collaboration. 


Your support will be instrumental in funding:

  • Rehearsal rental of studio space for preparation for November 1st Concert 

  • Stipends /honorarium for the professional performing arts. Many of our performers will be volunteering their time and talents, however we are committed to provide all with stipends to compensate for some (dancers musicians, etc.) of their time and professional talent

  • Videographer and photographer for assembling visual slide and video presentation as part of the show and documenting the show

  • Creating and producing the concert program and other printed materials associated with the show 

  • Reception for guests at the show

  • Critical seed and startup funds for the Joy of Collaboration initiative to cover initial legal and business fees, administrative costs etc.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

CRITICAL POINT THEATRE was founded in 2013 by a number of purposed young artists. Their goal? Create an ensemble-governed space where new works were put through their paces, engaging in a lengthy critical process before opening. It's a theatre of thoughtfulness, in which we constantly ask ourselves if the stories we select are worth telling. Rather than jumping in, the question is why -- and more often, why not? Most recently, we are beginning a multi-year collaborative process that is seeking to explore righteousness versus justice. CPT emphasizes transmedia approaches that look to all mediums to broaden stories that emphasize places of difference between peoples and how stories might bridge those gaps.

OUR MISSION: We are inventors at our core. We seek to take in stories unknown, combine them with vision and action, and bring these experiences to life through performance. Our ensemble strives to pair our own development with that of changing communities. We want to stand among and between states of matter to explore beyond boundaries.

WHAT IS WHEN WE GROW UP?

This play is designed to answer the question: “Where does our value come from?”  Is value an intrinsic property that we all have? How are we defined by our jobs? What makes a job a career? Are we valuable because of our productiveness to society?  Our kindness and generosity to others?  What makes us important in a society that seems to reduce us into only the parts it wants back? What should we teach one another?

When We Grow Up is also, primarily, a game. You get to listen to us do our song-and-dance routine for 15 minutes and then decide how the next 45 minutes proceed. There are winners, game pieces, and a major test. In this show, we need YOU to actually create the play. It will be an immersive world that lasts long after the show is over, with permanent space set up amongst web and real-life spaces to keep talking. Instead of sitting back and relaxing, we want you to join the parade.

As a company, this show has been a milestone, too. When We Grow Up is the first play that we’ve created that cannot be attributed to a single playwright, and has been entirely generated through ensemble process from concept to production.  This play is the culmination of a year and a half of trying ideas, tearing them apart, and building them back up. 

OK, OK, BUT WHAT DO YOU NEED MONEY FOR?

We produce all of our shows independently, financing only from collective donations from individuals like you. It's next to impossible for artists without a long business history and legal help to obtain large grants, so we rely on small, grassroots funding campaigns like this one in order to produce our work.

Each donation counts towards getting live performance on stage. Critical Point Theatre is committed to paying all artists involved in the program a significant stipend to support their work as well as reimbursing their expenses. This show involves, at minimum, 10 artists firsthand!

Our technical presentation has to be minimal to accommodate a festival environment, but we want to be design geniuses with the resources we have. This show involves video from three angles, projections and original graphic design, and building a gizmo to end all gizmos (you'll see)! Your donation will be directly financing this part of our game.

HOW CAN I PLAY, TOO?

Our performances run from July 10th-July 26th at various times during the Capital Fringe Festival in Washington D.C.  We will be performing at WS Jenks & Son at 910 Bladensburg Rd NE. It's a hip spot in the middle of Trinidad. Plus, there's a lot of chances to see us.

July 11- 9:30 - July 16- 8:15 - July 18- 9:45 
July 19- 4:45 - July 24- 6:00 - July 26- 6:30

WE WANT TO INVOLVE YOU!

The most important gift we could receive for When We Grow Up is your presence at the show. This show literally cannot thrive without an active audience. If you live in the D.C. area and haven't been to Capital Fringe, it is truly a can't-miss, vibrant summer extravaganza.

·  Can you envision collaboration with your workplace or school? We'd love to help you with our skills as storytellers and artists in exchange for advertising space, goods or services, etc. Let us know how we can help! We do video, audio, and have performed workshops at schools and businesses.

·  Are you an artist, blogger, Tweeter, designer, or otherwise have a voice? We're looking for theatre artists, media voices, and passionate community members to join us in our adventure. Please get in touch! Our podcast program, particularly, seeks new stories continually.

·  Want to give us some advice? As emerging artists, we're looking for all of the artistic, financial, and legal advice we can get. If you have access to any of these resources and would be willing to help, we'd appreciate it!

story:
I couldn't even look at myself in the mirror. I was an insecure 8-year-old. It was dance that changed me. 

Through dance, I lived a life of gratitude, confidence and aspiration. I went on to earning my Bachelors of Arts in dance and economics, with a minor in political science at Denison University. I did this with the hopes and dreams of taking Sri Lanka's dance platform on to the international level, to provide children a sustainable and educative culture of dance. 

Sri Lanka's dance platform is minimal, to say the least. Whilst many consider it a form of entertainment and fun, dance progression in Sri Lanka is almost on a standstill with not much artistic scope or awareness. The attitude of most people when it comes to dance is on the entertainment side if at all. 
This is why it has always been a dream to raise and improve our dance platform, while simultaneously helping those who can't afford to pay for classes to learn and grow through dance. 
Today, I am on the verge of doing so - but I need your help. 


About Mesh Academy of Dance

Launching in 2015, MeshAcademy of Dance will be  a vibrant,  dynamic,and creative cross-cultural establishment that awakens the love of dance through the integration of the body,the mind and the spirit to educate,enhance and cultivate the “dance as an educative art form” in Sri Lanka.

By exposing students and professional dancers to the principles of dance through the artist and theoretical lenses, Mesh Academy of Dance aims to provide performances of high quality, imbued with virtuosity, energy, dynamics, and humanity.

In addition, we would like to provide scholarships to children from poverty or low-income families for them to have a chance in pursuing dance. Right now, they feel as if it is a far away dream. Let us help them. 

You can check out my interview on Artra Magazine Sri lanka here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PCf2CqfeR_E

You can check out our facebook page here:

https://www.facebook.com/meshacademyofdance

What we need and what you get -  

The cost of living in Sri Lanka is rising, but income levels are nowhere close to keeping up with them. 
Therefore, rent costs are on an all time high with not much return of investment. Right now, I rent a studio to practice for our launching dance production and I haven't started charging children yet. Why? This is the launch, these passionate children believe in me and the vision of Mesh Academy of Dance and most of them can't afford to pay. But they give their time, energy and commitment to seeing this launch through day in and out.

 I realized renting out a studio is going to be a costly affair and not sustainable in the long run. Luckily, we have found a tiny space, but a space that requires restoration. While I am putting most of my savings into this investment (purchase of the space), I am still falling short. And this is where I would like your help. 

We require $10,000 for rebuilding certain parts of the space, attaching the wooden flooring, purchasing mirrors and bar handles,  the foundations required for sustaining a dance studio for Mesh Academy of Dance. 25% of the $10,000 will go towards the scholarship pool to help those less fortunate in having a chance to pursue dance and the arts and $1 dollar from each donation will go towards the donation pool for providing a wheel-chair for a cerebral palsy affected child. 

Cerebral palsy is a condition where individuals are deformed from the waist down. There are reported 40,000 cases in Sri Lanka. As a dancer and an athlete, I couldn't even imagine myself not being able to dance or run, let alone walk. Therefore, I have made it a mission to donate and assist with cerebral palsy affected individuals when and wherever I can. Would you help as well? 


WHAT YOU GET:
$20 
A Thank You Letter and an image of our dance showcase 
$50
A Thank you letter, an image of our dance showcase, and your name mentioned on our program with a copy of it.
$100
A Thank you letter, an image of our dance showcase, your name on our program,  and a video of our show. 
$500

A thank you letter, an image of our show, a video of our show, your name on the program with a copy of it and your name on our plaque once we have built the studio. 

$1000
A thank you letter, an image of our dance showcase, your name on our program, a video of our show, your name on our plaque when we open up our space and a scholarship based on age group under your name. 

Words can't describe how much this means to my students and myself, but I hope to show you at least a bit of it through the perks we have offered. It might not be much, but it means a lot and it comes from the bottom of our hearts. 

Thank you to everyone who is reading this right now. The fact that you are taking your precious time to read this means a lot to me. If you choose to invest in us, thank you and if you choose not to, thank you anyway and we hope you spread our word around. We are incredibly grateful for how far we have come and we believe strong heartedly that we can take Sri Lanka's dance level  onto the next level and provide the children of our future with a gift of creative expression through one's body. 

Much love and have a great day/month/year. :)

I went on to earning my Bachelors of Arts in dance and economics, with a minor in political science at Denison University. I did this with the hopes and dreams of taking Sri Lanka's dance platform on to the international level, to provide children a sustainable and educative culture of dance. 
Sri Lanka's dance platform is minimal, to say the least. Whilst many consider it a form of entertainment and fun, dance progression in Sri Lanka is almost on a standstill with not much artistic scope or awareness. The attitude of most people when it comes to dance is on the entertainment side if at all. This is why it has always been a dream to raise and improve our dance platform, while simultaneously helping those who can't afford to pay for classes to learn and grow through dance. Today, I am on the verge of doing so - but I need your help. 
About Mesh Academy of Dance

Launching in 2015, MeshAcademy of Dance will be  a vibrant,  dynamic,and creative cross-cultural establishment that awakens the love of dance through the integration of the body,the mind and the spirit to educate,enhance and cultivate the “dance as an educative art form” in Sri Lanka.
By exposing students and professional dancers to the principles of dance through the artist and theoretical lenses, Mesh Academy of Dance aims to provide performances of high quality, imbued with virtuosity, energy, dynamics, and humanity.
In addition, we would like to provide scholarships to children from poverty or low-income families for them to have a chance in pursuing dance. Right now, they feel as if it is a far away dream. Let us help them. 
You can check out my interview on Artra Magazine Sri lanka here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PCf2CqfeR_E
You can check out our facebook page here:
https://www.facebook.com/meshacademyofdance
What we need and what you get -  The cost of living in Sri Lanka is rising, but income levels are nowhere close to keeping up with them. Therefore, rent costs are on an all time high with not much return of investment. Right now, I rent a studio to practice for our launching dance production and I haven't started charging children yet. Why? This is the launch, these passionate children believe in me and the vision of Mesh Academy of Dance and most of them can't afford to pay. But they give their time, energy and commitment to seeing this launch through day in and out. I realized renting out a studio is going to be a costly affair and not sustainable in the long run. Luckily, we have found a tiny space, but a space that requires restoration. While I am putting most of my savings into this investment (purchase of the space), I am still falling short. And this is where I would like your help. 
We require $10,000 for rebuilding certain parts of the space, attaching the wooden flooring, purchasing mirrors and bar handles,  the foundations required for sustaining a dance studio for Mesh Academy of Dance. 25% of the $10,000 will go towards the scholarship pool to help those less fortunate in having a chance to pursue dance and the arts and $1 dollar from each donation will go towards the donation pool for providing a wheel-chair for a cerebral palsy affected child. 
Cerebral palsy is a condition where individuals are deformed from the waist down. There are reported 40,000 cases in Sri Lanka. As a dancer and an athlete, I couldn't even imagine myself not being able to dance or run, let alone walk. Therefore, I have made it a mission to donate and assist with cerebral palsy affected individuals when and wherever I can. Would you help as well? 
WHAT YOU GET:$20 A Thank You Letter and an image of our dance showcase $50A Thank you letter, an image of our dance showcase, and your name mentioned on our program with a copy of it.$100A Thank you letter, an image of our dance showcase, your name on our program,  and a video of our show. $500
A thank you letter, an image of our show, a video of our show, your name on the program with a copy of it and your name on our plaque once we have built the studio. 
$1000A thank you letter, an image of our dance showcase, your name on our program, a video of our show, your name on our plaque when we open up our space and a scholarship based on age group under your name. 

Words can't describe how much this means to my students and myself, but I hope to show you at least a bit of it through the perks we have offered. It might not be much, but it means a lot and it comes from the bottom of our hearts. 
Thank you to everyone who is reading this right now. The fact that you are taking your precious time to read this means a lot to me. If you choose to invest in us, thank you and if you choose not to, thank you anyway and we hope you spread our word around. We are incredibly grateful for how far we have come and we believe strong heartedly that we can take Sri Lanka's dance level  onto the next level and provide the children of our future with a gift of creative expression through one's body. 

 Much love and have a great day/month/year. :)

story:
DONATE TO:

Chicago Contemporary Circus Festival (CCCF) 
First Annual Fundraising Campaign


Watch the video, film your own and then click here to share;) #IAMCIRCUS


We listened, get involved

We heard from artists, volunteers, patrons and staff. We listened. We're making changes and we want your help. Together our work establishes circus as part of the contemporary arts community both in Chicago and in the United States. 


Member of the movement

Give today and become a member of the movement. Stay informed throughout the year as we share the latest news, programming and developments.  Get an insider's view of the process along with making your support known.  When you give today you'll receive quarterly updates, invitations to special events, great swag and the opportunity to buy your tickets early and at a discount.

What does your money buy?

CCCF operates without paid staff. Meaning the people who work year round to bring this work to you, do so while maintaining full time jobs and in their free time. They recognize and rejoice in the groundbreaking importance of the festival.

Rest assured that YOUR donations will be used to cover the costs of the festival. 

Artist Fees: $80,000 - It's not a festival without the talent. Our artists graciously discount their fees to help us make the festival possible. Even at dramatically discounted rates bringing great talent from all over the world to Chicago is our top priority and most expensive cost.

Venue Rentals: $20,000 - This pays for 3-4 performance and rehearsal spaces throughout the week and gives us time to set-up, tech, rehearse and perform. A week is a very small window of time given the scope of the festival. Schedules are tight but each year we pull it off through long days and a committed volunteer staff. 

Technicians: $15,000 -Our first year our entire backstage staff was volunteer only. In 2015 we paid half our technicians below market rate and the other half were still volunteer.

Equipment Rentals: $8,000 - Covers the cost all things that make a show a show and keep our performers safe: Truss, rigging, lighting, projection and much, much more.

CIRQUE MECHANICS: PEDAL PUNK


CASUS: KNEE DEEP




SLATER & JARON: SUBMARINE SHOW

KATE & PASI: SUHDE

ALL TOGETHER 

In 2014 & 2015 

WE
Hosted 10 DAYS OF CIRCUS
Presented 22 AMAZING SHOWS
Sold 7878 TICKETS
Applauded 148 PROFESSIONAL ARTISTS
Celebrated 100 YOUTH ARTISTS
Thanked 109 VOLUNTEERS
Shared 40 CIRCUS NOW WORKSHOPS
Attended 27 MASTERCLASSES

NEXT STEPS

Our INDIEGOGO campaign covers a small percentage of the major annual cost of the festival which is why it is one part of our annual fundraising campaign. Throughout the year CCCF is dedicated to raising funds through cultivation events, membership drives and actively seeking sponsorships. 

Give today. Be a part of the future. Be a part of the circus. 

ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE;)

The Chicago Contemporary Circus Festival is a non-profit 501(c)(3) charity founded in 2014 to celebrate and encourage the development of contemporary circus in the US through an annual circus festival including workshops and master classes and various events throughout the year in Chicago, Illinois. We strive to build a circus arts community that exchanges ideas and information and provides a US-based reference point, thereby promoting and raising awareness of this art form. We support education and the sharing of other forms of contemporary art that incorporate circus as a way to expand this unique movement and visual vocabulary (e.g., dance, theater, visual art, music). The festival is completely managed by non-paid volunteers.

story:
My story:

My name is Alaja Oni Le’alla Badalich and I'm 15 years old .  I was born on December 5, 2000. I was 3 months early and weighed 2 pounds.  After two months in the hospital, I was brought home February 14, 2001. For being born so early I have asthma, but I don't let it stop me from striving for success. I'm a freshmen in high school  and I'm currently attending a online school program called Oregon Connections Academy. 

I believe family is one of the most  important things in life. I live with my mom, step-dad, and my 4 year old half-brother. My grandparents also live in Eugene too, while mostly all of my other relatives live in California. My family gives me so much support  and they inspire me everyday.  My best friend is also one of the most important people in my life. She supports me but also inspires me to jump through every obstacle in the way. She shares this passion of dance with  me. I truly can't imagine my life without my family or my best friend.


Alaja means understanding, Oni means strength, and  Le’alla means adoration. I think that as I grow older I will grow into these qualities by expressing who I am in dance.  When I dance, everything fades away in my life that is bothering me, even if it's dance stressing me out. I like to say that dance is my passion, expression, therapy, and I guess you could say my connection with the world.  Each movement, even if it's just a turn, a balance, a pointed foot, a plie, a ronde de jambe, or any movement that you think is small is actually connected to a smaller one. I think dance is also about connection. You have connected movements; your movements are connected to the music, but to make each movement fluid you must connect within yourself.  


Training:

I train Monday through Saturday at Oregon Ballet academy. I take palliates, Tap, modern, Improvisation and ballet. I dance about 24 hours in a week or more if I have rehearsals. Summer of 2013, I studied at victor school of performing arts international for two weeks and at Oregon ballet academy for the rest of the summer. Summer of 2014, I studied at Texas Ballet Theater for 5 weeks and then Oregon ballet academy for the rest of the summer. Summer of 2015, I studied at Ballet West and Oregon ballet academy.At home in Oregon Ballet Academy, My instructors are : John Greenback, Felicia Sanders, Adam kelly, and during the summer : Carl Corry. My instructors at the Victor school of arts were : Joy victor and Tetyana Martyanova. My instructors at Texas ballet Theater were : Tim O’Keefe, Anna Donovan, Kathryn Warakomsky , Lyndette Galen, Carrie Cheng , Jan Miller, Steve Brule, Clara Cravey ,John Grensback, Janie Parker, Adam Boreland and more. At Ballet West my instructors : Peggy Dolkas, Bridget Payne, James Payne, Peter Stark, Heather Thackeray, Jan Clark Fugit, Heather Fryxell, Ai Fujii Nelson, Jessica Thompson, Christopher Anderson, Sayaka Ohtaki, and more.

Performances:

I have danced in many ballets and pieces with Oregon Ballet Academy. To name the most recent: In fall of 2013 I was Arabian in Nutcracker, Spring of 2014 I was in two improvisation pieces also I was in A Chorus Line . The most recent of them all was fall of 2014, I was a Big Swan and Spanish princess in Swan lake. Spring of 2015, I was in an improv piece,modern piece and contemporary ballet piece. In fall of 2015, I was one out three forest fairies in Snow White. 


Competitions:

I competed in NAACP’s ACT-SO competition in the category of dance. It is only for high-schoolers but they made a junior division.  In 2013, I did the canary fair variation from sleeping beauty. In 2014, I did a improvisation solo and won the first place throughout the junior and  high school division. In 2015, I did a improvisation solo and won 2nd throughout the junior and high school division. I going to compete again this year doing an improvisation solo on pointe on April 1st.


What I need:

This year I will be attending two summer programs, but I need your help! I am raising $4,400 to go to Alonzo King Lines Ballet four week summer session in San Francisco, California. It will also go to Dance Theater of Harlems five week summer session in New York City . All of this money will go to: Tuition, Housing, Airfare, Ballet Attire, Meal Plan, and Attire for Utah. Last year I was lucky enough to attend Ballet Wests six week long summer intensive with your help and summer of 2014 I was lucky enough to attend Texas Ballet Theater's 5 week long summer intensive with your help as well! Let's do it again! If you cannot donate, please spread the word by posting this on your social media or just telling people about it.

story:
POR LA LUZ DE LA LUNA: APRIL 9 & 10 AT THE SEBASTIANI THEATRE IN SONOMA


Short Summary

"Por La Luz de la Luna, is a labor of love, that honors Mexican heritage and illustrates to our community that there is a place for everyone on the stage — no matter what your background is. -Patty O'Reilly"

A message from our Director:

When I took over as Director of Sonoma Conservatory of Dance in 2005, I set out to continue the ethnic and cultural diversity I grew up with on Air Force bases as a child, doing so through the art and discipline of dance. I wanted SCD to be a space where diversity is not only nurtured but celebrated. 

Over the past 11 years, the studio has grown into a place that I can proudly say educates and fosters an array of beautiful and different cultural backgrounds. Sonoma is a community with many Hispanic residents, and specifically Mexican, families — something that is also reflected in the Studio's student population.

-Patricia O'Reilly, ARAD, Artistic Director

 Por la Luz de la Luna (By the Light of the Moon) is a full-length dance performance,  with a cast comprised of children ages 6 to 16 as well as adult guest artists from San Francisco and Oakland. Our production is a celebration of Mexican culture and the diverse landscape of Sonoma’s cultural makeup through the art of dances such as Folklorico, Aztec Dance, Classical Ballet, and Waltz.


The Story of Luna

This epic Mexican-American tale follows young Lucila who sees the evening moon for the first time while her mother, Carmela, explains that her ancestors have been adoring the moon for generations.

Through Carmela’s storytelling, Lucila and audiences are transported into the time of Mexico’s Joan of Arc, Jovita, who fought for religious freedom during Mexico’s second revolution in the early part of the 20th century; then they will travel with Carmelo and Estela who cross the Mexican border into the U.S. in search of the proverbial dream; and finally, enter the ancient story of the Aztec moon goddess, Coyolxauhqui, whose battle with her brother, Huizilopchtli, the sun god, brought light to the night sky.


The Real Jovita Valdovinos, 1935


Guest Artist, Pemex: Amidst painting our backdrop and explaining the juxtaposition of Chicano/Ballet Art


Guest Artist, Pemex at work on our backdrop!


Por La Luz de la Luna: AZTEC BATTLE SCENE REHEARSAL


Por La Luz de la Luna: LEAD CHOREOGRAPHER, ISABELLE SJAHSAM LEARNING FOLKORICO CHOREGRAPHY FROM GUEST ARTIST, JESUS CORTES



Guest Artist, Jesus Cortes: Aztec Battle Scene Rehearsal


Meet the Creative Team

     

Aida Salazar is a multidisciplinary writer, educator, arts administrator and mother. With an MFA in Writing from the California Institute of the Arts, her writings have appeared in publications such as the Huffington Post and Women and Performance: Journal of Feminist Theory.

She currently lives in Oakland, CA with her husband, Latin jazz musician, John Santos and home-schools her two fiery artist children for whom many of her children’s stories have been written. She is at work on a novel in verse for middle grades and a memoir, In the Womb of Love, about the death of her first-born infant child.

Her story, By the Light of the Moon, is being adapted into a ballet production by choreographer, Isabelle Sjahsam and artist, Roberto Miguel for the Sonoma Conservatory of Dance.


Ms. Sjahsam has performed with Bay Area dance companies including SF Renaissance Dancers, Em Space Dance, Jenny McAllister/13th Floor Dance Theater, and Anna Halprin and Dancers. She appeared in the works of Michael Lowe while working with Moving Arts Dance, Black Diamond Ballet Theatre, and Menlowe Ballet, and has toured internationally with Leyya Tawil’s Dance Elixir.
She looks forward to her new project with Sonoma Conservatory of Dance and would not be where she is today without her ballet mentors Michael Lowe, Sarah-Jane Measor and Augusta Moore.


Jesus Cortes, began his training in Mexican folk dance when he was 6 years old under the direction of his Great Uncle Juan Natoli. In 2000, he started dancing with Ballet Folklórico de Mexico de Amalia Hernandez in the Palace of Fine Arts in Mexico City. He became a soloist in the role of The Deer Dance “La Danza Del Venado” and toured Mexico, Europe and the US.


With a background in Ballroom Dance at Arthur Murray and a Bachelor’s Degree in Social Work from The University of Wisconsin – Madison, Giselle strives to meld these two passions and bring humanitarianism to the beautiful world of dance.
Through her work as Studio Manager at Sonoma Conservatory of Dance, as well as Production Manager/Guest Choreographer for POR LA LUZ DE LA LUNA, Giselle hopes to nourish the spirit and minds of SCD’s young dancers and to connect deeper with her Mexican-American roots, sharing this through the celebration of dance.


In the world of graffiti and massive urban murals, Pemex is a hard name to overlook.  He’s paid plenty of dues, getting his hands dirty and rising through the ranks to be one of the most renowned urban artists putting in work up and down California.  And it wasn’t an easy road getting there.  Born and raised South Central Los Angeles, it would have been easy to fall victim to the environment that raised him, to follow the same disastrous path that so many others did.  He was able to do what few others have done, to process his experience and channel it to grow strong and resilient, self-capable and fearless. His street work is savage and unrelenting, stylish and possessing in it a humor and history unique to the artist himself.


Roberto Miguel is an artist and Dj from Oakland, California.  His first exposure to the arts was with “baille folkorico” in Richmond, California, and went on to study with Los Cenzontles Mexican Arts Center and the East Bay Center for the Performing Arts.  He has played in numerous bands, traveling touring the United States and England.  He is also an event organizer and put many events including “Hoodstock Oakland,” “Hoodstock New York” and “Special Delivery” in Berkeley in conjunction with Endless Canvas.  In 2012, he collaborated with renowned street artist “Gats” on an installation, which was the focus of a short documentary produced by Pharell Williams.


CLICK THE LINK BELOW TO READ FULL ARTIST BIOS AND LEARN MORE POR LA LUZ DE LUNA:

http://sonomadancestudio.com/index.php/luna/




What We Need & What You Get

    Some Important Facts from our Production Manager:

    The cost of a performance of this level of this caliber is  $50,000 minimum, with ticket sales only covering a fraction of the costs.

    This includes things like:

    • lighting design/equipment
    • stage backdrop
    • props/costumes
    • graphic design and printing
    • venue rental
    • guest artists

    In addition, Sonoma Conservatory of Dance still provides a full schedule of classes, a Work-Study program,  and scholarships so that we can maintain the diversity we cherish.


    What You Get:

    Check out our list of Perks which includes:

    • A signed copy of Aida Salazar's Mexican folktale, By Light of the Moon, the inspiration for Por la Luz de la Luna.
    • A pair of point shoes signed by San Francisco Ballet's, Mexican-American Ballerina, Evelyn Cisneros
    • Dinner for 2 at one of Sonoma's most beloved restaurants, La Salette
    • Luxury wine tour from Blue Star Wine Country Tours
    • 2 Free fitness sessions from Big Picture Vitality
    • Free classes at Sonoma Conservatory of Dance

    The Impact

    This production was created as a celebration and to make an impact in our community. We want to serve an under-served population in Sonoma and inspire our community's youth, showing them that there is a place for them in the world of ballet.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Tell your friends to tell your friends about our show!

    Post the event on your Facebook:

    https://www.facebook.com/sonomaconservatoryofdance/?fref=ts

musician, John Santos and home-schools her two fiery artist children for
 whom many of her children’s stories have been written. She is at work 
on a novel in verse for middle grades and a memoir, In the Womb of Love, about the death of her first-born infant child.

Her story, By the Light of the Moon, is being adapted into a ballet 
production by choreographer, Isabelle Sjahsam and artist, Roberto Miguel
 for the Sonoma Conservatory of Dance.



Ms. Sjahsam has performed with Bay Area dance companies
 including SF Renaissance Dancers, Em Space Dance, Jenny McAllister/13th
 Floor Dance Theater, and Anna Halprin and Dancers. She appeared in the 
works of Michael Lowe while working with Moving Arts Dance, Black 
Diamond Ballet Theatre, and Menlowe Ballet, and has toured 
internationally with Leyya Tawil’s Dance Elixir.She looks forward to her new project with Sonoma Conservatory of Dance 
and would not be where she is today without her ballet mentors Michael 
Lowe, Sarah-Jane Measor and Augusta Moore.
Jesus Cortes, began his training in Mexican folk dance 
when he was 6 years old under the direction of his Great Uncle Juan 
Natoli. In 2000, he started dancing with Ballet Folklórico de Mexico de 
Amalia Hernandez in the Palace of Fine Arts in Mexico City. He became a 
soloist in the role of The Deer Dance “La Danza Del Venado” and toured 
Mexico, Europe and the US. 


With a background in Ballroom Dance at Arthur Murray and a Bachelor’s 
Degree in Social Work from The University of Wisconsin – Madison, Giselle strives to meld these two passions and bring humanitarianism to the beautiful world of dance.
Through her work as Studio Manager at Sonoma Conservatory of Dance, as well as Production Manager/Guest Choreographer for POR LA LUZ DE LA LUNA, Giselle
 hopes to nourish the spirit and minds of SCD’s young dancers and to 
connect deeper with her Mexican-American roots, sharing this through the
 celebration of dance.


In the world of graffiti and massive urban murals, Pemex is a 
hard name to overlook.  He’s paid plenty of dues, getting his hands 
dirty and rising through the ranks to be one of the most renowned urban 
artists putting in work up and down California.  And it wasn’t an easy 
road getting there.  Born and raised South Central Los Angeles, it would
 have been easy to fall victim to the environment that raised him, to 
follow the same disastrous path that so many others did.  He was able to
 do what few others have done, to process his experience and channel it 
to grow strong and resilient, self-capable and fearless. His street work is savage and unrelenting, stylish and possessing in it a humor and history unique to the artist himself.



Roberto Miguel is an artist and Dj from Oakland, 
California.  His first exposure to the arts was with “baille folkorico” 
in Richmond, California, and went on to study with Los Cenzontles 
Mexican Arts Center and the East Bay Center for the Performing Arts.  He
 has played in numerous bands, traveling touring the United States and 
England.  He is also an event organizer and put many events including 
“Hoodstock Oakland,” “Hoodstock New York” and “Special Delivery” in 
Berkeley in conjunction with Endless Canvas.  In 2012, he collaborated 
with renowned street artist “Gats” on an installation, which was the 
focus of a short documentary produced by Pharell Williams.
CLICK THE LINK BELOW TO READ FULL ARTIST BIOS AND LEARN MORE POR LA LUZ DE LUNA:
http://sonomadancestudio.com/index.php/luna/


What We Need & What You Get


Some Important Facts from our Production Manager:
The
 cost of a performance of this level of this caliber is 
 $50,000 minimum, with ticket sales only covering a fraction of the costs.
This includes things like:

lighting design/equipment
stage backdrop
props/costumes
graphic design and printing
venue rental 

guest artists



In
 addition, Sonoma Conservatory of Dance still provides a full schedule 
of classes, a Work-Study program,  and scholarships so that we can 
maintain the diversity we cherish. 

What You Get:
Check out our list of Perks which includes:

A signed copy of Aida Salazar's Mexican folktale, By Light of the Moon, the inspiration for Por la Luz de la Luna.

A pair of point shoes signed by San Francisco Ballet's, Mexican-American Ballerina, Evelyn Cisneros
Dinner for 2 at one of Sonoma's most beloved restaurants, La Salette
Luxury wine tour from Blue Star Wine Country Tours

2 Free fitness sessions from Big Picture Vitality

Free classes at Sonoma Conservatory of Dance




   The Impact This production was created as a celebration and to make an impact in our community. We want to serve an under-served population in Sonoma and inspire our community's youth, showing them that there is a place for them in the world of ballet. 
  Other Ways You Can Help Tell your friends to tell your friends about our show!
Post the event on your Facebook: 
https://www.facebook.com/sonomaconservatoryofdance/?fref=ts

story:
Short Summary

    Hi, 
  We are three young beginner actors from Vilnius, Lithuania: Mindaugas, Povilas and Motiejus. We are studying acting at Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre for the first year and we have already found out that theatre is our dream occupation. We are trying to find as many ways to improve our acting skills as possible. That is why we feel an unbounded desire to take part in theatre workshop in Nida, Lithuania's greatest seaside town at late spring. Greatest theatre directors, actors and modern dancers will gather here for a week. This theatre event is the one that requires not only a desire, but also a great sum of money, so we need your help to pay participant fee.
    With your help, we will be able to gain invaluable theatrical experience and dancing skills, which would be incredibly useful in our future projects and works.  


What We Need & What You Get

We need your financial support.
    In exchange, you will get our sponsors works:
https://soundcloud.com/saladzhius
https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.1581502382170671.1073741832.1386391285015116&type=1&__mref=message_bubble 
http://skate4create.com/

 


   We are young and wild and we really enjoy going out of our comfort zone. That is our daily routine. Surprising people and making their day better is a pleasure for us. What could be better than making a rude or sad  person stop and smile for a while, making people look at each other and laugh instead of walking from place to place without noticing that there are many great things and funny people around them. We sung in a jewelry shop, acted like monkeys in a shopping center, changed our clothes to make ourselves look like homeless children. We are being hunted by security guards, but it doesn't stop us from making life more appealing for others and ourselves as well. Our energy will soon be used in creating more serious theatre performances. So we need every skill we can get to become great and versatile artists



Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute, you can still be very helpful by sharing our campaign with Indiegogo share tools. Let others hear about our desire! Thank you!

Take a look at our special sponsor Www.proadventure.lt / https://m.facebook.com/ProAdventure.Lt/
