story:
What we are doing

Staging Bloody Haymarket, an original theatrical production.

Our goals for the production are as follows:

  • To create a bold and engaging performance for our audience.
  • To provide the audience an entertaining/ interactive experience

To develop a new kind of theatrical involvement.

This is a production we deeply believe in and want to share with the world. That includes you, and we would be honored if you would become a part of it.

What we need & what you get

This production has been carefully budgeted, with specially tailored perks:

  • We are asking for a total of $10,000, which will be used to pay for a venue, publicity, and honoraria for our incredibly hard-working cast and crew.
  • All levels of donation are deeply appreciated. No amount is too small, and each level of contribution comes with a token of our appreciation.
  • Every dollar raised will go towards helping this production reach its potential and our heartfelt gratitude.

Why we are doing this 

The work we are doing will provide audiences with an entertaining and educational spectacle about a critical event in Chicago and American history that all should know about. Our play explores still-relevant issues such as:

  • Worker’s rights,
  • Police brutality,
  • Corrupt politicians,
  • Immigrant rights, and
  • Racial discrimination.

Risks & Challenges

We are not naïve. Living in a theater city, like Chicago, makes standing out hard. Thankfully, we have two traits to help us shine:

  • Our company is made up of artists of the highest caliber, who are supremely dedicated to their cause.
  • We have a great story to tell. 

Furthermore, 2016 is the 130th anniversary of the Haymarket Riot event; what better way to honor all involved in the event than to tell their story to a younger audience? We have presented two public stagings of scenes from our production, which were well received.  The positive responses we received from those audiences are proof of how strong an impact our show will have.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we understand. This is a group made up of artists after all. 

There are plenty of valuable ways to show your support. Sharing this campaign online will always be appreciated. 

All of our campaign videos can be viewed at our website:  www.bloodyhaymarket.com

PERKS 


$5  Thank you

$10  Thank you on FaceBook 

$25  Thank you on FaceBook + Autographed Playbill

$50  Thank you on FaceBook + Playbill Mentionu on FaceBook + Playbill Mention + Autographed Playbill

$100  Thank you on FaceBook + Playbill Mention + Autographed Playbill + 2 tickets performance of your choice.

$200  Thank you on FaceBook + Playbill Mention + Autographed Playbill + 2 tickets performance of your choice + a speaking part in the production

No Perk.  I just want to contribute.

story:
Dear Sobriety, 

I am writing this letter to inform you of the mishaps caused by Blacklist Babes andBlack Garter Dolls while you were away. Maybe you've heard they have decided to produce a Fringe 2016 show…4 shows actually. Can you believe it?! 

Let me tell you they sure have been scandalous this year while you've been gone.  They wanted their own Burlesque Cabaret so they’ve danced on bars in Orlando; they took off their clothes from Pompano Beach to St. Augustine; they’ve performed on large event stages, for small private parties and even at charitable concerts all over Central Florida. Oh my, what would their mothers say?! 

If that isn’t enough, those Blacklist Babes won themselves an award as a burlesque cabaret troupe in The Venue’s Amateur Burlesque contest. Did you hear what they did next?? Those boys and girls went out and performed at the main stage at Lake Eola during the Orlando Pride event. Bless their hearts. 

When you are around, these hard working artists spend their days in retail, education, theme parks and college…and that ain’t cheap. Now they tell me they have dreams of this International Orlando Fringe Festival and had their show accepted for The Black Venue. Let me explain a few things involved in making the magic happen: 
• Festival Fees 
• Technical Production Fees 
• Posters and Marketing Material 
• Published Music Fees 

Shake my head, those darn kids desperately need help. They rehearse twice a week and are busy performing one to five times a month. They keep telling me long nights, show day jitters, sore feet and corset mishaps are worth it to be able to produce their own show. Maybe they can get your help getting there?

I am asking for them since they've decided to name their first show extravaganza after me, ain't that sweet!  I don't want to brag, but they tell me they know it will be a good time when I show up - Mercy, these Babes and Dolls sure know how to make me blush!

Sincerely, 
Black Out!

P.S. All funds raised go directly to the production of Black Out! coming to theOrlando Fringe Festival this May. Check out the perks that are yours to keep!

story:
Short Summary

Acorn Productions started the Maine Playwrights Festival as part of our mission to nurture theater artists and the local arts community. Now in its 16th year, the MPF is Maine's premiere incubator for new plays. Over the years we have been proud to present hundreds of world premiere plays, some of which have gone on to be produced at festivals in New York and elsewhere. For playwrights, this is an invaluable opportunity to see their words interpreted by directors and actors and see how audiences react. For the actors it is a unique chance to originate characters that will set the standard for future productions of the work. For the audience it is an introduction to emerging and established playwrights who live and write here in Maine. Who knows...some day one of these playwrights could be accepting a prestigious award for one of their plays and you can say "I was there when they got their start at the Maine Playwrights Festival!"

Your contribution toward our $2,500 goal helps make it possible for Acorn to provide this important service to our community by helping with overhead costs for this vibrant and exciting new works festival.

"The Brownwater Legend, by Michael Kimball (MPF'10)

What We Need & What You Get

Our $2,500 indiegogo campaign goal bridges the gap between our anticipated expenses and projected ticket sales and sponsorship revenue. This funding will be divided among all the essential aspects of the Maine Playwrights Festival: publicity, technical and directorial staff, tech materials (such as costumes, props, paint, lighting gel, and glowtape for backstage safety), bringing William Donnelly, our Playwright-in-Residence, to Portland, and venue rental fees.

Here's what your donation helps to fund:

  • Your $25 donation buys a sheet of plywood to help build the sets
  • Your $50 donation pays the stipend for one actor
  • Your $100 donation purchases an ad in the Portland Phoenix to spread the word about the MPF
  • Your $250 donation covers the rental cost for one performance
  • Your $500 donation covers much of the cost to design and print publicity materials for the festival

Every donation at every level makes a big difference.

Your contribution is important to us, but we don't want that to be the end of your association with the Festival. We want you to see the plays you support, so we are offering rewards ranging from a ticket to an MPF performance of your choice, acknowledgement in the program and/or curtain speech, and an invitation to the MPF cast party!

(The 24-Hour Portland Theater Project, 2010)

The Impact

The Maine Playwrights Festival has been a consistent feature of the state's cultural landscape for the past 15 years.  Every year, we inspire dozens of playwrights to polish their final scripts to submission, and those that are selected receive extensive opportunities to revise their piece with the help of MPF co-Artistic Director Daniel Burson and our Playwright-in-Residence.  We also hold open auditions for the festival, introducing new actors into the community each year.  Not to overlook the adrenaline-filled craziness that is the 24-Hour Portland Theater Project.  Your donation helps Acorn Productions, the MPF's producer, ensure that this event is financially stable so that we can continue to offer this unique opportunity to Maine-based theater artists.

"Done Deal," by Linda Griffith (MPF'07)

Other Ways You Can Help

Contributions of all kinds are needed to get us to our fundraising goal and make the Maine Playwrights Festival a success.

  • Tell all your friends! Pass along the information about this campaign and the Festival. Encourage them to get involved.
  • Volunteer! Contact Michael Levine at acornacting@gmail.com if you would like to usher, help with publicity, or volunteer in some other way.
  • Share this fundraising campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you!

story:
What it is:

It is 1961 in glamorous Hollywood. With the release of Exodus, the Eichmann trial and the eminent filming of the Diary of Anne Frank, America is just beginning to directly address and talk about the Holocaust.

We are led on a journey by Esthie, the beautiful 31-year old wife of a movie studio head, who is also a German political Holocaust survivor. Upon discovery that a film based on a grossly inaccurate pornographic novel about Block 24 has been green-lit, she's on a mission to stop the movie from being made.

For the first and last time in her life, Esthie tells the story of her forced prostitution in the largely unacknowledged camp brothel. The truth must be said, at least once.

Through Esthie's story, Nepenthe also examines the seldom explored persecution of gay WWII prisoners, the post-holocaust refugee crisis, survivor's guilt, and ultimately the need not to remember, but forget.


What We Need & What You Get:

  • We need some cash to pay for rehearsal space, costume, transportation and more focused time to rehearse.
  • You'll then be a partner in our journey, to give voice to a story that hasn't been told, a story that will shed light on key aspects of life in today's world.
  • Our goal is for this production to touch several cities including;  Berlin and NYC. If you would love us in your city, help make it happen!


Who we are:

SHANE KILLORAN - Dramaturge, Co-Creator, (Resident Dramaturge, Literary Manager- The Private Theatre) received her B.F.A in Acting from New York University with a heavy concentration in Women’s Studies. After acting for several years in New York and Los Angeles, she realized she enjoyed the rehearsal process far more than performing. This realization took her to England and the University of London where she pursued her post-graduate work in theatre including her Doctoral candidacy which focused primarily in devised performance. Upon her return from London, Shane produced television for several years. She has since left the world of TV production to focus full-time on writing and theatrical projects.

As well as serving as Literary Manager  and sitting on the Literary Committee for the Private Theatre since its founding, in 2012, Shane was the Co-Creator and Dramaturge for the Private Theatre's production of Strindberg's, Playing With Fire. In 2013 she adapted the Indian play Sakaram Binder for MAD Playhouse Theater. 

She is currently working on The Shriver Project as a Co-Creator and Dramaturge (Private Theatre), and Dramaturge for Brecht's Drums in the Night (Private Theatre), A Doll's House (Private Theatre) with an upcoming place at the Dorset Theatre Festival as well as her own production, The Trilogy Project (working title)as Co-Creator and Dramaturge.

RACHEL NEUBURGER - Writer, Co-Creator in 250 words exactly, is a writer and producer currently working out of London and New York City.  Besides having the pleasure of currently working on Nepenthe, she has recently completed her mystery novel Red Frog Beach. Her feature length horror film The Howlers is scheduled to go into production in the summer of 2017. Her play Silencer, was most recently seen at NYC’s Festival of the Offensive after a run at Edinburgh’s Pleasance in 2012. Her short horror film Noctulent was produced in 2009. She is currently working on a new novel called On Sea. As a producer, she is currently producing The Intergalactic Nemesis: Twin Infinity for Edinburgh in August 2016, as well as acting as a consulting producer on this wonderful Women And War Festival. Selected producing credits include Nothing To Hide (dir. Neil Patrick Harris), Martin McDonagh’s A Behanding in Spokane (Broadway), On The Line, Judas & Me (Chad Beguelin & Matt Sklar), Theatre O’s Three Dark Tales, and Texarkana Waltz. Previously she acted as Associate Producer for Ostar Productions, working on Broadway shows including Thurgood, Inherit The Wind, Spamalot, The Country Girl, Impressionism and The Seafarer. With Ostar, she produced workshop versions of Nora Ephron’s Love, Loss and What I Wore and the opera Innocence (Jonathan Dove and Alaisdair Middleton). She was the originating Artistic Director of the Summer Play Festival in NYC for the first two seasons in 2004 and 2005. She also provides creative consultation to film and theatre companies. www.RachelNeuburger.com

MIRIAM IBRAHIM - Director, is the founder of LabelGray.org, she grew up in Germany and Ethiopia, began performing in high school and later graduated in 2005 from Stage School Music, Dance and Drama Hamburg. Throughout various theaters in Germany she played roles in Crucible (Theater Bonn), Hair (Theater an der Rott) and Mutter Afrika (Deutsches Schauspielhaus Hamburg) and others. She always had a passion to teach and create her own performances. She moved to New York City in 2010 to study the 2 Year Evening Conservatory at the Stella Adler Studio of Acting. In New York she played in Eastern Standard, Escape from Happiness, Crucible, Vestiges, Piece/Peace of Mine. In addition to her work as an actress she directed and thought for BINI e.V., Backstage Hamburg, Geminin Trust Ethiopia, Mad-Playhouse NYC, Rebel Theater Company and Label Gray. She has been assisting for John Gould Rubin in NYC and for the Herbstsalon for Maxim Gorki Theater Berlin. She just finished her studies at Freie Universität Berlin in Theater and Social-/Cultural Anthropology. Miriam believes that Art and Theater give us the possibility of a complex perspective of the things in and outside of life, that it can unfold the unseen and the things hidden in between. www.miriamibrahim.com

ZOE HUTMACHER - Actress, is of German, Swiss and Italian heritage. In 2001 she trained as an actress in Hamburg, Germany, earning her diploma in 2004. Upon graduating she has played in various theatres throughout Germany, New York and Switzerland. Between 2007-2011, Zoe was a permanent company member at the Theaterhaus Jena and at the Theater Basel from 2012-2015. She has performed at: Thalia Theater Hamburg, Deutsches Schauspielhaus Hamburg, St. Pauli Theater, Secret Theater LIC/NY, Staatstheater Braunschweig, Deutsches Theater Berlin, Kampnagel Hamburg, Theaterhaus Jena and Sophiensäle. Zoe has had the pleasure to work with: Calixto Bieito, Romeo Castelluccuci, Cilli Drexel, Julia Hölschwer, Rayka Kobiella, Andreas Kriegenburg, Richard Maxwell and many more. Zoe loves to act on stage or in front of the camera. Currently she is performing, Kristine Linde in, A Doll’s House at the Concert Theater Bern, Switzerland. www.zoehutmacher.com


Something personal:

"It is so important for us to never forget, though growing up with my fathers family who escaped the Nazis, sporadically from 1938 to 1942, there was a need to try to forget that I saw in my grandparents. My father was too young to remember anything, as he was two when they fled to Paraguay. In my far too little 22 years that I had with my grandparents, they never mentioned the Holocaust and I never asked. Many years after they passed away, I began to have guilt about never asking, but eventually realized that it was the last thing they would have wanted. For them, the absolute joy of having grandchildren who could run around free, never having to suffer a moment of what they suffered, was an undoubted gift to them. Even though they sat in an apartment in Brookline, MA, not doing a hell of a lot, what a gift to my grandfather saying  not much but to be able to walk the quarter mile to pray a schul every day…" R. Neuburger
story_txt:
What it is:

It is 1961 in glamorous Hollywood. With the release of Exodus,
the Eichmann trial and the eminent filming of the Diary of Anne Frank,
America is just beginning to directly address and talk about the Holocaust.
We are led on a journey by Esthie, the beautiful 31-year old wife
of a movie studio head, who is also a German political Holocaust
survivor. Upon discovery that a film based on a grossly inaccurate
pornographic novel about Block 24 has been green-lit, she's on a mission to
stop the movie from being made.
For the first and last time in her life, Esthie tells the story of
her forced prostitution in the largely unacknowledged camp brothel. The truth
must be said, at least once.
Through Esthie's story, Nepenthe also examines the seldom
explored persecution of gay WWII prisoners, the post-holocaust refugee crisis,
survivor's guilt, and ultimately the need not to remember, but forget.

   What We Need & What You Get:  We need some cash to pay for rehearsal space, costume, transportation and more focused time to rehearse. You'll then be a partner in our journey, to give voice to a story that hasn't been told, a story that will shed light on key aspects of life in today's world. Our goal is for this production to touch several cities including;  Berlin and NYC. If you would love us in your city, help make it happen!    
Who we are:


SHANE KILLORAN - Dramaturge, Co-Creator, (Resident
Dramaturge, Literary Manager- The Private Theatre) received her B.F.A in Acting from New York University with a heavy
concentration in Women’s Studies. After acting for several years in New York
and Los Angeles, she realized she enjoyed the rehearsal process far more than
performing. This realization took her to England and the University of London
where she pursued her post-graduate work in theatre including her Doctoral candidacy
which focused primarily in devised performance. Upon her return from
London, Shane produced television for several years. She has since
left the world of TV production to focus full-time on writing and theatrical
projects.
As well
as serving as Literary Manager  and sitting on the Literary Committee for
the Private Theatre since its founding, in 2012, Shane was the Co-Creator
and Dramaturge for the Private Theatre's production of
Strindberg's, Playing With Fire. In 2013 she adapted the Indian
play Sakaram Binder for MAD Playhouse Theater. 
She is currently working on The Shriver Project as
a Co-Creator and Dramaturge (Private Theatre), and
Dramaturge for Brecht's Drums in the Night (Private Theatre), A
Doll's House (Private Theatre) with an upcoming place at the Dorset
Theatre Festival as well as her own production, The Trilogy
Project (working title)as Co-Creator and Dramaturge.
RACHEL NEUBURGER - Writer, Co-Creator in 250 words exactly, is a writer and
producer currently working out of London and New York City.  Besides having the pleasure of currently
working on Nepenthe, she has recently
completed her mystery novel Red Frog
Beach. Her feature length horror film The
Howlers is scheduled to go into production in the summer of 2017. Her play Silencer, was most recently seen at
NYC’s Festival of the Offensive after a run at Edinburgh’s Pleasance in 2012. Her
short horror film Noctulent was
produced in 2009. She is currently working on a new novel called On Sea. As a producer, she is currently
producing The Intergalactic Nemesis: Twin
Infinity for Edinburgh in August 2016, as well as acting as a consulting
producer on this wonderful Women And War Festival. Selected producing credits
include Nothing To Hide (dir. Neil
Patrick Harris), Martin McDonagh’s A
Behanding in Spokane (Broadway), On
The Line, Judas & Me (Chad Beguelin & Matt Sklar), Theatre O’s Three Dark Tales, and Texarkana Waltz. Previously she acted
as Associate Producer for Ostar Productions, working on Broadway shows
including Thurgood, Inherit The Wind,
Spamalot, The Country Girl, Impressionism and The Seafarer. With Ostar, she produced workshop versions of Nora
Ephron’s Love, Loss and What I Wore
and the opera Innocence (Jonathan
Dove and Alaisdair Middleton). She was the originating Artistic Director of the
Summer Play Festival in NYC for the first two seasons in 2004 and 2005. She
also provides creative consultation to film and theatre companies.
www.RachelNeuburger.com
MIRIAM IBRAHIM - Director, is the founder of
LabelGray.org, she grew up in Germany and Ethiopia, began performing in
high school and later graduated in 2005 from Stage School Music, Dance and
Drama Hamburg. Throughout various theaters in Germany she played roles in
Crucible (Theater Bonn), Hair (Theater an der Rott) and Mutter Afrika
(Deutsches Schauspielhaus Hamburg) and others. She always had a passion to
teach and create her own performances. She moved to New York City in 2010 to
study the 2 Year Evening Conservatory at the Stella Adler Studio of Acting.
In New York she played in Eastern Standard, Escape from Happiness, Crucible,
Vestiges, Piece/Peace of Mine. In addition to her work as an actress she
directed and thought for BINI e.V., Backstage Hamburg, Geminin Trust Ethiopia,
Mad-Playhouse NYC, Rebel Theater Company and Label Gray. She has been assisting
for John Gould Rubin in NYC and for the Herbstsalon for Maxim Gorki Theater
Berlin. She just finished her studies at Freie Universität Berlin in Theater
and Social-/Cultural Anthropology. Miriam believes that Art and Theater give us
the possibility of a complex perspective of the things in and outside of life,
that it can unfold the unseen and the things hidden in between. www.miriamibrahim.com
ZOE HUTMACHER - Actress, is of German, Swiss and Italian heritage. In 2001 she trained as an actress in Hamburg, Germany, earning her diploma in 2004. Upon graduating she has played in various theatres throughout Germany, New York and Switzerland. Between 2007-2011, Zoe was a permanent company member at the Theaterhaus Jena and at the Theater Basel from 2012-2015. She has performed at: Thalia Theater Hamburg, Deutsches Schauspielhaus Hamburg, St. Pauli Theater, Secret Theater LIC/NY, Staatstheater Braunschweig, Deutsches Theater Berlin, Kampnagel Hamburg, Theaterhaus Jena and Sophiensäle. Zoe has had the pleasure to work with: Calixto Bieito, Romeo Castelluccuci, Cilli Drexel, Julia Hölschwer, Rayka Kobiella, Andreas Kriegenburg, Richard Maxwell and many more. Zoe loves to act on stage or in front of the camera. Currently she is performing, Kristine Linde in, A Doll’s House at the Concert Theater Bern, Switzerland. www.zoehutmacher.com

"It is so important for us to never forget, though growing up with my
fathers family who escaped the Nazis, sporadically from 1938 to 1942, there was
a need to try to forget that I saw in my grandparents. My father was too young
to remember anything, as he was two when they fled to Paraguay. In my far too
little 22 years that I had with my grandparents, they never mentioned the
Holocaust and I never asked. Many years after they passed away, I began to have
guilt about never asking, but eventually realized that it was the last thing
they would have wanted. For them, the absolute joy of having grandchildren who
could run around free, never having to suffer a moment of what they suffered,
was an undoubted gift to them. Even though they sat in an apartment in Brookline,
MA, not doing a hell of a lot, what a gift to my grandfather saying  not
much but to be able to walk the quarter mile to pray a schul every day…" R. Neuburger

story:
About Us

  • We create dance to inspire action to better our community
  • 1 in 4 adults suffer from a diagnosable mental illness each year
  • Erasing the stigma of mental illness will promote acceptance, create a safer world, and even save lives!
  • We will START the conversation. Help us KEEP IT GOING!


What We Need & What You Get

  • It costs money to produce a show. And being that we are not just producing a dance show, but incorporating projection, animation, and video, this project will take at least $10,000 to bring to fruition. But the result will be an unforgettable experience for all involved from behind the scenes to in the audience...and the opportunity for mental illness to HAVE A VOICE. 
  • WHAT'S IN IT FOR YOU? Anyone who donates $100 will receive two free tickets to this evening's event- and if you are not in town...you will receive a link to our Live Stream for the performance :) 
  • Even if we do not reach our goal of $10,000- we will still perform the evening of Sep 25- we will still bring our stories to our audience, and we will still provide a platform for people to TALK openly about mental illness, to ask all kinds of questions, and to SEEK HELP if it is needed. This is SO IMPORTANT! 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out! Put our page on your Social Media! SPREAD THE WORD, and that is a Great Help!

story:
About the Festival

The 2nd Latin Festival Madras will happen between 2nd to 4th October, 2015. 

The Latin Festival Madras was started in 2014 by SALSA MADRAS run by Arun Srinivasan to bring in an International Afro and Latin Dance experience in Chennai, one of the leading destinations for SALSA in India.  The objective of the festival is to bring in International artists to showcase and share the passion for Afro and Latin Dances in Chennai, to create more awareness and for improving the quality of the instructors and dancers in Chennai and India

  • Arun Srinivasan has been teaching in India for the last 6 years and now one of the leading artists in Asia to teach, perform and compete.
  • SALSA MADRAS founded in 2014 strives to bring the best of Afro and Latin dance experience through classes, socials, workshops, parties, events, festivals, congresses and also promoting salsa festivals organised across Asia
  • With Latin Festival Madras, Chennai is now of the best destinations to go dancing salsa, bachata and kizomba alike and has been a trend-setter in making the festival a truly International experience with participants from more than 10 countries attending the event. 

The Festival has been a big contribution to the quality of dancing in the city and would create much more awareness towards social dancing involving Latin Dances

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • The funding is essentially to cover the costs involving flights, stay, food, and the professional fee for all the invited artists from different parts for the world to teach, perform and dance with all the dancers at the festival 
  • For every contribution there is something exciting you get in return, be it as simple as a Festival T-shirt or the full access to attend the festival and experience the festival at its best. 
  • Even if the target isn't reached, it will still help in covering the expenses partly that could still be a great help in hosting the festival for the SALSA Community in Chennai

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Chennai is relatively new in Latin World but has been progressing greatly in the last few years. Your contribution will help put Chennai as one of the favourite salsa destinations in Asia, also helping the dancers from other countries to come and experience India through the wonderful city - Chennai
  • SALSA MADRAS has organised the 1st Latin Festival Madras 2014, 5 editions of Kizomba pool parties, hosts 3 socials every week at 3 different venues and is also promoter of salsa festivals in India and Asia, viz. Singapore International Latin Festival, Manila boracay Latin dance festival, Salsa Pattaya Tropicana Vacation, India fiesta Latina, etc.
  • With about 10 International artists, an International DJ and expected 100-150 participants this is an event targeted to benefit not just individuals but also upcoming Latin Instructors and schools.

Risks & Challenges

The greatest risk is to be able to cover the costs of the artists and the logistics involved in the festival, making it a memorable experience for all the dancers

  • The Greatest challenge is to reach out to the right participation from Chennai, other cities and other countries that would benefit from the International artists. 
  • SALSA MADRAS will reach out to all the leading Latin Dances schools and teams to come and experience the festival.

Other Ways You Can Help

It doesnt matter if you can't contribute but you can help us in our initiative to make Chennai a Latin dance favourite 

  • Please spread the word to your fellow dance friends to come and attend the festival.
  • Subscribe to the updates at www.latinfestivalmadras.in 
  • Share www.facebook.com/latinfestmadras to your friends
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Help build Maryland School of Dance!

Thank you to everyone who contributed to our campaign!!!!  Keep a look out in your inbox for Perk fulfillment!

To keep up to date about all things MSD, please join our mailing list here: http://marylandschoolofdance.org/contact

Again, thank you to everyone for donating, sharing, and spreading the word and I look forward to seeing you at the studio!

May 15, 2015

Thank you to everyone for donating, supporting and sharing our campaign!!! In honor of an extremely successful campaign, I give you "The Potato Dance" choreographed by: The Dancers.  Enjoy =] 


May 8, 2015

It’s only been a week, but Maryland School of Dance’s campaign has been busy!

Thanks to your generosity and support we’ve raised $10,420 in just 7 days!

Our 50 funders have claimed 4 pliés, 8 rond de jambes, 7 pirouettes, 2 arabesques and 1 tour en l’air!

As the founder of MSD, and on behalf of our future students, I offer my most sincere thanks to everyone who has contributed, supported and shared our campaign.  Keep it up and spread the word! Every donation, no matter what the size, helps bring us toward our goal. 



May 1, 2015

Maryland School of Dance is dedicated to providing high quality dance education to students of all ages and varying abilities. Through a dance education, MSD is committed to building a community, which fosters the development of artistic, dedicated, respectful and confident individuals. MSD will provide a nurturing environment for students to explore artistry and creativity while refining their dance technique. 

We are seeking:

- $35,000 for a sprung Marley floor

- $5,000 for mirrors

- $500 for barres

All other funds will go toward building out our new space in Rockville, MD.

Your contribution will not only help build a home for an existing community of dancers, but will provide a space for future MSD students to learn, dance and grow as creative individuals. 

Our most sincere thanks for your generosity and support!

- Kim Parmer, Founder & Director of MSD




Kim Parmer has taught around the DC area at American Dance Institute, Joy of Motion Dance Center, and is the Artistic Director of Georgetown University Dance Company. Originally from Long Island, she has studied with renowned teachers, Maggie Black, Elena Kunikova and Fabrice Herrault. She attended North Carolina School of the Arts, where she studied with Melissa Hayden, and the Walnut Hill School under the direction of Michael Owen. Ms. Parmer is a former dancer, choreographer, and rehearsal director for MOVEIUS Contemporary Ballet and has danced with regional companies in the Boston, Chicago, and New York City area. Ms. Parmer holds her B.A. in Psychology from Boston University and is a certified teacher in the ABT® National Training Curriculum, levels Primary-Seven. Under the tutelage of Raymond Lukens, Franco De Vita and Susan Koff, Ms. Parmer is a graduate of New York University's Master's program in Dance Education with a concentration in American Ballet Theatre Ballet Pedagogy.

story:
Yes, Because... it's time!

Thunder's Mouth Theatre has a grand new show to get on the road, and we need your help to make sure our audiences know about it.

  • I'm Flloyd Kennedy, aka Dame June Bloom (singing clown, Shakespeare actor, raconteur, chanteuse) 
  • Following the success of our last Dame June Bloom production, 'The Fall of June Bloom (or What You Will)', which toured to New York, Dunedin NZ, Phoenix AZ and Brisbane Australia, we've created a brand new show in which June gets to sing and reminisce about her life on the road, as well as sharing her great love for Shakespeare's sonnets
  • Our Brisbane season - 6th, 7th and 8th September - needs to be promoted and recorded!

Your contributions will help to fund a gloriously professional marketing and promotional campaign including a fabulous video, ensuring that audiences know who we are and why, and where and how they can find Dame June as she heads off on tour again!

When: 6th, 7th, 8th September. 7.00 pm

Where: New Globe Theatre, 220 Brunswick Street, Fortitude Valley, Brisbane

“It’s seriously funny!”

“Delightfully driven with stories, verse speaking and song, Flloyd brings such presence and power to her gorgeously vulnerable and funny DAME JUNE.”

What We Need & What You Get

Help us fund our marketing and promotion campaign

  • The wonderful people at Oblong + Son have come on board to design and brand the production, the amazing folk at the QBI - Clem Jones Centre for Ageing and Dementia Research have chipped in to cover printing costs. Now  we need to raise enough to pay for marketing and distribution experts to make sure we reach our target audience of seniors - and their kids and grandkids. We also need a great promotional video and a clear and entertaining web page.
  • You can take your pick of some great perks, from tickets to see the show in Brisbane, (or wherever June's forthcoming UK/European tour takes her) to a personal coaching session (in person or on Skype) with Dame June Bloom for you or your nominated participant. June (well ok, it's really Flloyd) specialises in voice, speech, accents (dialects), public presentation skills, and - of course - Shakespeare - but she can also help you get started with that ukulele you've been longing to play, or coach you with your singing.
  • Every cent we raise will help to raise the profile of Thunder's Mouth Theatre, and in particular this production, "Yes, Because..." featuring Dame June Bloom. If we reach our goal, we know we will have the best marketing and promotion campaign that money can buy.

The Impact

This show is pretty special, appealing to young and old alike, providing a bridge across that generation gap that lets teenagers and grandparents meet up for a bit of a rave in the middle. 

June has a way of using Shakespeare's sonnets to reveal some personal insights while making a metaphysical point. Her songs are joyfully quirky and poignant,  her stories full of the wonder and the pain of a life well-lived.

The last June Bloom show you helped us to produce travelled from Brisbane to New York, Phoenix Arizona to Dunedin and back again. It was performed in college halls, Fringe theatre venues and even bedrooms for people who couldn't make it out of their sick beds! We call that Bedsite Theatre, and we want to do more of it.

  • Help us to spread the word far and wide, by having super attractive and inspiring, professionally produced promotional material that tells it as it is!

Risks & Challenges

Creating great theatre is always, first and foremost, our aim. This doesn't mean BIG, or SPECTACULAR. The size and spectacle we create exists in the imagination of the audience. We want to build audiences wherever we go, to perform for people who don't know that theatre is for them, for people who can't make it to the theatre, for communities who don't have a theatre space. 

  • We know these audiences are out there.  We just don't have the specialised skills ourselves to reach them, so that we can bring the show to them. We need to engage a team of experts who know how to do this.
  • The first step is already in motion, with Oblong + Son creating our new image and design portfolio.  Now we need to bring in the marketing team and the videographer to get the word out.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can contribute to this campaign by making a donation, or by helping to spread the word amongst your own friends and colleagues.  

  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Now  we need to raise enough to pay for marketing and distribution experts to make sure we reach our target audience of seniors - and their kids and grandkids. We also need a great promotional video and a clear and entertaining web page. You can take your pick of some great perks, from tickets to see the show in Brisbane, (or wherever June's forthcoming UK/European tour takes her) to a personal coaching session (in person or on Skype) with Dame June Bloom for you or your nominated participant. June (well ok, it's really Flloyd) specialises in voice, speech, accents (dialects), public presentation skills, and - of course - Shakespeare - but she can also help you get started with that ukulele you've been longing to play, or coach you with your singing. Every cent we raise will help to raise the profile of Thunder's Mouth Theatre, and in particular this production, "Yes, Because..." featuring Dame June Bloom. If we reach our goal, we know we will have the best marketing and promotion campaign that money can buy.    The Impact This show is pretty special, appealing to young and old alike, providing a bridge across that generation gap that lets teenagers and grandparents meet up for a bit of a rave in the middle. 
June has a way of using Shakespeare's sonnets to reveal some personal insights while making a metaphysical point. Her songs are joyfully quirky and poignant,  her stories full of the wonder and the pain of a life well-lived.
The last June Bloom show you helped us to produce travelled from Brisbane to New York, Phoenix Arizona to Dunedin and back again. It was performed in college halls, Fringe theatre venues and even bedrooms for people who couldn't make it out of their sick beds! We call that Bedsite Theatre, and we want to do more of it.  Help us to spread the word far and wide, by having super attractive and inspiring, professionally produced promotional material that tells it as it is!    Risks & Challenges  Creating great theatre is always, first and foremost, our aim. This doesn't mean BIG, or SPECTACULAR. The size and spectacle we create exists in the imagination of the audience. We want to build audiences wherever we go, to perform for people who don't know that theatre is for them, for people who can't make it to the theatre, for communities who don't have a theatre space.   We know these audiences are out there.  We just don't have the specialised skills ourselves to reach them, so that we can bring the show to them. We need to engage a team of experts who know how to do this. The first step is already in motion, with Oblong + Son creating our new image and design portfolio.  Now we need to bring in the marketing team and the videographer to get the word out.    Other Ways You Can Help You can contribute to this campaign by making a donation, or by helping to spread the word amongst your own friends and colleagues.    
Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

I am a young emerging dance artist with a passion for life, collaboration and bringing people together. Money has always been a issue that I quietly ignore as I am passionate about what I do, yet at times it stops me in my tracks.  I am a passionate and enthusiastic teacher, dancer and I am very excited to now being able to explore my choreographic voice for the first time. The body has always fascinated me and this piece has allowed me to explore what my own body can do whilst posing many interesting questions to the audience and myself as a performer. Its quite a challenging and clever (according to a recent review from @SteveStraford9) piece that i feel is quite traditional and classical yet has a modern twist. I want to take this show to the Edinburgh Fringe in order to raise the show's profile, access more audience, and so begin my journey as a new and exciting choreographer. 

What We Need & What You Get

I have been invited to perform at the festival by American Choreographer Susana B. Williams, which is am amazing opportunity as very few artists have been selected to perform under the 'Danceforms Choreographic Showcase'. Thanks to my AMAZING parents, I have been given a loan (which I will start paying back in september so hopfully I can get more paid work by then haha) which has covered the platform fee of around £1000, which includes my technical rehearsal, accommodation and all my marketing and press coverage at the festival. I still need to raise a lot more in order to have a successful time at the festival. I have very little funds available at present, so any donations will help pay my food so that I may stay fit and healthy. It will also enable me to see other artists work and so make good networking opportunities for possible future work, collaberations and in general to supoort the British arts scene. At a time where the arts could face further cuts from the government, we all need to stand together and help each . The Fringe is the most competitive market in which to advertise a performance, and to help further my networking opportunities and raise ticket sales,I have decided to create my own flyers of which i can advertise myself on the street to all the crowd. This will be funded by myself. Even though i will have the support of Susana's platform, I will be there by myself which is quite daunting.

Any box office share I get from my performances, 10% will be donated B.e.a.t and MacMillan Cancer, two charities very close to my heart. 


The perks that you will get for helping me are aimed at me sharing the work with you. Images, a video of my performance, a live sound score of my 'silent' piece and tickets to see the show. 


The Impact

Your donation will mean that more people see this work, more people give money to both my chosen charities , more tickets are sold and the run at the Fringe can be a great success. Your donation will enable me to share my first professional piece at a national level, and so hopefully create future contacts. It will also give the audience a unique and personal experience as each performance of my solo will be different.

Risks & Challenges

I am willing to put my as much on my own limited  funds into the project as i can, and will most likely have to. Any profit will go to both my charities and any future work that i may develop. I am currently looking at other funding sources including a bank loan.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the campaign with friends and family. Spread the word about this and about the show itself. Thank you so much in advance and i hope to see you there in Edinburgh :)

story: The Luckenbooth Theatre Collective is DFW's newest theatre company: 100% of the funds raised will go to funding our first season's productions and the classes we will offer to varying artistic organizations in the community!
story_txt: The Luckenbooth Theatre Collective is DFW's newest theatre company: 100% of the funds raised will go to funding our first season's productions and the classes we will offer to varying artistic organizations in the community!

story:
The Show

1945. Dresden, Germany. Lizzie, her mother - and an elephant from the zoo, flee the Allied fire-bombing in the end-game of the Second World War.

by Michael Morpurgo
adapted and directed by Simon Reade
performed by Alison Reid

Poonamallee Productions is remounting this hugely successful show which was first performed at the Northcott Theatre, Exeter and The Tobacco Factory Theatre, Bristol.

"This is masterful storytelling by all concerned and a gem of a standout
performance"  StageTalk Magazine  


What We Need
We need funding to allow us to underwrite our costs (insurance, marketing, travel and accommodation) as we work on a shoestring travelling around the country from Norfolk via the West Coast of Wales, to London and back to Bristol, bringing this important story to children, young people and adults alike.

The Creative Team

  • Performer Alison Reid
  • Adaptor & Director Simon Reade
  • Designer Max Johns
  • Costumes  Elizabeth De-Tisi
  • Lighting Matthew Graham
  • Sound Jason Barnes
  • Stage Manager Steffi Procter

Michael Morpurgo is the multi-award winning author of well over 100 books including 'War Horse', 'Private Peaceful' and 'Kensuke's Kingdom'.

An Elephant in the Garden is the new adaptation by Simon Reade from Michael Morpurgo's best selling children's novel. It is very much in the theatrical mould of their previous collaborations on Michael's war stories Toro!Toro!, The Mozart Question and 5 star hit theatrical touring phenomenon Private Peaceful .

Alison Reid has worked extensively as an actress at the RSC, for Filter Theatre, at Bristol Old Vic, Tobacco Factory Theatres and at the National Theatre.

"An Elephant in the Garden is just the right length to engage its youthful target audience. It's also a perfect opportunity for them to discover the magic that only live theatre can offer: the ability to suspend disbelief and allow an actor to play on your imagination, conjuring up worlds out of thin air."

Bristol 24/7


Here is some rehearsal footage - (you'll need to turn the volume up)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in the position to contribute please do buy a ticket and come to see the show and remember to share the link with your friends.

AN ELEPHANT IN THE GARDEN UK TOUR 2016

London, Vault Festival, Waterloo, Sat Jan 30, 2.45pm
London, Vault Festival, Waterloo, Sun Jan 31, 2.45pm
http://www.vaultfestival.com/
Theatre Royal, Bury St Edmunds, Feb 1, 7pm
Theatre Royal, Bury St Edmunds, Feb 2, 1.30pm
http://www.theatreroyal.org/shows/an-elephant-in-the-garden/
London, Vault Festival, Waterloo, Sat Feb 6, 2.45pm
London, Vault Festival, Waterloo, Sun Feb 7, 2.45pm
http://www.vaultfestival.com/
Bristol Old Vic Studio, February 9th - 13th, 3pm (7pm on Fri) 
http://www.bristololdvic.org.uk/elephantinthegarden.html
Aberystwyth Arts Centre, Tue Feb 16, 2pm
https://www.aberystwythartscentre.co.uk/

story:
Spring 2015 marks Sans Limites Dance’s fifth performance season, featuring new works by Artistic Director Diana Pettersen that explore the theme of marriage equality, develop a new movement technique employing only one pointe shoe, and experiment with humor in dance.  These pieces will be performed by Sans Limites Dance Company Members: Elliott Keller, Lindsey Lykowski, Rhys Martin, Susanne McHugh, Casie O'Kane, Taylor Paige, Boonyarith Pankamdech, and Shelley White.

This season will also include the fifth installment of the Sans Limites Dance Guest Choreographers Program.  Since 2013, we have produced pieces by over 30 emerging and mid-career choreographers at nominal cost to these artists. 

For the first time, we are presenting six choreographers with the Lounsbery Award, affording them free tech and performance space, light design, stage management, and marketing. This is made possible by our Technical Director, Michael Lounsbery, who donates his time, skill, and resources to producing each season.

The inaugural group of Lounsbery Awardees is composed of: Aaron Atkins of Ballet, Inc., Yuka Kawazu of Danse en L'air, Cameron McKinney of Kizuna Dance, Joe Monteleone of Monteleone Collective, Ella Rosewood of Ella Rosewood Dance, and Sarah Zehnder of Zehnder Dance.

Each Sans Limites Dance season not only presents the work of our Artistic Director Diana Pettersen, but also promotes the work of a growing number of choreographers.  We need your support in an effort to push financial limits out of the picture for our community of choreographers and dancers.

Donations to this campaign will contribute to production and marketing costs for the Sans Limites Dance Spring and Winter seasons.  Reaching our campaign goal of $12,000 will allow us to:
  • offer a new round of Lounsbery Awards,
  • pay a select group of choreographers to mount new works in our Winter Season,
  • increase compensation for Sans Limites Dance company dancers,
  • and strengthen our promotional efforts in order to widen exposure for the approximately 30 dance groups participating in our Spring and Winter seasons.

Choreographers, dancers, and artists of all kinds continually struggle with keeping their dreams alive.  Your tax-deductible contribution will ensure this unique communal endeavor toward dance without limits doesn’t fade. 

Help us fill the dance world with this vision.  Donate now and share our campaign with friends on social media and via e-mail.


Learn more about our Artistic Director's work and vision by listening to her interview on Pod de Deux, a new podcast series about contemporary issues and life in the dance community.


Follow us!

Facebook - /SansLimitesDance

Instagram - @sanslimitesd

Twitter - @sanslimitesd


Visit our website:

www.sanslimitesdance.com


Contact us:
info@sanslimitesdance.com

Sans Limites Dance is a community of artists and arts professionals that moves beyond limits.  We break down financial obstacles for emerging choreographers and dancers by fully producing their work at nominal cost.  We prowl city streets to claim public spaces as pop-up performance stages.  We sway and twirl with urban communities, providing affordable youth dance instruction and supporting community initiatives.  We pierce through the fourth wall to create collaborative experiences that blur the line between art and life.  

Volunteer Staff:
Diana Pettersen, Artistic Director
Michael Lounsbery, Technical Director
Erika Pettersen, Development Director
